ques: The concept of differential heating was primarily given to explain which of the following geographical phenomena in India?
ans_detail: Notes: The concept of differential heating about the origin of Indian Monsoon was given by Halley.

ques: Polavaram Project is located in which state?
The controversial Babli project is a barrage being built by Maharashtra Government across which among the following rivers?
ans_detail: Notes:The Babli reservoir project is being constructed by Maharashtra across the river Godavari. It was disputed by Telangana and in 2013, Supreme Court delivered a ruling after seven years in favour of Maharashtra.

ques: Which among the following state produces maximum raw silk in India?
ans_detail: Notes:Karnataka accounted for as much as 60% of the country’s raw silk output

ques: India’s Andaman and Nicobar Islands share a maritime border with which among the following?
options: ["Thailand","Thailand and Indonesia","Thailand, Sri Lanka and Indonesia","Thailand and Sri Lanka"]

ques: Which among the following is the largest river system among the Deccan system of rivers?
ans_detail:
Notes:With a length of 1465 Kilometers, Godavari is India’s second largest river that runs within the country and also the longest river in South India. It originates near Trimbak in Nashik District of Maharashtra state and flows east across the Deccan Plateau into the Bay of Bengal near Narasapuram in West Godavari district of Andhra Pradesh.
The river is also known as Dakshin Ganga and Gautami. The Manjra and Indravati rivers are its major tributaries.

ques: Which among the following was the first port in India to be a Public Company?
Phawngpui in Mizoram is also known as which of the following?
ans_detail: Notes:Phawngpui or Blue Mountain, is the highest mountain peak in the Mizo Hills (Lushai Hills) and in Mizoram.

ques: Raniganj coal bed methane  (CBM) acreage is located in which of the following states ?
ans_detail: Notes:Raniganj is located near Asansol of Paschim Bardhaman district in West Bengal. ONGC is operating Raniganj North CBM block.

ques: Which among the following rivers is known as Yarlung Tsangpo in Tibet?
The death of Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb occurred at which among the following places?
ans_detail: Notes: Aurangzeb had died in Ahmednagar on 20 February 1707 at the age of 88. Unlike other earlier Mughals, he was buried in a modest open-air grave in Khuldabad, which shows his deep devotion to his Islamic beliefs.

ques: Which among the following was the single biggest item of import to the Vijayanagar empire?
ans_detail: Notes:Kings of Vijayanagar, imported Arabian horses on a large scale, in order to improve the breed of cavalry horses in their own districts. Thus, the single biggest item of import to the Vijayanagar empire was Horses.

ques: Who was Sultan of Delhi Sultanate when Timur invaded India in 1398?
options: ["Mahmud Shah Tughluq","Jalal ud din Firuz Khilji","Aram Shah","Ghiyas-ud-din Balban"]
ans_detail: Notes:Mahmud Shah Tughlaq was the last sultan of the Tughlaq dynasty to rule the Islamic Delhi Sultanate. During his reign in 1398, Amir Timur the Chagtai ruler invaded India. He carried away with him a large booty from Delhi and the surrounding area. Soon after the invasion, the Tughlaq dynasty came to an end.

ques: Which one of the following books is the official History of Revolt of 1857 published by publication division ,Ministry of Information and broadcasting ,Government of India?
options: ["Eighteen Fifty Seven","Theories of Indian Mutiny","The Sepoy Mutiny and the Revolt of 1857","None of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:Eighteen Fifty Seven was written by well known Indian Historian Dr. Surendra Nath Sen ,with a foreword by Maulana Azad. It was published on May 1957 by the publication division, Ministry of Information and broadcasting, Government of India.

ques: Out of Capital of Akbar’s Kingdom, Buland Darwaja , Panch Mahal and Akbar’s Mausoleum , which are located at the same place?
options: ["Panch Mahal and Akbar’s Mausoleum","Buland Darwaja , Panch Mahal and Akbar’s Mausoleum","Capital of Akbar’s Kingdom, Buland Darwaja , Panch Mahal","Capital of Akbar’s Kingdom and Akbar’s Mausoleum"]
ans: Capital of Akbar’s Kingdom, Buland Darwaja , Panch Mahal
ans_detail: Notes:Capital of Akbar Kingdom, Buland Darwaja , Panch Mahal  (all fatehpur sikri ) mausoleum at Sikandara

ques: Who built the tomb of itmad ud daula?
ans_detail: Notes:The Tomb of Itimad-Ud-Daula was constructed by the Mughal queen Nur Jahan. IT was constructed between 1622 and 1628 where her father Itimad Ud Daula was buried.

ques: In which of the following forts Jahanagir Mahal is located ?
ans_detail: Notes:Jahangir Mahal is located In Agra fort , built by Akbar in Hindu Design and was used by the Rajput wives of Akba

ques: Sakambhari near Ajmer is a place related to emergence of which of the following dynasties?
ans_detail: Notes:Sakambhari near Ajmer is a place related to emergence of Chauhanas. They ruled parts of the present-day Rajasthan and its neighbouring areas between 6th and 12th centuries.

ques: Which of the following Mughal Emperors shifted his imperial court and residence from Agra to Sikri, later renamed as Fatehpur Sikri?
ans_detail: Notes:Akbar is the Mughal emperor who shifted his imperial court and residence deom Agra to Sikri. Fatehpur Sikri is a town in the Agra District of Uttar Pradesh, India. The city itself was founded as the capital of Mughal Empire in 1571 by Emperor Akbar.

ques: Mirza Ghalib was a contemporary of which among the following Mughal Emperors?
ans_detail: Notes:Mirza Ghalib was a prominent Urdu and Persian poet. He served during the last years of the Mughal Empire. He was contemporary of Bahadur Shah Zafar.

ques: The Gajner Wildlife Sanctuary (GWS) is located in which state?
ans_detail: Notes:The Gajner Wildlife Sanctuary (GWS) is located at a distance of about 32.0 km from Bikaner in Rajasthan. There is a lake in this sanctuary and a variety of animals come here to quench their thirst in summer. It is a lush green forest which is a haven to the nilgai, chinkara, black buck, wild boar, flocks of imperial sand grouse and many other species of migratory birds that make the sprawling forest their winter home. This is one of the proposed forests for the reintroduction of cheetahs in India.

ques: Eutrophication is due to lack of oxygen and severe reductions in water quality, fish, and other animal populations which ultimately destroys the particular ecosystem
options: ["Increased pollution in water bodies","Increased chemical nutrients and compounds containing nitrogen or phosphorus","increased microbes and parasitic organism in stagnant water","None of the above"]
ans: Increased chemical nutrients and compounds containing nitrogen or phosphorus
ans_detail: Notes:Eutrophication is when a body of water becomes overly enriched with minerals and nutrients which impetus to excessive growth of algae. It causes oxygen depletion of the water body. Due to this problem algal bloom occurs which is the increase of phytoplankton.

ques: Many a times we read in the newspapers about Clean Development Mechanism
options: ["It allows industrialized countries with a greenhouse gas reduction commitment to invest in projects that reduce emissions in developing countries as an alternative to more expensive emission reductions in their own countries","The CDM allows net global greenhouse gas emissions to be reduced at a much lower global cost by financing emissions reduction projects in developing countries where costs are lower than in industrialized countries","It is an arrangement under Geneva Protocol","It is an arrangement under Kyoto Protocol"]
ans: It is an arrangement under Geneva Protocol
ans_detail: Notes:The Clean Development Mechanism was defined in the Kyoto Protocol which provides for emissions reduction projects. It allows industrialized countries with a greenhouse gas reduction commitment to invest in projects that reduce emissions in developing countries as an alternative to more expensive emission reductions in their own countries. The CDM allows net global greenhouse gas emissions to be reduced at a much lower global cost by financing emissions reduction projects in developing countries where costs are lower than in industrialized countries.

ques: Who heads the National Disaster Management Authority in India?
options: ["Home Minister of India","Prime Minister of India","Prime Minister of India","President of India"]
ans_detail: Notes:The Disaster Management Act, 2005 received the Presidential assent on 23 December, 2005. It envisaged the creation of the National Disaster Management Authority with not more than nine members (including a Vice-Chairperson) and the Prime Minister of India as its chairperson.

ques: With which among the following subjects, the Agenda 21 , that came out of Earth Summit 1992 , explicitly deals with ?
ans_detail: Notes:Agenda 21 is yet another outcome of the 1992 Earth Summit. It is the “Voluntary” action plan of the United Nations (UN) related to sustainable development. This 40 point document was a comprehensive blueprint of action to be taken globally, nationally and locally by organizations of the UN, governments, and major groups in every area in which humans directly affect the environment.

ques: Which Green House Gas is created by the accumulated Waste Water?
ans_detail: Notes:Methane gas is produced by the decomposition of organic waste in an oxygen-free environment. The treatment and handling of waste water also produces Methane.

ques: The Ozone Day is observed in memory of signing of which of the following protocols?
ans_detail: Notes:The Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer was an international treaty which was organized in 1987. The UN General Assembly celebrate 16th September in memory of the date in 1987 when nations inked the Montreal Protocol.

ques: The ‘Montreaux Record’ is a register of:
options: ["Invasive Alien Species and their ecological hazards outside their native environment.","Wetland sites under the threat of anthropogenic activities.","Endangered species of tropical and sub-tropical fauna","Coastal cities under direct threat of consequences of global warming."]
ans: Wetland sites under the threat of anthropogenic activities.
ans_detail: Notes:The Montreux Record is a register of wetland sites under the threat of anthropogenic activities (on the List of Ramsar wetlands of international importance). Presently 48 sites are listed in Montreux Record.

ques: Consider the following statements about National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA):It is an agency of the Ministry of Home AffairsThe Prime Minister is the ex-officio chairperson of NDMA Which of the above statements is/are correct?
ans_detail: Notes:National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) is an agency of the Ministry of Home Affairs whose primary purpose is to coordinate response to natural or man-made disasters and for capacity-building in disaster resiliency and crisis response. The Prime Minister is the ex-officio chairperson of NDMA.

ques: Consider the following:Albedo effectAerosols in atmosphereWater vapour Which of the above has/have contributed to Global Warming?
ans_detail: Notes:All three are major contributors to Global Warming.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: During the reign of which Kushana king, the Fourth Buddhist Council was held?
ans_detail: Notes: The Fourth Buddhist Council was held at Kundalvana, Kashmir in 72 AD during the reign of Kushan king Kanishka. It was held under the Presidentship of Vasumitra to compose commentaries on the Tripitika.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: In which rock edict Ashoka mentioned “Every Human is my child…”?
options: ["Major Rock Edict V","Major Rock Edict IV","Major Rock Edict VI","Major Rock Edict VII"]
ans_detail: Notes: In the major Rock Edict V, Ashoka mentioned “Every Human is my child”. He had concerns about the policy towards slaves. This rock edict also referes to the appointment of Dhamma-mahamatta for the first time in the twelfth year of his reign.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: In the Maurya empire, who was the superintendent of Ports ?
ans_detail: Notes: As per the officials mentioned in the Arthashastra, Pattanadhyaksha was the superintendent of Ports.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: In which state of India, the first Paleolithic site was discovered?
ans_detail: Notes: The first evidence of the Stone Age culture in India surfaced in Karnataka as early as in 1842 when Dr. Primrose discovered polished stone knives and arrow heads at Lingsugur in Raichur district of Karnataka.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: “Revere all the Buddhas, revere the dharma, revere the sangha” Which among the following quotes this _________?

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: The place Dharanikota in South India is related to which ancient dynasty?
ans_detail: Notes: Dharanikota is a town near Amaravati in the Guntur district of Andhra Pradesh in India, It is the site of the ancient Dhanyakataka which was the capital of the Satavahana kingdom which ruled in the Deccan around the 1st to 3rd centuries A.D.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Who overthrew Saka rulers from India?
ans_detail: Notes: The sakas were finally overthrown by Gautamiputra Satakarni, the ruler of Satavahana dynasty. He killed Saka ruler Nahapana and his governor Rishavadatta and restored his territories.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions

options: ["Bolan Pass","Nathu La Pass","Shipki La Pass","Bara-lacha la Pass"]
ans_detail: Notes: The Sakas came to India through the Bolan Pass. They were a Scythian tribe or group of tribes of Iranian origin.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Who among the following had written “Rajavalipataka”?
Grand Slam is used in which of the following games?
ans_detail: Notes:In tennis, a Grand Slam is the achievement of winning all four major tournaments in the same calendar year. The four major tournaments in tennis are the Australian Open, the French Open, Wimbledon, and the US Open. Winning all four of these tournaments in the same year is considered one of the greatest achievements in the sport, and players who accomplish this feat are considered among the all-time greats of tennis. The term “Grand Slam” is also used to refer to winning all four major tournaments at some point in a player’s career, although this is less commonly referred to as a “career Grand Slam.”

ques: What is the approximate maximum weight of Golf Ball as per Rules of Golf?
ans_detail: Notes:1.62 oz which is equivalent to 45.93 gms.

ques: What is the other name of Sir Garfield Sobers Trophy?
options: ["ICC Cricketer of the Year Awards","ICC Test Captain of the Year","Spirit of the Cricket Awards","Test Player of the Year Award"]
ans: ICC Cricketer of the Year Awards

ques: Who among the following players is considered the greatest Hockey players in the history of Hockey and was also offered a senior position in the German Army by Adolf Hitler?
options: ["Dhyan Chand","Lal Shah Bokhari","Kishan Lal","Jaipal Singh Munda"]
ans_detail: Notes:Dhyan Chand was an Indian Hockey player and is considered as one of the greatest Hockey player in the history of the sport. He helped India win three Olympic Golds (1928, 1932 and 1936). Swimming Which is the International governing body of Swimming in the world?

ques: Which is the governing body Chess in the world?
options: ["World Chess Federation","World Chess Association","World Chess Organisation","Association of World Chess Champions"]
ans_detail: Notes:World Chess Federation is the governing body of World Chess. It is an international organisation which connects various national chess organisations.

ques: How many teams currently participate in the Commonwealth Games?
ans_detail: Notes:There are 53 members of the Commonwealth of Nations. But, 71 teams currently participate in the Commonwealth Games as a number of dependent territories compete under their own flag.

ques: Which Indian woman wrestler won a bronze in the Rio Olympics?
ans_detail: Notes:Shakshi Malik, from Haryana state won a bronze medal in the Rio Olympics. She is the first Indian female wrestler to win a medal in Olympics. She won a bronze medal at Rio Olympics in the 58kg category.

ques: Which country is the birthplace of the “Olympic Games”?
ans_detail: Notes:The birthplace of the “Olympic Games” is Greece. The creation of modern Olympic Games was inspired by the ancient Olympic Games, held in Olympia, Greece from the 8th century BC to the 4th century AD. Baron Pierre de Coubertin founded the International Olympic Committee (IOC) in 1894, leading to the first modern Games in Athens in 1896.

ques: In which year, the first Youth Olympic Games was held?
ans_detail: Notes:In the year 2010, the first Youth Olympic Games was held. The Youth Olympic Games is an international multi-sport event organized by the International Olympic Committee. The games are held every four years in summer and winter events consistent with the current Olympic Games format. The first summer version was held in Singapore from 14 to 26 August 2010 while the first winter version was held in Innsbruck, Austria from 13 to 22 January 2012.

ques: Who is the first recipient of the “most valuable player (MVP)” award of the Asian Games?
ans_detail: Notes:Koji Ito is the first recipient of the “most valuable player (MVP)” award of the Asian Games. The most valuable player (MVP) award was introduced since the 1998 Asian Games in Bangkok, Thailand.

ques: Which among the following was the first state in India in the pre-independence times, when the compulsory primary education was launched for the first time?
ans_detail: Notes:The first law on compulsory education was introduced by the State of Baroda in 1906.  This law provided for compulsory education for boys and girls in the age groups of 7–12 years and 7–10 years respectively

ques: Who among the following established the Ved Samaj in Madras in 1864?
ans_detail: Notes:Reform in Southern India Brahmo Samaj under the leadership of Keshabchandra Sen made its appearance in 1864 in Madras with the name Ved Samaj.

ques: The resolution of Swadeshi was adopted in which session of Congress?
options: ["Madras session of 1903","Bombay session of 1904","Benaras session of 1905","Calcutta session of 1906"]
ans_detail: Notes:The resolution of Swadeshi was adopted in 1906 Calcutta session of the Indian National Congress. This session was headed by Dada Bhai Naoroji. Prior to this, in Banaras 1905 session, a resolution of boycott of British goods was put forward. However, it was 1906 session at Calcutta in which four resolutions on self-government, boycott movement, Swadeshi and national education were passed by the Congress. Dadabhai Naoroji said in his presidential speech: “we do not ask for favours we want only justice. Instead of going into any further divisions or details of our rights as British citizens the whole matter can be comprised in one word – self-government or Swaraj like that of the United Kingdom or colonies.”

ques: By which of the following for the first time, British government recognized the “Right of Dominion” for India?
ans_detail: Notes:The Cripps mission came to India in March 1942. The mission was headed by a Sir Stafford Cripps. The mission was sent to negotiate an agreement with the nationalist Congress leaders. The mission asked India to keep loyalty to the British war effort and promised of elections and full self-government or Dominion status after the cessation of the World War II.

ques: Who among the following was the first Indian to get selected in ICS (Indian Civil Services)?
options: ["Ras Bihari Bose","Satyendra Nath Tagore","Devendranath Tagore","Surendranath Banerjee"]
ans_detail: Notes:Satyendranath Tagore was selected for the Indian Civil Service in June, 1863. He completed his probationary training and returned to India in November 1864. He was posted as Judge, Satara after this examination.

ques: William Digby is known to write on which of the aspects of India ?
options: ["Indian education","Indian society","Famines in India","Poverty in India"]
ans_detail: Notes:Digby was based in India during British raj and witnessed to several famines that devastated India, including a disastrous famine in Madras in the mid-1870s. He blamed British policies for fueling and exacerbating the famines, agitating for humanitarian aid from Europe to India

ques: During tenure of which of the following all high Indian officials were dismissed and all posts worth more than £500 a year were reserved for Europeans?
ans_detail: Notes:He is known for beginning of Indian Civil Service and Europeanization of Higher postings

ques: In which year, the custom duties were completely waived for the trade for East India Company?
ans_detail: Notes:Mughal Emperor Farrukhsiyar granted a forman to the East India Company, which is regarded as Magna Carta in the year 1717. As per the Farman the import and export duty of the company was exempted from the customs duty. Issuing of Dastak was permitted for transportation of goods. Levy of all duties were exempted in Surat for a payment of Rs. 10,000 annually.

ques: At which among the following places, Jayaprakash Narayan had convened the first All India Congress Socialists Conference in 1934?
ans_detail: Notes:Jayaprakash Narayan (The People’s Leader or Lok Nayak) was an independence activist, socialist and political leader of India. He organized a meeting in Patna on 17th May 1934. Bihar Congress Socialist Party was founded in that meeting.

ques: What was the immediate cause of the Revolt of 1857?
options: ["Heavy taxation on Indian products","Introduction of enfield guns","Annexation of Oudh","Demolition of traditional handicrafts that hit poor peasants and artisians"]
ans_detail: Notes:The immediate cause of the Revolt of 1857 was the introduction of Enfield rifles whose cartidges were said to have greased cover made of beef and pork sparked off the revolt.

ques: The Buran wind blows across:
ans_detail: Notes: The buran wind blows across eastern Asia, specifically Xinjiang, Siberia, and Kazakhstan. The buran takes two forms: in summer, it is a hot, dry wind, whipping up sandstorms; in winter, it is bitterly cold and often accompanied by blizzards.

ques: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the Planet Mars?
options: ["It has two permanent polar ice caps","After the Moon, it is the brightest object in our night sky","Liquid water cannot exist on the surface of Mars due to low atmospheric pressure","Mars is less dense than Earth"]
ans: After the Moon, it is the brightest object in our night sky
ans_detail: Notes:Second statement is incorrect because Venus is the second brightest object in our night sky after Moon.

ques: Systematic approach is one of the major approach to study geography
ans_detail:
Notes:Geography is studied majorly by using two approaches
1. Systematic approach
2. Regional approach
Systematic geography approach was introduced by German Geographer Alexander Von Humboldt where as regional geography approach was introduced by another German geographer Karl Ritter
•	Any phenomenon of geography in systematic approach is studied world over as a whole, and then the identification of typologies or spatial patterns is done.•	In the regional approach, the world is divided into regions at different hierarchical levels and then all the geographical phenomena in a particular region are studied

ques: Which of the following rocks are known as Primary rocks?
options: ["Igneous Rocks","Metamorphic Rocks","Sedimentary Rocks","None of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:All the rocks are derived from igneous rocks which are formed by the solidification of hot molten material called magma or lava. Therefore igneous rocks are also called as primary rocks or parent rocks.

ques: Who was the first to observe Saturn with a telescope?
ans_detail: Notes:Saturn has been known to us because it is easily visible to the naked eye. Galileo Galilei was the first to observe Saturn with a telescope in 1610.

ques: Which among the lines is a boundary between France & Germany ?
ans_detail: Notes:The Siegfried Line was a German defensive line built during the 1930s opposite the French Maginot Line. It is the boundary between France and Germany.

ques: What is the Modern name of a country which has Abyssinia as its old name?
ans_detail: Notes:Ethiopia is formerly known as Abyssinia. It was named Ethiopia around the 4th century by king Ezana as a new “christian” name for a kingdom he was converting.

ques: Which of the following country is known as Kalaallit Nunaat, meaning “Land of the people”?
ans_detail: Notes:Greenland is the world’s largest island. It located between the Arctic and Atlantic oceans, east of the Canadian Arctic Archipelago. is known as Kalaallit Nunaat, meaning “Land of the people”.

ques: While going towards the centre of the earth, the weight of a body shall ?
ans_detail: Notes:While going towards the centre of the earth, the weight of a body shall decrease. This is because the distance from the centre of the earth reduces.

ques: Mass of Sun is equal to how many moons of earth (approximately) ?
ans_detail: Notes:The mass of sun is equal to 270 lakh moons. About 1.3 million Earths could fit inside the sun. The mass of the sun is 1.989 x 1030 kilograms, about 333,000 times the mass of the Earth.

ques: In which year Reserve bank of India introduced Special Fund Facility for Security Settlement SFFSS?
ans_detail: Notes:In the year 2000, the Special Fund Facility for Security Settlement, which was introduced as an amendment to Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956. The main purpose behind introducing such a facility was regularization and smoothening of security-related transactions.

ans: A single tax that replaces State Taxes like surcharge, turnover tax, etc.

ques: Which of the following Price Indices of India is considered for measuring ‘Headline Inflation’?
In recent times, the term “Import Substitution” was making news
ans_detail: Notes:Import Substitution refers to a trade and economic policy based on the premise that a developing country should attempt to substitute products which it imports (mostly finished goods) with locally produced substitutes. This often times involves government subsidies, high tariff barriers and/or artificially maintained domestic currencies to protect local industries. Import substitution is also a policy strategy, e.g. as an attempt to utilize underused capacities, reduce regional unemployment or protect infant industries. This form of economic protectionism has helped some countries industrialize in the past, (such as South Korea and Taiwan) but these steps can be fraught with economic risks, most notably potential economic inefficiencies, uneconomical use of available resources, and ultimately leading to higher prices.During 60’s and 70’s import substitution strategy became popular in developing countries like such as Argentina, Brazil, and Mexico. Some nations still use it today. It extensively uses trade barriers to protect domestic industries from import competition and can lead to complete self sufficiency. For e.g. if fertilizer imports occur import substitution may call for establishment of a domestic fertilizer industry to produce replacement of fertilizer imports.Advantages: Risks of establishing home industry to replace imports are low, easier to protect domestic manufactures against foreign competitions; it provides jobs and reduces import expenditures.Disadvantages: Import substitution breeds corruption as the economy is more protected and within, for small nations, for indigenous development cost becomes very high of setting up own units, due to trade restrictions there are no incentives to increase efficiency as they are away from competition.

ques: The Human Capital Report is published by the:
options: ["World Economic Forum","International Committee of the Red Cross","World Bank","Human Rights Foundation"]
ans_detail: Notes: The Human Capital Report is published by the World Economic Forum. As per recent report, India has been ranked at 105th position globally.

ques: Which of the following is not a correct statement about Bitumen?
options: ["It’s a mixture of highly condensed polycyclic aromatic compounds","Its is soluble in Carbon Disulphide","SARA analysis is used to determine bitumen chemistry","All of above are correct statements"]
ans: All of above are correct statements
ans_detail: Notes: Bitumen is a mixture of organic liquids that are highly viscous, black, sticky, soluble in carbon disulfide and composed of highly condensed polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.

ques: Which among the following element is an essential constituent of acids?
ans_detail: Notes:Acids are molecules that are able to donate proton or H+ thus, hydrogen is essential for acids. However, there are exception to this such as Bronsted acids. A Bronsted acid is an acid which can accept an electron pair, but does not have a proton (H+) to donate. Examples of such acids are Aluminum Chloride (AlCl3), Boron Trifuoride (BF3).

ques: Kazimierz Funk or Casimir Funk, was a Polish biochemist, generally credited with the first formulation of the concept of which of the following ?
ans_detail: Notes:Kazimierz Funk (1884 – 1967) was a Polish biochemist, and one of the first to formulate the concept of Vitamins.

ques: With reference to the nuclear fuels, how the Fissile material is different from the Fertile material? 1
options: ["Only 1 is correct","Only 2 is correct","Both 1 & 2 are correct","Neither 1 nor 2 is correct"]
ans_detail: Notes:The fissile material is the one which undergoes nuclear fission (splitting of atom) upon bombardment by slow/fast neutrons. The fissile materials used are Uranium 235, Plutonium239 and Uranium233. (India is the only country in the world to use U 233 fuel, used in Purnima & Kamini Reactors. Fertile material is the one which by itself is not fissionable but will capture the neutron and will get converted to a fissile material. Examples are Uranium 238 becoming Plutonium 239. Thorium 232 becoming Uranium 233 etc.

ques: Consider the following statements about soaps and detergents:While soaps are sodium salts of fatty acids, detergents are sodium salts of sulphonic acids
ans_detail: Notes:Second statement is incorrect because addition of soaps or detergents decreases the surface tension of water.

ques: Consider the following pairs:Water glass – Sodium silicateMohr’s salt – Ferrous ammonium sulphateCaustic soda – Sodium hydroxide    Which of the above is/are correct?
ans_detail: Notes:All given pairs are correctly matched

ques: Consider the following compounds:WaterCarbon dioxideCarbon monoxide  Which of the above is/are organic compound/compounds?
ans_detail: Notes:Organic compounds not only have carbon bonds but also contain hydrocarbons or carbon bonded to hydrogen. A few types of carbon-containing compounds, such as carbides, carbonates, simple oxides of carbon (such as CO and CO2), and cyanides are considered inorganic. Water does not contain any carbon atom in its molecule, H2O. So water is only an inorganic compound.

ques: Which of the following element is NOT an alkaline earth metal?
ans_detail: Notes:The elements of Group 2 include beryllium, magnesium, calcium, strontium, barium and radium. These elements with the exception of beryllium are commonly known as the alkaline earth metals.

ques: How is Aqua regia formed?
options: ["by mixing 2 parts of concentrated HCl and one part of concentrated HNO<sub>3</sub>","by mixing 3 parts of concentrated HCl and one part of concentrated HNO<sub>3</sub>","by mixing 1 part of concentrated HCl and three parts of concentrated HNO<sub>3</sub>","None of the above"]
ans: by mixing 3 parts of concentrated HCl and one part of concentrated HNO3
ans_detail: Notes:When three parts of concentrated HCl and one part of concentrated HNO3 are mixed, aqua regia is formed which is used for dissolving noble metals, e.g., gold, platinum.

ques: Choose the incorrect ‘Alloy – constituent metal’ pair:
ans_detail: Notes:Lockalloy is an alloy that contains 62% beryllium and 38% aluminum. All other pairs are correctly matched.

ques: Rajgir Mahotsav is celebrated in __:
ans_detail: Notes:Rajgir, the ancient capital of the Magadhan empire in Bihar is held sacred by both Buddhists and Jains for its association with the Buddha and Mahavir. Department of Tourism, Bihar holds a colourful festival of dance and music, Rajgir Mahotsav or Dance Festival every year in Rajgir.

ques: Which among the following Indian classical dance form was developed by Siddhendra Yogi from Bhamakalapam dance drama ?
ans_detail: Notes:Siddhendra Yogi from Bhamakalapam dance drama developed the classical dance of Kuchpudi. The play Bhamakalpam deals with the Hindu God, Lord Krishna and his companions Satyabhama and Rukmini.

ques: Bohag Bihu is a festival in North East India, mainly in the state of ____?
ans_detail:
Notes:Bihu is the name of the biggest festival of the Assam. The people in Assam celebrate three Bihus as follows:
Bohag Bihu: In mid-April, this is the largest festival and also the state festival of Assam. Related to spring season. It is also known as Rongali Bihu. This festival celebrates the onset of the Assamese New Year and the coming of Spring. It continues for seven days which is called Haat Bihu ( Saat (seven) for Hindi). These are called Chot Bihu, Goru Bihu, Manuh Bihu, Kutum Bihu, Senehi Bihu, Mela Bihu and Chera Bihu

ques: Which among the following Sikh Guru declared that Guru Granth Sahib will be the holy scripture of Sikkhism and will be the permanent Guru of Sikhs?
options: ["Guru Govind Singh","Guru Arjun Dev","Guru Teg Bahadur","None of them"]
ans_detail: Notes:Guru Govind singh declared that Guru Granth Sahib will be the holy scripture of Sikkhism and will be the permanent Guru of Sikhs.

ques: How many astika schools of Hindu philosophy did exist in ancient times, recognizing the authority of the Vedas?
ans_detail: Notes:There were  six astika(orthodox) schools of Hindu philosophy, recognizing  the authority of the Vedas. These include six systems namely, Sankhya, Yoga, Nyaya, Vaisheshika, Mimamsa and Vedanta.

ques: How many tirthankaras are the part of Jain Dharma tradition?
ans_detail: Notes:Jains trace their spiritual ideas to twenty-four leaders or tirthankaras, with the first being Rishabhanatha. The twenty-third tirthankara was  Parshvanatha in 900 BCE, and the twenty-fourth tirthankara  Mahaviralived around 500 BCE.

ques: Kolattam and Chholiya are the dance forms of which of the two States?
options: ["Kerala and Karnataka","Andhra Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh","Tamil Nadu and Madhya Pradesh","Karnataka and Bihar"]
ans_detail: Notes:Kolattam is an art form of Andhra Pradesh played with sticks. It is a rural dance, a combination of rhythmic movements, songs and music usually performed during village festivals. Chholiya is a dance form practised in the Kumaon region of Uttarakhand. It is basically a sword dance accompanying a marriage procession but now it is performed on many occasions.

ques: To which of the following states does the folk song ‘Bhawaiya’ belong?
ans_detail: Notes:Bhawaiya is a musical form or a popular folk music in Northern Bangladesh, especially Rangpur District and in Cooch Bihar, Jalpaiguri, part of Darjeeling and North Dinajpur district of West Bengal and Dhubri and Goalpara of Assam in India.This folk song is sung traditionally both solo and by chorus.

ques: The famous dancer T
ans_detail: Notes:Tanjore Balasaraswati also known as Balasaraswati was a celebrated Indian dancer, and her rendering of Bharatanatyam, a classical dance style. She was awarded the Padma Bhushan in 1957 and the Padma Vibhushan in 1977, the third and the second highest civilian honours given by the Government of India. In 1981 she was awarded the Sangeetha Kalasikhamani award of The Indian Fine Arts Society, Chennai.

ques: In which of the following states is the festival of Hareli celebrated?
ans_detail: Notes:The Hareli festival is one of the famous celebrations of Chhattisgarh. It is an old traditional festival of Chhattisgarh that marks the beginning of Shravan month, the holy month for Hindus. Hareli festival is actually a festival of harvest focusing on the monsoon of a year. The Goddess ‘Kutki Dai’ is the presiding deity worshiped during this festival for good crops.

ques: Which among the following oxides cause the Acid rain ?
options: ["Carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide","Nitrous oxide and sulphur dioxide","Carbon dioxide and nitrous oxide","Sulphur dioxide and carbon monoxide"]

ques: How many pairs of ribs are there in a human body?
ans_detail: Notes:There are total 24 ribs (12 pairs), out of which 14 (7 pairs) are true ribs

ques: Which among the following has a fibrous root?
ans_detail: Notes:A fibrous root system is universal in monocotyledonous plants and ferns. It is the opposite of a taproot system and usually formed by thin, moderately branching roots growing from the stem. Fibrous root system is present in grass.

ques: The Red color of Red wine is mainly because of _____?
ans_detail: Notes:The Red color of Red wine is mainly because of pigments such as anthocyanin. Anthocyanin is present in many fruits like plums, blueberries, and cherries.

ques: Which among the following factors are essential for ‘blood coagulation’?Vitamin KCalcium ions (Ca++)Christmas factorSelect the correct option from the codes given below:
ans_detail: Notes:Factor IX (or Christmas factor) is one of the serine proteases of the coagulation system. Deficiency of this protein causes hemophilia B.

ques: The functions of the humps in camel is to __: 1
ans_detail: Notes:Camels do not store water in their humps as is commonly believed. The humps are actually a reservoir of fatty tissue. Concentrating body fat in their humps minimizes heat-trapping insulation throughout the rest of their body, which may be an adaptation to living in hot climates. When this tissue is metabolized, it acts as a source of energy, and yields more than 1 g of water for each 1 g of fat converted through reaction with oxygen from air. This process of fat metabolization generates a net loss of water through respiration for the oxygen required to convert the fat.

ques: Which of the following is / are correct statements about the cosmic rays?They are made of charged particlesThey are received on earth mainly from SunThey cause Ozone DepletionSelect the correct option from the codes given below:
ans_detail: Notes:Cosmic Rays are made up of positively and negatively charged particles. Cosmic rays may broadly be divided into two categories: primary and secondary. The cosmic rays that originate from astrophysical sources are primary cosmic rays; these primary cosmic rays interact with interstellar matter creating secondary cosmic rays. Sun is not the major source but is a minor source. The Sun also emits low energy cosmic rays associated with solar flares. The third statement is correct. The chain of reactions in the upper atmosphere due to the cosmic rays causes depletion of the ozone but this depletion is small in comparison to the depletion caused by CFCs.

ques: What is the difference between GSLV and PSLV? 1
ans_detail: Notes:While PSLV is a four stage vehicle, GSLV is three stage vehicle. You may read this if you want.

ques: What is the average power consumption of a heartbeat in an adult?
ans_detail: Notes:Average power consumption by an adult in some of the common processes/activities: 1. Heartbeat – 1.2 watt 2. Sleeping – 75 watt 3. Slow walking – 200 watt 4. Bicycling – 500 watt

ques: What is the relation between Time period(T) and angular frequency(ω) of a wave?
ans_detail: Notes:Period T of oscillation of a wave is defined as the time any element of the medium takes to move through one complete oscillation. It is related to the angular frequency ω through the relation T = 2π/ω.

ques: Which article of the Indian Constitution provides the right to constitutional remedies, that allows Indian citizens to stand up for their rights against anybody – even the government of India?
ans_detail: Notes:Article 32 provides the right to Constitutional remedies which means that a person has right to move to Supreme Court (and high courts also) for getting his fundamental rights protected. While Supreme Court has power to issue writs under article 32, High Courts have been given same powers under article 226

ques: The first session of constituent assembly took place on which of the following dates?
ans_detail:
Notes:The first meeting of the Constituent Assembly of India took place in Constitutional Hall, New Delhi, on 9th December 1946. Dr. Sachchidananda Sinha was the first president of the Constituent Assembly. In the first meeting, the assembly adopted an ‘Objective Resolution’ which later became the preamble of the constitution. It appointed various committees. The report of the committees formed the basis on which the first draft of the constitution was prepared.  It reassembled on 14 August 1947 as Constituent Assembly for independent India.
After partition, Dr. Rajendra Prasad became the president of Constituent Assembly of Independent India.  Professor Harendra Coomar Mookerjee was Vice President of the Constituent Assembly. While Dr. Rajendra Prasad later became President of India, Prof. HC Mookerjee became first Governor of West Bengal.

ques: Which article of the Indian Constitution provides for a Governor?
ans_detail: Notes:Article 153 of the Constitution of India requires a governor to be appointed for every state in India.

ques: Which among the following fundamental rights has been to subject to maximum litigation after inauguration of the Constitution of India?
options: ["Right to Freedom","Right to Constitutional remedies","Right to Property","Right against exploitation"]

ques: Who among the following was the main rival candidate against India’s first President Dr
ans_detail: Notes:Dr. Rajendra Prasad contested and won Presidential elections for two times viz. 1952 and 1957. In 1952 Presidential elections, he defeated his nearest rival K. T.Shah while in 1957 elections, he defeated his nearest rival Chowdhry Hari Ram.

ques: Which among the following term correctly represents the Zonal Councils?
options: ["Advisory Bodies","Actually Working Bodies","Law Making authorities","Administrative Bodies"]
ans_detail: Notes:Zonal Councils are statutory and advisory bodies.

ques: Which of the following Constitution Amendment Act grants citizens a fundamental right to form cooperative societies?
ans_detail: Notes:Constitution (97th) Amendment Act, 2011 gave a constitutional status and protection to co-operative societies. This amendment made the following three changes in the constitution:It made the right to form co-operative societies a fundamental right (Article 19)It included a new Directive Principle of State Policy on the promotion of co-operative societies (Article 43-B).It added a new Part IX-B in the constitution which is entitled as “The Co-operative societies” (Articles 243-ZH to 243-ZT).

ques: Many key features of the constitution such as the federal structure of government, provincial autonomy, a bicameral central legislature and the principle of separation of powers, are directly taken from:
options: ["Nehru Report of 1928","Government of India Act, 1919","Government of India Act, 1935","Indian Independence Act, 1947"]
ans_detail: Notes:The most important source of Constitution of India is the Government of India Act 1935 which at time of enactment had 321 sections and 10 schedules. It is source of several important features such as Federal Scheme (also from constitution of Canada), Office of Governor, Judiciary, Public Service Commission, Emergency Provisions and Administrative Details.

ques: Who among the following is appointed as the Returning Officer in President Elections?
options: ["Election Commissioner","Lok Sabha Secretary General","Lok Sabha speaker","A person nominated by Election Commission"]
ans_detail: Notes:By convention, the Secretary General, Lok Sabha and the Secretary General, Rajya Sabha are appointed as the Returning Officers by rotation. For the 2007 Presidential Election, the Secretary General, Lok Sabha was appointed as Returning Officer. Therefore, for the 2012 Presidential Election, the Secretary General, Rajya Sabha has been appointed as the Returning Officer. Two other senior officers of Rajya Sabha Secretariat and the Secretaries and one more senior officer of Legislative Assemblies of all States including NCT of Delhi and Union Territory of Puducherry have also been appointed as the Assistant Returning Officers.

ques: Which act of British India was one of the main sources of Constitution of India?
options: ["Government of India Act, 1919","Indian Councils Act, 1909","Government of India Act, 1935","Indian Independence Act, 1947"]
ans_detail: Notes: The Government of India Act, 1935 was an important source for the Constitution of India. Many provisions of Indian Constitution like federal government, dyarchy at the center, distribution of power between center and states and establishment of a federal court have been taken from it.

ques: Plasmodium falciparum, which causes malaria in humans is kept in which among the following groups?
ans_detail: Notes:Plasmodium, a tiny protozoan is responsible for malarial disease. Different species of Plasmodium (P. vivax, P. malaria and P. falciparum) are responsible for different types of malaria. Of these, malignant malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum is the most serious one and can even be fatal.

ques: Herpetology is the branch of science that deals with the study of__?
ans_detail: Notes:Herpetology is the branch of zoology which deals with the study of amphibians such as frogs, toads, salamanders, newts and the gymnophiona; and reptiles such as snakes, lizards, amphisbaenids, turtles, terrapins, tortoises, crocodilians and the tuataras.

ques: In which of the following diseases copper accumulates in tissues ?
ans_detail: Notes:Wilson’s disease is a genetic disorder in which excess copper builds up in the body. Symptoms are typically related to the brain and liver. Some of the symptoms are vomiting, weakness, fluid build up in the abdomen, swelling of the legs, etc.

ques: Which among the following correctly refers to Ischemia?
options: ["restriction in blood supply due to factors in the blood vessels","Abrupt fall in the blood Pressure","necrosis in a blood vessel due to a local lack of oxygen","condition of severely deficient supply of oxygen to the body"]
ans: restriction in blood supply due to factors in the blood vessels
ans_detail: Notes:Restriction in blood supply due to factors in the blood vessels refers to Ischemia. Ischemia can have causes that aren’t due to underlying disease some of which include extreme exercise, cold exposure or tourniquet.

ques: Which among the following vitamins is involved in the breakdown of energy molecules such as glucose?
ans_detail: Notes:Vitamin B is involved in the breakdown of energy molecules such as glucose. Vitamin B are a class of water-soluble vitamins which play an important role in cell metabolism.

ques: Biologists have been able to demonstrate the hearing and sound sensory mechanism through the acoustico-lateralis system in which of the following vertebrates ?
ans_detail: Notes:Biologists have been able to demonstrate the hearing and sound sensory mechanism through the acoustico-lateralis system in fishes.

ques: The Bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) is commonly known as _______?
options: ["Foot & Mouth Disease","Mad Cow Disease","Fog fever","Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease"]
ans_detail: Notes:The Bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) is commonly known as Mad Cow Disease. It is a brain disorder in an adult cattle that may be spread to humans through diseased meat.

ques: Who gave theory of photosynthesis?
ans_detail: Notes:Jan Ingenhausen is a Dutch-born British physician and scientist, best known for his discovery of the process of photosynthesis, by which green plants absorb carbon dioxide and release oxygen in sunlight.

ques: Which of the following give maximum energy after breaking down?
ans_detail: Notes:Fat gives maximum energy after breaking down, fat is composed of essential carbon and hydrogen atoms releasing 9.1 calories per gram of energy.

ques: What is Rancidity?
options: ["Deterioration of Fat","Deterioration of Glucose","Deterioration of Protein","Deterioration of Vitamins"]
ans_detail: Notes:The process of oxidation of oily and Fatty food, which changes its taste and smell is known as Rancidity. Rancidity generally occurs in Fat.

ques: The alpha radiation is not used in radiotherapy because:
options: ["It is an ionizing radiation","It is unable to penetrate human skin","It is toxic to human tissues","It is not cost effective"]
ans: It is unable to penetrate human skin
ans_detail: Notes:The alpha particles have very large atomic volume and hence do not penetrate human skin.

ques: If we look at the floating piece of iceberg on the sea, approximately what fraction of it is visible above the seawater level?
ans_detail: Notes:Approximately 1/8 (12.5 %) of the ice is visible above water and 7/8 (87.5 %) of the ice is submerged below the surface. This is because ice and snow are less dense than water. Here we must note that if the iceberg is made up of only compact ice, its visible part may be even 1/10th part because the compact part is relatively denser. But the top of the iceberg is usually made up of snow which is not that much compact and that is why the correct answer of this question is 1/8th.

ques: The pulling sensation when we stand near a running train can be explained on the basis of ___:
options: ["Archimedes Principle","Bernoulli’s law","Avogadro’s Hypothesis","Newton’s Third Law of motion"]
ans_detail: Notes:It is just a feeling, we are actually being pushed towards the moving train by the atmosphere surrounding us. The reason can be explained with the help of “Bernoulli’s law”. When a train is stationary, the pressure at points in surrounding area would be uniform and at atmospheric pressure. As the train starts and gains momentum, the increasing velocity of the train depletes the pressure at the points in the area at close proximity to the train. Now the pressure at these points is less than atmospheric pressure. The points at an area farther away from the train are at same atmospheric pressure as before. It has to be noted that, the velocity of the train affects pressure of the areas closer to the train and not of those a little far away. Naturally, air from the points at atmospheric pressure (relatively high) would rush towards the low pressure area (the area immediately surrounding the train) or towards the train. Thus a person standing near a moving train will actually be pushed towards the train by the gush of wind destined to the low pressure area.

ans_detail: Notes:Refraction is a phenomenon of light, sound wave, water wave by which the direction of a wave changed while passing from one medium to another. Some of the examples of refraction are Mirage, appearing of raised coin in a trough filled with water, bent pencil in glass of water, rainbow, dispersion of light sunset, etc.

ques: With reference to Mirage, which among the following statements is / are correct?  1
ans_detail: Notes:As the cold air is denser than warm air, so it has a greater refractive index. When light rays pass from hotter to cooler layers of air, they tend to move downward. Superior mirages mainly witnessed in polar regions. A mirage is a illusion of water which is caused by the refraction of light.

ques: Total Internal Reflection would happen only if __:A ray travels from denser to rarer mediumA ray travels from rarer to denser mediumThe angle of incidence in denser medium is greater than the critical angleThe angle of incidence in rarer medium is greater than the critical angleSelect the correct option from the codes given below:
ans_detail: Notes:For a ray of light to suffer total internal reflection, the necessary conditions are as follows:The ray must travel from a denser to a rarer medium.The angle of incidence in denser medium should be greater than the critical angle.

ques: A person runs up two flights of stairs instead of walking up
options: ["He does more work when he runs in comparison to when he walks","His power output is greater when he runs in comparison to when he walks","His gravitational force is greater when he runs in comparison to when he walks","He has more inertia when he runs in comparison to when he walks"]
ans: His power output is greater when he runs in comparison to when he walks
ans_detail: Notes:Energy required during running up two flights of stairs is much higher than the time of walking up. It needs more energy and that is why the person feels more tired.

ques: Consider the following statements with respect to LIGO project, which is sometimes seen in news: LIGO project helps to understand Earth’s interior by studying seismic waves
ans_detail: Notes:First statement is incorrect because LIGO project is related to study of gravitational waves in space. Second statement is correct. Also, we note that LIGO-India, or INDIGO, is a planned collaborative project between the LIGO Laboratory and the Indian Initiative in Gravitational-wave Observations (IndIGO) to create a world-class gravitational-wave detector in India.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Sarnath, is related to which among the following events in the life of Buddha?
ans_detail: Notes:The deer park in Sarnath is where Gautama Buddha first taught the Dharma, and where the Buddhist Sangha came into existence through the enlightenment of Kondanna. It was also the site of the Buddha’s Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta, which was his first teaching after attaining enlightenment, in which he taught the four noble truths and the teachings associated with it.So either A or D can be marked as the correct answer.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Kushinara or Kushinagar, where Lord Buddha attained parinirvana was located in which among the following provinces of ancient India?
ans_detail:
Notes:The Buddha belonged to a small gana known as the Sakya gana, and was a kshatriya. When he was a young man, he left the comforts of his home in search of knowledge. He wandered for several years, meeting and holding discussions with other thinkers. He finally decided to find his own path to realisation, and meditated for days on end under a peepal tree at Bodh Gaya in Bihar, where he attained enlightenment. After that, he was known as the Buddha or the Wise One. He then went to Sarnath, near Varanasi, where he taught for the first time.
Buddha attained Nirvana at Kusinara a village some 180km from Varanasi and it was in the state of Mallas.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which among the following is not Correctly matched?
options: ["Milinda Panho – Buddhism","Tatwarthadhigam – Vaishnavism","Mahapurana – Jainism","All are correct"]
ans_detail: Notes:Tatwarthadhigam is of Jainism composed by Uma Swami

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which among the following scripts of modern India have descended from the Sarda Script?GurmukhiDogriSindhiSelect the correct option from the codes given below:
ans_detail: Notes:Sarada is a script of the Brahmic family of scripts, developed around the 8th century. It was used for writing Sanskrit and Kashmiri. The Gurmukhi script was developed from Sarada by Guru Angad. Originally more widespread, its use became later restricted to Kashmir, and it is now rarely used except by the Kashmiri Pandit community for ceremonial purposes. There are several variants of Sarada Scripts such as Takkari or Tankari which is the parent of the Dogri script, Kului script (Kullu in Himachal Pradesh), Chameali Script (in Chamba Himachal Pradesh), Sindhi, Bania of Punjab etc.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following was basis of initial differentiation between the Vedic and non-Vedic people?
ans_detail: Notes:The basis of initial differentiation between the Vedic and non-Vedic people was Varna or colour. The Vedic people were fair and spoke a different language whereas the non-Vedic indigenous people were dark in complexion.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following was the first state to use elephants on a large scale against its neighbours?
ans_detail: Notes:Magadha was the first empire to use elephants on a large scale against its neighbours. Elephants could be effectively used in storming fortresses. They could be used for  marching over areas lacking roads or other means of communication.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: According to Kautilya which of the following was referred to as the Dharmapravakta?
ans_detail: Notes:According to Chanakya also known as Kautilya, the king was referred to as the Dharmapravakta in Mauryan administration. He was the promulgator of social orders as he issued Rajasasana which are royal rescripts and maintained porana pakiti, i.e., ancient rules and customs.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following forms of arts flourished in the post-Mauryan period?1) Ivory work2) Glass Manufacture3) Bead cuttingSelect the correct option from the codes given below:
ans_detail: Notes:In the post-Mauryan period art and crafts flourished on a large scale. There was a significant progress made in cloth-making and silk-weaving craft. Some of the other arts that flourished during this period were Ivory work,  Glass Manufacture & Bead cutting.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: During which of the following period cotton was exported to different countries?
ans_detail: Notes:Under the Satavahanas, agriculture was prominent. They produced and cultivated cotton. As mentioned in different foreign accounts, Andhra was famous for its cotton products also. Cotton was also exported from India to different countries.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following text mentions that the water touched by an untouchable is seen as unfit for consumption by higher caste?
ans_detail: Notes:According to the famous text Acharakkovai, if the water is touched by an untouchable also called as Pulaiya, it is seen as unfit for consumption by higher caste people. It is also mentioned that even glancing at a pulaiya polluted the upper caste people.

ques: Which of the following statements is/ are correct?Konyak languages are spoken in NagalandThe largest river island in the world is in AssamArunachal Pradesh has the least density of population in IndiaThe largest desert in the world is situated in IndiaChoose the correct option from the codes given below:
ans_detail: Notes:The largest desert in the world is situated in northern Africa (The Sahara Desert).

ques: Arrange the following cities of India from west to east1
ans_detail: Notes:Correct order from west to east- Jodhpur (Rajasthan), Bhopal (Madhya Pradesh), Bilaspur (Chattisgarh), Ranchi (Jharkhand).

ques: What is the main reason for the average temperature of the Earth remains fairly steady as compared to that of the moon?
ans_detail: Notes:The average temperature of the earth remains fairly steady as compared to that of the moon mainly because of the earth’s atmosphere. The atmosphere of earth is capable of absorbing ultraviolet solar radiation, which causes warming of the surface through heat retention (greenhouse effect) and reducing temperature extremes between day and night. The atmospheric layer is not present in the Moon.

ques: Which of the following is the approximate length of the Himalayan Range?
ans_detail: Notes:The Himalayan ranges are approximately 2400 km in length with an average width of about 320 to 400 km which is situated in the northern boundary of India. It is the highest mountain range found in the world.

ques: Which among the following pairs are correct?1
ans_detail: Notes:Main Control Thrust (MCT) is located between the Greater Himalayas and Lesser Himalayas. Main Boundary Thrust is located between the Lesser Himalayas and Shiwalik Himalayas. Himalayan Frontal Fault is located between Shiwalik Himalayas and Northern Plain.

ques: The vertical rock face known as Hillary step is located in which of the following mountain peak?
ans_detail: Notes:Hillary step is located in the Mt. Everest. It is named after Sir Edmund Hillary (The first man to climb the mountain).

ques: Which of the following matches of states and their highest peaks are correct?1

ques: Which among the following condition of the soil in the cold desert region of India are correct?1
ans_detail: Notes:In the cold desert region, the soil is highly acidic (pH 4.5-6.5) in nature. It has very low organic matter content. The water retention capability of soil is very low and the texture of the soil varies from loamy to sandy.

ques: Coco island is located in which side of Andaman island?

ques: Lakshadweep group of islands are separated from the Maldives by which of the following?

ques: Who among the following founded the principality of Ghazani in AD 962?

ques: Which among the following was NOT a landmark of Alauddin Khilji’s Reign?

ans: Creation of Agricultural department called Diwan-i-kohi
