ques: During whose reign Changez Khan invaded India?
ans_detail: Notes:Chengez khan invaded India during the reign of Iltumish. He was the founder and first Great Khan of the Mongol Empire. The Mongol Empire launched several invasions into the Indian subcontinent from 1221 to 1327. They were able to conquer the area around Indus River and crossed to invade Punjab. Iltutmish was the ruler of the Delhi Sultanate during these invasions.

ques: With reference to the “Chisti Order”, which among the following statements is / are correct?Chishti Order originated in a place which is currently located in modern AfghanistanChishti Order was founded by Moinuddin ChishtiQutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki was a saint of Chisti orderSelect the correct option from the codes given below:
options: ["1, 2 & 3 are correct","Only 1 & 2 are correct","Only 2 & 3 are correct","Only 1 & 3 are correct"]
ans_detail: Notes:The Chishti Order is a Sufi order which arose from Chisht, a small town near Herat, in western Afghanistan. It was founded by Abu Ishaq Shami in about 930 CE (Christian Era). Before returning to western Asia he trained and deputed the son of local emir, Abu Ahmad Abdal, under whose leadership the Chishtiyya flourished as a regional mystical order. Moinuddin Chishti is credited with laying its foundations in India. Other famous saints of the Chishti Order are Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki, Fariduddin Ganjshakar, Nizamuddin Auliya and Alauddin Ali Ahmed Sabir Kalyari.

ques: Who among the following Sikh Guru initiated ‘The Khalsa’?
options: ["Guru Gobind Singh","Guru Tegh Bahadur","Guru Nanak Dev","Guru Angad Dev"]
ans_detail: Notes:The Khalsa tradition was initiated in 1699 by the last living Guru of Sikhism, Guru Gobind Singh. Guru Gobind Singh created and initiated the Khalsa as a warrior with a duty to protect the innocent from any form of religious persecution. The Khalsa redefined the Sikh tradition from the start.

ques: Who among the following introduced the Mansabdari system?
ans_detail: Notes:The Mansabdari system was the administrative system of the Mughal Empire introduced by Akbar. The word mansab is of Arabic origin meaning rank or position. The system, hence, determined the rank of a government official.

ques: Which Mughal King’s coin depicted Swastika?
ans_detail: Notes:Like his ideology, coins of Akbar also reflect secularism. The Hindu symbol of Swastika appears on many of his coins along with the “Kalima” (Islamic affirmation of faith). He also issued gold half mohurs with depictions of Rama and Sita on them. Some silver coins also had the words “Rama” and “Gobind” on them.

ques: Tabaqat-i-Akbari was written by which of the following authors?
options: ["Mir Muhammad Masum","Muhammad Bihamad Khani","Yahya ibn Ahmad Sihrindi","Nizamuddin Ahmad"]
ans_detail: Notes:Khwaja Nizam-ud-Din Ahmad Bakshi was a Muslim historian of late medieval India. He was the son of Muhammad Muqim-i-Harawi. Nizamuddin Ahmad wrote the book Tabaqat-i-Akbari which is a general history of the Muslim rule in India coming down to the year of its composition.

ques: Consider the following: Botanical Survey of India Zoological Survey of IndiaArcheological Survey of India Anthropological Survey of IndiaWhich among the following represents the correct chronological arrangement of their establishments ?
ans_detail:
Notes:Botanical Survey of India 1887,
Zoological Survey of India 1916,
ASI 1784 as Asiatic Society of Bengal ,
Anthropological Survey of India 1945

ques: After failure of which among the following movements, the Swaraj Party was formed?
options: ["Quit India Movement","Non-cooperation Movement","Civil disobedience Movement","Swadeshi Movement"]
ans_detail: Notes:The Swaraj Party was founded by Chittaranjan Das and Motilal Nehru as the Congress-Khilafat Swaraj Party on 1st January 1923 after the Gaya annual conference in December 1922 of the INC. The formation of the Swaraj Party came after the failure of non-cooperation movement and events like the Government of India act 1919 and the elections of 1923.

ques: After the Hindustan Republican Association was renamed as Hindustan Socialist Republic Association, a central committee was formed
ans_detail: Notes:After the Hindustan Republican Association was renamed as Hindustan Socialist Republic Association in the year 1928, a central committee was formed. P.N. Ghosh was from Bihar in this central Committee.

ques: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct regarding the Quit India Movement?It was a leaderless movement, with the reigns of the movement in the hands of the masses
ans_detail: Notes:The Quit India Movement was a civil disobedience movement launched in India in August 1942 in response to Mohandas Gandhi’s call for immediate independence. The All-India Congress Committee proclaimed a mass protest demanding what Gandhi called “an orderly British withdrawal” from India. The call for determined, but passive resistance appears in his call to Do or Die, issued on 8 August at the Gowalia Tank Maidan in Bombay.Almost the entire Indian National Congress leadership, and not just at the national level, was imprisoned without trial within hours after Gandhi’s speech; most spent the rest of the war in prison. It was a leaderless movement, with the reigns of the movement in the hands of the masses. The British refused to grant immediate independence, saying it could happen only after the war ended. Sporadic small-scale violence took place around the country but the British arrested tens of thousands of leaders, keeping them imprisoned until 1945, and suppressed civil rights, freedom of speech and freedom of the press. (Hence Statement 1. and 2. are correct)In terms of immediate objectives Quit India failed because of heavy-handed suppression, weak coordination and the lack of a clear-cut programme of action. However, the British government realized that India was ungovernable in the long run, and the question for postwar became how to exit gracefully while protecting Britain’s allies, the Muslims and the princes.(Hence Statement 3. is also correct)

ques: Who was the Governor General of India when the Charter Act of 1833 was passed?
options: ["Lord Wellesley","Lord Hastings","Lord Minto I","Lord William Bentinck"]
ans_detail: Notes:The Charter Act of 1833 was passed during the time of Lord William Bentinck. Excerpts of the act –a) Monopoly of the British East India company was abolished.b) It redesignated the Governor-General of Bengal as the Governor-General of India.c) Lord William Bentinck became the first Governor-General of India.d) The bishops of Bombay, Madras, and Calcutta were to be appointed for the benefit of the Christians in India

ques: Which of the following was/were the reforms of Sir John Lawrence (Viceroy of India)?
options: ["Telegraphy System opened between India and Europe","Advocated State-managed railways","Created the Indian Forest Department","All of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:In the tenure of Viceroy of India, Sir John Lawrence (1864–69), the following reforms took place: Telegraphy System opened between India and Europe, High Courts were established at Calcutta, Bombay and Madras in 1865, expanded canal works and railways; Bhutan War (1865), Advocated State-managed railways, created the Indian Forest Department and recognised the native Judicial service.

ques: During the viceroyalty of whom Rowlatt act (1919) was passed?
ans_detail: Notes:During the viceroyalty of Lord Chelmsford, the Rowlatt act (1919) was passed. As per this act, the British government was empowered to detain anyone in the lockup without any trial. It was repealed by Viceroy Lord Reading.

ques: Who launched All India Home Rule League in September 1916?
options: ["Mahdev Govind Ranade","Bal Gangadhar Tilak","Annie Besant","Joseph Baptista"]
ans_detail: Notes:The All India Home Rule League was launched by Annie Besant on September 1916. The league had to work in all India except Maharastra and Central Provinces. The objectives of this league were same as the Indian Home rule league formed by Bal Gangadhar Tilak in April1916. These were –a) To establish self- government.b) To build up an agitation for home rule by promoting political education and discussion.c) To build the confidence of the Indians against the suppression of the British government and to create an alternative movement to break the existing state of stagnation and the inertia.d) To revive the political activity on their own while maintaining the principles of congress. To demand for greater political representation from the British government.e) To demand for greater political representation from the British government.

ques: Where was the Hindustan Socialist Republican Association (HSRA) founded?
ans_detail: Notes:The Hindustan Socialist Republican Association (HSRA), a revolutionary organisation, was founded in 1928 at Feroz Shah Kotla in Delhi by Chandrasekhar Azad, Bhagat Singh, Sukhdev Thapa, etc.

ques: Consider the following matches:Madan Mohan Malviya – Banaras Hindu UniversitySohan Singh Bakhna – Gadar MovementChidambaram Pillai – Swadeshi Steam navigation CompanyRajgopalachari – Vedaranyan Salt SatyagrihaPeriyar E
ans_detail: Notes:Madan Mohan Malviya – Banaras Hindu University (1916). Sohan Singh Bakhna – Gadar Movement (1913), Chidambaram Pillai – Swadeshi Steam navigation Company (1906), Rajgopalachari – Vedaranyan Salt Satyagriha (1930), Periyar E. V. Ramasamy – Self Respect Movement (1925).

ques: Reserve Tranche Position (RTP) is a term used in context with ____?
options: ["Reserve Bank of India","Federal Reserve Bank (of America)","World Bank","International Monetary Fund"]

ques: The Laffer curve is the graphical representation of :
options: ["The relationship between tax rates and absolute revenue these rates generate for the government.","The inverse relationship between the rate of unemployment and the rate of inflation in an economy.","The inequality in income distribution","The relationship between environmental quality and economic development."]
ans: The relationship between tax rates and absolute revenue these rates generate for the government.
ans_detail: Notes:In economics, the Laffer curve is a hypothetical representation of the relationship between government revenue raised by taxation and all possible rates of taxation. It is used to illustrate the concept of taxable income elasticity – that taxable income will change in response to changes in the rate of taxation.

ques: Which among the following is NOT a subsidiary of RBI?
options: ["National Housing Bank","NABARD","Bharatiya Reserve Bank Note Mudran Private Limited","SIDBI"]
ans_detail: Notes:RBI has four subsidiaries viz. Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation, DICGC; National Housing Bank; Bharatiya Reserve Bank Note Mudran Private Limited (BRBNMPL) and NABARD.

ques: Which of the following organizations in India manages the Micro Finance Development Equity Fund?
ans_detail: Notes: NABARD is the correct answer.

ques: The service tax in India is __:
options: ["collected and appropriated by the Union Government","collected by union government, appropriated by state governments","collected by state governments, appropriated by union government","collected and appropriated by state governments"]
ans: collected and appropriated by the Union Government
ans_detail: Notes: To enable Parliament to formulate by law principles for determining the modalities of levying the Service Tax by the Central Govt. and collection of the proceeds thereof by the Central Govt. and the State, the amendment vide Constitution (92nd amendment) Act, 2003 has been made. Consequently, new article 268 A has been inserted for Service Tax levy by Union Govt., collected and appropriated by the Union Govt., and amendment of seventh schedule to the constitution, in list I-Union list after entry 92B, entry 92C has been inserted for taxes on services as well as in article 270 of the constitution the clause (1) article 268A has been included.

ques: Consider the following:External Commercial BorrowingsTreasury billsSpecial drawing rightsWhich of the above can serve as a tool to combat current account deficit?
options: ["1 Only","1 and 2 Only","1 and 3 Only","1,2 and 3"]
ans_detail: Notes:Current account can be reduced with the help of foreign exchange.Treasury bills are short term securities by government.The Reserve Bank of India does not allow foreign institutional investors from buying short-term government securities – treasury bills, or T-Bills to prevent interest rate-related volatility.Hence, treasury bills do not earn any foreign exchange.

ques: Consider the following statements about Unified Payments Interface (UPI):It seeks to promote cashless economy in the countryIt has been developed by National Payments Corporation of India (NPCI)It facilitates the user to have a single virtual address for multiple bank accounts Which of the above statements is/are correct?
ans_detail: Notes: Third statement is incorrect because UPI will allow a customer to have multiple virtual addresses for multiple accounts in various banks.

ques: Consider the following pairs:Indian Veterinary Research Institute – BareillyNational Sugar Institute (NSI) – KanpurCentral Food Technological Research Institute – Mysore Which of the above is/are correct?
ans_detail: Notes: Indian Veterinary Research Institute is located at Izatnagar, Bareilly. The National Sugar Institute (NSI) established in 1936 in Kanpur. Central Food Technological Research Institute is a premier Research Institution under the Council of Scientific & Industrial Research (CSIR).

ques: Which of the following countries recently announced to withdraw from Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP)?
ans_detail: Notes: The 12 countries among which TPP has been agreed upon include – United States, Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Peru, Singapore, and Vietnam. These countries are home to 800 million people and account for 40% of global trade. But recently, on 23 January 2017, President Trump signed a presidential memorandum to withdraw from TPP.

ques: Which of the following is not the member of Federation of Indian Airlines (FIA)?
ans_detail: Notes:Members of the Federation of Indian Airlines are: Indigo, Go Air, Jet Airways, SpiceJet and Kingfisher Airlines. Air Asia India and Vistara, two new entrants in Indian aviation industry are not the members of FIA.

ques: A solstice represents _______?
options: ["Longest day of the year","Shortest Day of the year","Either longest or shortest day of the Year","Solar eclipse"]
ans: Either longest or shortest day of the Year
ans_detail: Notes:A solstice represents Either longest or shortest day of the Year. The summer solstice is on June 21 and winter solstice is on December 21.

ques: Which of the following part of Africa is called “Horn of Africa”?
options: ["westernmost projection of the African continent.","easternmost projection of the African continent.","southernmost part of the African continent.","North west part of African continent."]
ans: easternmost projection of the African continent.
ans_detail: Notes:The Horn of Africa is a peninsula in Africa Continent. It lies along the southern side of the Red Sea and extends hundreds of kilometers into the Gulf of Aden, Somali Sea and Guardafui Channel. The area is the easternmost projection of the African continent.

ques: Which star is directly above North Pole?
ans_detail: Notes:Polaris star is directly above the north pole. Earth rotates around this point, so Polaris does not appear to move in the sky.

ques: What kinds of stars are smaller than Earth?
ans_detail: Notes:White Dwarfs are smaller than the Earth. A white dwarf is a small hot star that is a leftover center of an older star. They can shine for billions of years before they extinguish.

ques: Which among the following is an asteroid as well as a dwarf planet?
ans_detail: Notes:Vesta, Juno and Pallas are asteroids, whereas, Ceres is an asteroid as well as a dwarf planet. Ceres was classified as a dwarf planet in 2006.

ques: Which among the following pairs is/are correctly matched?Sea floor spreading – Explains the Movement of Continents onlyContinental Drift Theory – Explains the Movement of Oceanic Plates onlyPlate Tectonics – Explains the Movement of Lithospheric plates that include both continents and oceans
ans_detail: Notes:Sea Floor Spreading by Harry Hess explains the movement of oceanic plates only.Continental Drift Theory by Alfred Wegener explains the movement of continents only.

ques: What are the two types of surface waves?
options: ["Love waves and Raleigh waves","Love waves and Longitudinal waves","Longitudinal and Transverse waves","Longitudinal and Raleigh waves"]
ans_detail: Notes:Surface waves travel parallel to the Earth’s surface and are the slowest and the most damaging.surface waves are divided into: Love waves and Raleigh waves.

ques: Which among the following volcanoes is not included in the Mediterranean Belt?
ans_detail: Notes:Cotopaxi in Andes is a part of the Circum Pacific Belt. 80% of all the volcanoes are situated in the Circum Pacific Belt.

ques: Which among the following rocks is highly resistant to weathering?
ans_detail: Notes:Quartz, chemically weathers very, very slowly due to its high stability. It therefore remains unchanged.

ques: On the basis of which of the following are landforms classified?
ans_detail: Notes:The study of landforms is called as geomorphology. Landforms are classified on the basis of stratification, elevation, slope, orientation etc.

ques: Which of these is NOT a compound of carbon?
ans_detail: Notes:Caustic soda is a compound of sodium where as Acetic acid, Chloroform and Methane are the compounds of carbon.

ques: What is Rose metal?
options: ["It is an alloy of Nickel, Tin and Zinc","It is an alloy of Bismuth, Copper and Palladium","It is an alloy of Palladium, Tin and Lead","It is an alloy of Bismuth, Tin and Lead"]
ans: It is an alloy of Bismuth, Tin and Lead
ans_detail: Notes:Rose metal is an alloy of Bismuth, Tin and Lead. It’s a fusible alloy with low melting point commonly used for soldering.

ques: Which of the following is correct about tincture of iodine?
options: ["It is a solution of iodine in ethanol","It is a solution of iodine in Hydrochloric acid","It is a solution of iodine in Nitric acid","None of the above"]
ans: It is a solution of iodine in ethanol
ans_detail: Notes:A solution of iodine in alcohol known as ‘tincture of iodine’, has iodine (solid) as the solute and alcohol (liquid) as the solvent.

ques: Choose the incorrect ‘Alloy – constituent metal’ pair:
ans_detail: Notes:Lockalloy is an alloy that contains 62% beryllium and 38% aluminum. All other pairs are correctly matched.

ques: Which of the following is a correct statement about minerals and ores?
options: ["All minerals are ores","All ores are minerals","Minerals are the native form in which various metals exist","Ores are usually used to extract metals economically"]
ans_detail: Notes:All ores are minerals but all minerals are not ores. Minerals are the native form in which various metals exist and ores are those minerals which are used to extract metals economically.

ques: Which of the following refining methods works on the principle that impurities are more soluble in the melt than in the solid state of the metal?
ans_detail: Notes:Zone refining works on the principle that impurities are more soluble in the melt than in the solid state of the metal. This method is very useful for producing semiconductors.

ques: What is the probability of finding an electron at a point within an atom?
options: ["proportional to the square of the orbital wave function","proportional to the orbital wave function","proportional to the twice of the orbital wave function","proportional to the cube of the orbital wave function"]
ans: proportional to the square of the orbital wave function
ans_detail: Notes:The probability of finding an electron at a point within an atom is proportional to the square of the orbital wave function i.e., ψ|2 at that point. |ψ|2 is known as probability density and is always positive.

ques: What is the difference between the mass number of Parent nucleus and Daughter nucleus in an alpha-decay process?
ans_detail: Notes:In α-decay, the mass number of the product nucleus (daughter nucleus) is four less than that of the decaying nucleus (parent nucleus), while the atomic number decreases by two.

ques: Which of the following gas is used to prevent the chips from getting oxidised?
ans_detail: Notes:The chips manufacturers usually flush bags of chips with gas such as nitrogen to prevent the chips from getting oxidised.

ques: What is the order of the reaction which is independent of the concentration of reactants?
ans_detail: Notes:Order of a reaction can be 0, 1, 2, 3 and even a fraction. A zero order reaction means that the rate of reaction is independent of the concentration of reactants.

ques: Which of the following depicts correct sequence in the context of Preamble of the Constitution of India?
options: ["Democratic – Secular – Sovereign – Republic – Socialist","Sovereign – Socialist – Democratic – Republic – Secular","Sovereign – Socialist – Democratic –Secular – Republic","Sovereign – Socialist – Secular – Democratic – Republic"]
ans_detail: Notes:The correct sequence depicted in the Preamble of the Constitution of India is as follows: “We, THE PEOPLE OF INDIA, having solemnly resolved to constitute India into a SOVEREIGN SOCIALIST SECULAR DEMOCRTAIC REPUBLIC…”

ques: Which of the following Articles of the Indian Constitution provides protection to the accused regarding conviction from double-bar and self-incrimination?
ans_detail: Notes:Article 20(2) says that no person shall be prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once. Article 20(3) describes that no person accused of any offence should be compelled to be a witness against himself.

ques: Elementary education was made a Fundamental Right under which Constitutional Amendment Act?
options: ["42nd Amendment Act, 1972","44th Amendment Act, 1974","86th Amendment Act, 2002","92nd Amendment Act, 2003"]
ans_detail: Notes:By changing the subject-matter of Article 45, elementary education was made a fundamental right under Article 21 A through the 86th Amendment Act of 2002. The amendment directs the State to provide early childhood care and education for all children until they complete the age of six years.

ques: Which of the following Articles directs the state to protect and improve the environment?
ans_detail: Notes:Article 48A directs the state to protect and improve the environment and to safeguard forests and wild life. The is included in this category representing the ideology of liberalism

ques: Which of the following provisions cannot be amended by simple majority?
options: ["Admission or establishment of new states","Abolition or creation of legislative councils in states","Directive Principles of State Policy","Sixth Schedule–administration of tribal areas"]
ans_detail: Notes:Article 368 provides for two types of amendments- (1) amendment by simple majority and (2) amendment by special majority. The provisions which can be amended by special majority are (i)Fundamental Rights; (ii) Directive Principles of State Policy.

ques: According to which Article of the Constitution the executive power of the Union is vested in the President?
ans_detail: Notes:According to the Article 52 (1) of the Constitution of India the executive power of the Union Government is vested in the President and shall be exercised by him either directly or through officers subordinate to him.

ques: On whose advice the President can promulgate or withdraw an ordinance?
options: ["Prime Minister","Vice-President","Council of Ministers","On his own will"]
ans_detail: Notes:The President has the power to  withdraw an ordinance at any time. However, this power of ordinance-making is not a discretionary power. He can promulgate or withdraw an ordinance only on the advice of the council of ministers headed by the prime minister.

ques: Who described Prime Minister as ‘primus inter pares’ (first among equals) and ‘key stone of the cabinet arch’?
options: ["Herbert Marrison","Sir William Vernor Harcourt","H.J. Laski","Lord Morely"]
ans_detail: Notes:Lord Morely described Prime Minister as ‘primus inter pares’ (first among equals) and ‘key stone of the cabinet arch’. He said, “The head of the cabinet is ‘primus inter pares’, and occupied a position which long as it lasts, is one of exceptional and peculiar authority”.

ques: Who said that the “The Cabinet is the pivot around which the whole political machinery revolves”?
ans_detail: Notes:Sir John Marriott said that “The Cabinet is the pivot around which the whole political machinery revolves”. He was a British educationist, historian and Conservative Member of the Parliament.

ques: Which Article of the Constitution deals with the definition of money bills?
ans_detail: Notes:Article 110 of the Constitution of India deals with the definition of money bills. It states that a bill is deemed to be a money bill if it contains ‘only’ provisions dealing with imposition, abolition, remission, alteration or regulation of any tax, regulation of the borrowing of money by the Union government etc.

ques: Leela Samson is associated to which classical dance style?
ans_detail: Notes:Leela Samson is a Bharatanatyam dancer, choreographer, instructor and writer. Starting her career as a Bharatanatyam soloist, Samson taught at Shriram Bharatiya Kala Kendra, Delhi, and Gandharva Mahavidyalaya, Delhi. Over the years she has performed across India and abroad including Europe, Africa and the Americas.

ques: Madhuri Dixit is associated with which Indian Dance form?
ans_detail: Notes:Madhuri Dixit is a trained professional Kathak dancer. Pandit Birju Maharaj, a Kathak dancer, who choreographed Dixit in the film Devdas for the song “Kaahe Chhed”, calls her “the best Bollywood dancer due to her versatility.” Kathak is one of the ten major forms of Indian classical dance.

ques: Begum Akhtar is associated to which art form?
ans_detail: Notes:Akhtari Bai Faizabadi, also known as Begum Akhtar, was a well-known Indian singer of Ghazal, Dadra, and Thumri genres of Hindustani classical music. She was given the title of Mallika-e-Ghazal (Queen of Ghazals). She was from Bhadarsa is a town and nagar panchayat in Faizabad district in state of Uttar Pradesh, India.

ques: In which of the following states is Kardang Monastery situated?
ans_detail: Notes:Kardang monastery is one of the oldest possession of Drukpa lineage. The monastery is historical because it is a part of Kardang village which was once the capital of Lahaul, Himachal Pradesh. The monastery houses a phenomenal collection of murals, paintings, frescos, Thangka paintings, old weapons and instrumentals like horns, flutes, drums, etc.

ques: Shiv Kumar Sharma is famous for playing which instrument?
ans_detail: Notes:Pandit Shivkumar Sharma is an Indian music composer and santoor player from Jammu. The santoor is originally a folk instrument, but became an instrument for Indian classical through his internationally recognized playing style. Tarun Bhattacharya is also a famous santoor player.

ques: Which of the following states holds GI tag for Kasuti Embroidery?
ans_detail: Notes:Kasuti is a traditional form of folk embroidery practised in the state of Karnataka, India. Kasuti work which is very intricate sometimes involves putting up to 5,000 stitches by hand and is traditionally made on dresswear like Ilkal sarees, Ravike and Angi. Karnataka Handicrafts Development Corporation (KHDC) holds a Geographical Indications (GI) protection for ‘Kasuti Embroidery’ which provides intellectual property rights on ‘Kasuti’ to KHDC.

ques: Ebraham Alkazi is an eminent personality in which one of the following area?
ans_detail: Notes:Ebrahim Alkazi is one of the most influential Indian theatre directors and drama teachers in 20th-century Indian theatre. He is a former Director of National School of Drama, New Delhi. A noted art connoisseur, collector and gallery owner, he founded Art Heritage Gallery in Delhi.

ques: Match the following
Which painting is also known as Italon?
ans_detail: Notes:Soura tribal painting comes from the state of Odisha, India. It is said to be one of the tribal paintings of India. This is the wall painting style of the tribal tribe. It is also called Italon. This is a painting having religious significance like a blind form. In Soura’s painting, the border is first drawn and then the inner parts are filled in, which is called the fish-net approach. The symbols included in this include the sun god, moon, trees, plants, and animals being part of life, horses, elephants, village activities.

ques: Where was the statue of “Bronze Dancer” of Harappan civilization found?
ans_detail: Notes:Indus art is a famous ancient Indian art. It is widely accepted that the Indus civilization is completely indigenous. The most important works of this art are the bronze sculpture of a dancer from Harappa and the torso of a red stone idol, figures of bulls, and monkeys from Mohenjodaro.

ques: What is the nickname of India Women’s National Hockey Team?
ans_detail: Notes:India Women’s National Field Hockey Team is ranked 9th in the International Hockey Federation’s rankings. It is nicknamed as Nabhvarna.

ques: Where are the headquarters of the Olympic Council of Asia?
ans_detail: Notes:The headquarters of the Olympic Council of Asia are at Kuwait City at Kuwait. It is the governing body of sports in Asia and has 45 member National Olympic Committees.

ques: In which year, the first modern Olympic Games held?
ans_detail: Notes:The first modern Olympic Games was held in the year 1896. In 1890, after attending the Olympian Games of the Wenlock Olympian Society, Baron Pierre de Coubertin was inspired to found the International Olympic Committee (IOC). Coubertin built on the ideas and work of Brookes and Zappas with the aim of establishing internationally rotating Olympic Games that would occur every four years. He presented these ideas during the first Olympic Congress of the newly created International Olympic Committee. This meeting was held from 16 to 23 June 1894, at the University of Paris. On the last day of the Congress, it was decided that the first Olympic Games to come under the auspices of the IOC would take place in Athens in 1896. The IOC elected the Greek writer Demetrius Vikelas as its first president.

ques: In which Olympic Games, Olympic mascot have first started using?
options: ["1928 Summer Olympics, Amsterdam","1936 Winter Olympics, Berlin","1948 Summer Olympics, London","1968 Winter Olympics, Grenoble"]
ans_detail: Notes:In the 1968 Winter Olympics, Grenoble, a city of France, Olympic mascot have first started using. Since the 1968 Winter Olympics in Grenoble, France, the Olympic Games have had a mascot, usually an animal native to the area or occasionally human figures representing the cultural heritage. Nowadays, most of the merchandise aimed at young people focus on the mascots, rather than the Olympic flag or organization logos.

ques: Which was the target country of the infamous “Munich massacre” in the 1972 Summer Olympics, Munich?
ans_detail: Notes:Israel was the target country of the infamous “Munich massacre” in the 1972 Summer Olympics, Munich. The Munich massacre was an attack during the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich, West Germany, by eight members of the Palestinian terrorist group Black September, who took nine members of the Israeli Olympic team hostage, after killing two of them previously, and killing them along with a West German police officer. The motive was Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

ques: Which was the motive behind the infamous “Munich massacre” in the 1972 Summer Olympics, Munich?
options: ["West Germany-East Germany Conflict","Chile-Argentina Conflict","Israeli-Palestinian Conflict","United States of America-Cuba Conflict"]
ans_detail: Notes:Israeli-Palestinian Conflict was the motive behind the infamous “Munich massacre” in the 1972 Summer Olympics, Munich. The Munich massacre was an attack during the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich, West Germany, by eight members of the Palestinian terrorist group Black September, who took nine members of the Israeli Olympic team hostage, after killing two of them previously, and killing them along with a West German police officer. The motive was Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

ques: Which Olympic Games is also known as the “Millenium Olympic Games”?
options: ["1996 Summer Olympics, Atlanta","2000 Summer Olympics, Sydney","2004 Summer Olympics, Athens","2008 Summer Olympics, Beijing"]
ans_detail: Notes:The 2000 Summer Olympics, Sydney is also known as the “Millenium Olympic Games”. The 2000 Summer Olympics, officially known as the Games of the XXVII Olympiad and commonly known as Sydney 2000, the Millennium Olympic Games or the Games of the New Millennium, were an international multi-sport event held from 15 September to 1 October 2000 in Sydney, New South Wales, Australia. It was the second time the Summer Olympics were held in Australia, and in the Southern Hemisphere, the first being in Melbourne, Victoria, in 1956. The United States topped the medals table and won the most gold.

ques: Which is the second-largest multi-sport event after the Olympic Games?
ans_detail: Notes:Asian Games is the second-largest multi-sport event after the Olympic Games. The Asian Games, also known as Asiad, is a continental multi-sport event held every four years among athletes from all over Asia. The Games were regulated by the Asian Games Federation (AGF) from the first Games in New Delhi, India, until the 1978 Games. Since the 1982 Games, they have been organized by the Olympic Council of Asia (OCA), after the breakup of the Asian Games Federation. The Games are recognized by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and are described as the second-largest multi-sport event after the Olympic Games.

ques: Which is the first mascot of the Asian Games?
options: ["Hodori, the Tiger Cub","Pan Pan, the Panda","Popp and Cuccu, the pair of white doves","Appu, the Indian Elephant"]
ans_detail: Notes:Appu, the Indian Elephant is the first mascot of the Asian Games. Since the 1982 Asian Games in New Delhi, India, the Asian Games have had a mascot, usually an animal native to the area or occasionally human figures representing the cultural heritage.

ques: Who was “George Parr”?
options: ["An English Cricketer","An English Footballer","An English Golfer","An English Tennis player"]
ans_detail: Notes:“George Parr” was an English Cricketer. George Parr (22 May 1826 – 23 June 1891) was an English cricketer whose first-class career lasted from 1844 to 1870. Known popularly as the “Lion of the North”, Parr was a right-handed batsman and bowled occasional right-handed underarm deliveries. Throughout his career, he played mainly for Nottinghamshire and was club captain from 1856 to 1870. He was a stalwart of the All-England Eleven and was captain of the first England touring team, which went to North America in 1859. He also captained England’s second tour to Australia and New Zealand in 1864, returning home unbeaten.

ques: The spray bottles used as window or household cleaner or perfume spray works on:
ans_detail: Notes:When we press the top of bottle the pressure at top of the bottle decreases and hence, the velocity of liquid flow increases. Bernoulli’s Principle states that an increase in the speed of a fluid produces a decrease in pressure and that a decrease in the speed of a fluid produces an increase in pressure. The principle states that the total energy of a moving fluid remains constant at all times.

ques: Consider the following differences between bacteria and cyanobacteria:While bacteria are prokaryotic organisms, cyanobacteria are eukaryotic organismsBacteria are comparatively smaller in size than cyanobacteria Which of the above statements is/are correct?
ans_detail: Notes:First statement is incorrect because both bacteria and cyanobacteria are prokaryotic organisms.

ques: Consider the following statements with respect to the Thermionic emission: 1
ans_detail: Notes:The thermionic emission is cased by electrons or ions that break loose from the metal surface due to heat energy. The minimum heat energy required to make a metal emit an electron (thermion), from its surface is called threshold energy or work function. Electron volt (eV): It is the smallest unit of work and is generally used to measure threshold energy. It is defined as the amount of work done, when a charge of 1.6 × 10–19 coulombs (charge of one electron), moves through two points in an electric field, at a potential difference of one volt. 1 eV = 1.6 × 10–19 C × V = 1.6 × l0–19 J. The minimum temperature at which a particular material emits thermions from its surface on heating is called threshold temperature. A metal cannot emit thermions at all temperatures. The thermions are emitted by a metal only when its temperature is higher than the threshold temperature. (b) 1eV = 1.6 × l0–19 C × 1 V = 1.6 × l0–19 J

ques: Which among the following statements with reference to Rainbow is / are correct? 1
options: ["Only 1 is correct","Only 2 is correct","Both 1 & 2 are correct","Neither 1 nor 2 is correct"]
ans_detail: Notes:The first statement need knowledge and second statement needs some commonsense. Beautiful rainbows, which sometimes arch across the sky during rain showers, do not appear during snow showers. This is because a snowflake has a different shape than a raindrop. When raindrops fall from the sky, they are round like tiny balls. To form a rainbow, the sun must shine on the raindrops. When a ray of sunlight reaches a raindrop, some of the light enters the drop and refracts. This means that the ray bends at the surface of the drop and changes its direction. Different colors of light refract in slightly different directions. This is how the white sunlight, which is really a combination of red, orange, yellow, green, blue and violet light, gets separated into different colors. Then each colored ray of light takes its own path inside the raindrop and exits in a different direction. Therefore, when you look up at the rain in the sky, each color of light comes at you from a different direction, and you see a rainbow. In contrast to the simple round shape of raindrops, snowflakes are six-sided and flat. When sunlight shines on snowflakes tumbling and falling through the air, the many different surfaces of the snowflakes cause the light to be refracted and reflected in many different directions, and the light is too scattered to form a rainbow. However, in special situations snowflakes can create interesting and beautiful displays with sunlight. Parahelia, sometimes called “mock suns” or “sun dogs,” are bright spots that appear to the left and right of the sun. They form when rays of sunlight refract through thin plate-like snowflakes that are falling flat through calm air. Often each bright spot has a reddish side and a bluish side. The rainbow is not located at a specific distance, but comes from any water droplets viewed from a certain angle relative to the Sun’s rays. Thus, a rainbow is not a physical object, and cannot be physically approached. Indeed, it is impossible for an observer to manoeuvre to see any rainbow from water droplets at any angle other than the customary one of 42 degrees from the direction opposite the Sun. Even if an observer sees another observer who seems “under” or “at the end” of a rainbow, the second observer will see a different rainbow further off-yet, at the same angle as seen by the first observer.

ans_detail: Notes:

ques: Consider the following statements:Speed of sound increases with increase in density of the mediumSpeed of sound increases with increase in temperature of the medium    Which of the above statements is/are correct?
ans_detail: Notes:When the elasticity of the medium increases the density decreases and it increases the sound speed. Higher temperatures lower the density of a medium, which puts less resistance on the sound waves.

ques: Nuclear Reactors are based on which of the following phenomenon?
options: ["Magnetic confinement of Plasma","Nuclear Fusion","Controlled Nuclear Fission","None of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:Nuclear Reactors uses Controlled Nuclear Fission to generate electricity. A nuclear reactor splits the atoms of nuclear fuel (eg. uranium) to generate energy to turn water into steam to drive turbine generators. Nuclear fission is the splitting of a heavy nucleus into two lighter ones. Fission was discovered in 1938 by the German scientists Otto Hahn, Lise Meitner, and Fritz Strassmann.

ques: kg m2is the unit of which of the following physical quantities?
ans_detail: Notes: kg m2is the unit of Moment of Inertia. The moment of inertia is a physical quantity which describes how easily a body can be rotated about a given axis. It is a rotational analogue of mass. Moment of Inertia = mass x (radius of gyration)2

ques: What is the slope of the velocity-time graph when an object moves with constant negative acceleration, having positive initial velocity?
ans_detail: Notes:When an object moves with constant negative acceleration, having positive initial velocity, the velocity-time graph is a straight line having slope more than 90°. When an object moves with constant positive acceleration, having positive initial velocity, the velocity-time graph is a straight line having slope less than 90°.

ques: The acceleration at a given instant of time is called as:
ans_detail: Notes:The acceleration of an object at a given instant of time is called Instantaneous acceleration. When an object moves with variable acceleration, then it possesses different acceleration at different point of time.

ques: The Newton’s third law is applicable when:
options: ["bodies are at rest","bodies are in motion","bodies are in the air","bodies are at rest or in motion"]
ans: bodies are at rest or in motion
ans_detail: Notes:The Newton’s third law is applicable whether the bodies are at rest or in motion. It states that to every action there is an equal and opposite reaction.

ques: Choose the correct statement about weight:
options: ["It is a scalar quantity","Its value is independent of g","It is determined by a spring balance","None of the above"]
ans: It is determined by a spring balance
ans_detail: Notes:Weight is the attractive force exerted by earth on any body. Its value changes with g. It is determined by a spring balance. It is a vector quantity.

ques: The minimum speed required to put a satellite into a given orbit around earth is known as:
options: ["Escape velocity","Orbital velocity","Kinetic velocity","None of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:The minimum speed required to put a satellite into a given orbit around earth is known as Orbital velocity of the satellite. Orbital velocity (v) = (GM/r)1/2 where G= gravitational constant, M= mass of the earth and r = radius of the orbit of the satellite.

ques: Which of the following is the orbital velocity of a satellite orbiting very close to the surface of earth?
ans_detail: Notes:In this case, the radius of the orbit will be nearly equal to the radius of earth. The orbital velocity of a satellite orbiting very close to the surface of earth is 7.92 km/s.

ques: Which of the following statements is correct?
options: ["Bulk stress occurs only in liquids","Longitudinal stress occurs only in solids","Both a and b","None of the above"]
ans: Longitudinal stress occurs only in solids
ans_detail: Notes:Longitudinal stress occurs only in solids. It comes in picture only when one of the three dimensions viz. length, breadth, height is much greater than other two.

ques: What is the relationship between mass and time period of a spring pendulum?
options: ["T∝ 1/√m","T ∝ √m","T ∝ m","√T ∝ m"]
ans_detail: Notes:Time period of a spring pendulum depends on the mass suspended as T∝  √m i.e. greater the mass greater will be the inertia and so lesser will be the frequency of oscillation and greater will be the time period.

ques: Which of the following is correct about Convection?
options: ["It is possible in solids only","It is possible in fluids only","It is possible in solids and gases only","None of the above"]
ans: It is possible in fluids only
ans_detail: Notes:Convection is a mode of heat transfer by actual motion of matter. It is possible only in fluids.

ques: What do we call the process taking place at constant volume?
ans_detail: Notes:The process taking place in a thermodynamic system at constant volume is known as Isochoric process.

ques: What is the refractive index of water?
ans_detail: Notes:The refractive index of air is 1.33.

ques: What is the equivalent internal resistance of a series combination of n cells?
options: ["the arithmetic mean of their internal resistance","the product of their individual internal resistance","the sum of their individual internal resistance","the sum of the reciprocal of their individual internal resistance"]
ans: the sum of their individual internal resistance
ans_detail: Notes:The equivalent internal resistance of a series combination of n cells is just the sum of their internal resistances.

ques: Which of the following is a reducing sugar?
ans_detail: Notes:The dietary monosaccharides galactose, glucose and fructose are all reducing sugars.

ques: Zygotic meiosis is characterized by__?
ans_detail: Notes:Chlamydomonas is a genus of green algae that includes about 150 species. All these unicellular flagellates are found as “snow algae” in stagnant water and on moist soil, in freshwater, seawater and even ice. A zygotic meiosis is the meiosis of a zygote immediately following the karyotype, which is the fusion of two cell nuclei.

ques: Which of the following is a common feature of protonema of multicellular fungi, filamentous algae, and mosses?
options: ["way of nutrition","diplomatic life cycle","multiply by fragmentation","members of the plant kingdom"]
ans_detail: Notes:The protonema of multicellular fungi, filamentous algae and mosses all show multiplication by fragmentation.

ques: The cocci which form a bunch and irregular pattern are__?
ans_detail: Notes:Staphylococcus species are gram-positive cocci (spherical) bacteria belonging to the family Micrococcaceae. It also includes Micrococcus and Kocuria.

ques: Pyrenoids are the center of the formation of__?
ans_detail: Notes:Pyrenoids are the center of the formation of Starch. Pyrenoids are non-membrane-bound organelles found in the chloroplasts of algae and hornwort plants. It can be seen by light-microscopy.

ques: Which of the following is not a characteristic of Bryophyta?
options: ["Motile sperms","Presence of archegonium","Presence of archegonium","Photosynthetically independent sporophyte"]
ans_detail: Notes:Motile sperms, the Presence of archegonium, and the Presence of archegonium are characteristics of Bryophyta.

ques: What are the characteristics of gymnosperms?
options: ["naked seeds","separate female and male gametes","pollination by wind, and tracheids","All of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:The characteristics of gymnosperms are naked seeds, separate female and male gametes, pollination by wind, and tracheids.

ques: To which family do brown mustard and broccoli belong?
ans_detail: Notes:Brassicaceae or Cruciferae is a medium-sized family of flowering plants commonly known as the mustard, cruciferous or cabbage family.

ques: Which plant tissue has the ability to grow rapidly by division?
ans_detail: Notes:Meristematic tissues have the ability to grow rapidly by division and they help in the major development of vegetation. The increase in length and increase in diameter of the plant is done by these cells. Meristematic cells are dense, living cells that have a large nucleus.

ques: Apical, lateral and intercalary are the types of which plant tissue?
ans_detail: Notes:Apical, lateral and intercalary are the types of Meristematic tissue. Apical meristem upsurges the length of the plant, Lateral meristem upsurges the thickness of the plant, and Intercalary meristem upsurges the size of the internode.

ques: In recent times, the Wildlife and zoo managers have focussed on conserving endangered species such as Nilgiris Tahr, Nilgiris Langur and Lion Tailed Macaques (LTMs), which are on the verge of becoming extinct
ans_detail: Notes:Captive breeding is the process of breeding animals in human controlled environments with restricted settings, such as wildlife reserves, zoos and other conservation facilities; sometimes the process is construed to include release of individual organisms to the wild, when there is sufficient natural habitat to support new individuals or when the threat to the species in the wild is lessened. Captive breeding programs facilitate biodiversity and may save species from extinction. However, such programs may also reduce genetic diversity and species fitness. Captive breeding techniques are usually difficult to implement for highly mobile species like some migratory birds (e.g. cranes) and fishes (e.g. Hilsa). Species like large cetaceans (whales, dolphins, etc.) may also have some difficulties as it would be hard to meet their biological requirements in captivity, especially the vast amount of space required to keep large populations.

ques: Which among the following play role in Global Warming?Water VapourLaughing GasCarbon MonoxideCarbon DioxideSelect the correct option from the codes given below:
ans_detail: Notes:All of them. Nitrous Oxide is laughing gas, rest three are GHG. Please note that as it is, Carbon monoxide (CO) is only a very weak and insignificant greenhouse gas, but has important indirect effects on global warming. Carbon monoxide reacts with hydroxyl (OH) radicals in the atmosphere, reducing their abundance. As OH radicals help to reduce the lifetimes of strong greenhouse gases. like methane, carbon monoxide indirectly increases the global warming potential of these gases. Carbon monoxide in the atmosphere can also lead to the formation of the Ground level Ozone.

ques: Identify the animal on the basis of the below hints:This animal is a primate and is generally known as only poisonous primate discovered so farIt is nocturnal, insectivorous animalIt does not have a tail or has a rudimentary tailSelect the correct option from the codes given below:
ans_detail: Notes:Loris is the answer. They have very sharp needle-like teeth on their lower jaw, shaped like a spade. Their bite is so painful and agonizing that they can create extreme allergic reactions (up to anaphylactic shock), followed by Hematuria, which is a reaction to the allergen. Their elbows plays an important part as a lethal weapon, in their defense mechanism. On the inside of the elbows, lies a patch which is used to store a foul smelling toxin. Right before the toxic biting, the loris will suck some poison from the patch and mix it with their saliva, inside their mouth.

ques: The objectives of the National Clean Energy Fund’ (NCEF) include: 1
ans_detail: Notes:Idea is to invest in entrepreneurial ventures and research in the field of clean energy technologies. Any project/scheme for innovative methods to adopt to clean energy technology and research & development is eligible for funding under the NCEF. This fund is not used to provide funds to states for setting up solar units.

ques: The famous Kigali Amendment is related to:
options: ["Phase out the use of hydro fluorocarbons (HFCs)","New global treaty to reduce green house gases emission","International agreement for transboundary movements of genetically modified organisms (GMOs)","International disaster risk reduction plan"]
ans: Phase out the use of hydro fluorocarbons (HFCs)
ans_detail: Notes:The Kigali agreement took place in October 2016. It amends the Montreal Protocol and substantially limit the emission of hydro fluorocarbons (HFCs) that contribute to global warming represents major progress. As with other such global compacts on environmental matters, India pressed for a more lenient deadline at the Rwanda negotiations.

ques: The most favorable habitat of a plant is called _?
ans_detail: Notes:First option is the correct answer A micro habitat is that which is small or limited extent and which differs in character from some surrounding more extensive habitat.

ques: Consider the following organisms:BatsMonkeysLizardMice Which of the above is/are pollinating agent/agents?
ans_detail: Notes:The most common agents of pollination are flying insects and the wind, but crawling and hopping insects, snails, bats, primates, rodents, and hummingbirds may also serve.

ques: Bellandur Lake, which was frequently in news due to environmental issues, is located in which state?
ans_detail: Notes:Bellandur Lake is located in Bengaluru, Karnataka. It was recently in news when National Green Tribunal (NGT) recently ordered shut-down of all industries around the water body.

options: ["Baghelkhand Plateau","Malwa Plateau","Chotanagpur Plateau","None of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:The Malwa Plateau is enclosed by Bundelkhand in the east, Aravalli in the north and Vindhyan Range in the south.

ques: Marwar plateau lies which side of the Aravalli hill range?
ans_detail: Notes:Marwar plateau lies to the north-western side of the Aravalli hill range (southwestern Rajasthan). Some parts of it lie in the Thar desert.

ques: Deltas are common in the East-flowing river of India, whereas they are nearly absent on the West coast because West-flowing rivers
options: ["originate in dry areas","originate largely in the Western Ghats and have short distance to cover to the sea","are few","have lesser water volume and carry less run-off silt"]
ans: have lesser water volume and carry less run-off silt
ans_detail: Notes:Most of the Western flowing rivers travel a lesser distance than eastern flowing rivers before draining into the sea. On way to Western coast through hard rocks and over a steep gradient rift valley, they couldn’t collect a large amounts of Slit and flow with very high speed compared to East flowing rivers. Eastern rivers flow through broken hills and are widened and flow with lesser velocity before draining into sea. So, they are capable of depositing sediments and silt before draining into the sea and usually form a Delta.

ques: Which of the following is not a tributary of the river Luni?
ans_detail: Notes:The Luni River originates near Ajmer in the Pushkar valley of the western Aravalli Range at an elevation of about 550m. The name of its lefy banktributaries are the Sukri, Mithri, Bandi, Khari, Jawai, Guhiya and the right bank tributaries are Sagi, and the Jojari River.

ques: Which among the following are the artificial lakes of India?1
ans_detail: Notes:Pangong (Ladakh), Pushkar (Rajasthan), Kodaikanal (Tamil Nadu) are the artificial lakes of India.

ques: Which of the following type of soils is commonly known as ‘self-mulching soil’?
ans_detail: Notes:Black soil is commonly known as ‘self-mulching soil’ (It mixes itself its surface layer shrink and swell farming deep cracks).

ques: Kaziranga national park is famous for which of the following species?
ans_detail: Notes:Kaziranga national park is famous for its horn Rhinoceros.

ques: Which one of the following states in India has the largest area under forest cover?
ans_detail: Notes:Madhya Pradesh has the largest area (77,414 Sq. Km) under forest cover.

ques: Which of the following physiographic division of India has the highest forest cover?
options: ["Himalayan region","The great plain","Peninsular plateau region","Eastern and Western ghat"]
ans_detail: Notes:The Peninsular plateau region of India has the highest forest cover (57%). It is followed by the Himalayan region (18%).

ques: Which of the following states has the maximum percentage of forest cover?
ans_detail: Notes:The state of Mizoram (85.41%) has the maximum percentage of forest cover. Mizoram is followed by Arunachal Pradesh and Meghalaya.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following is an example of rock-cut architecture of the Mauryan period?
ans_detail: Notes:The Maurya period also saw the beginning of rock-cut architecture. Ashoka replaced the use of wood and brick with stone. The rock-cut architecture of Lomasha Risi cave in the Barabara hills near Gaya, and the Dhauli caves near Bhubaneswar, are some of the good examples.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: The achievements of Gautamiputra Satkarni were described and eulogised after his death in which of the following inscriptions?
options: ["Junagarh Inscription","Naneghat Inscription","Nashik Inscription","None of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:The achievements of Satavahana King  Gautamiputra Satkarniare were described and eulogised after his death, during his son Pulumayi II’s reign, in a Nashik Inscription of his mother Gautami Balashri. The inscription is written in Prakrit.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following was the official language of the Satavahanas?
ans_detail: Notes:Prakrit was the official language of the Satavahanas. One of the famous Prakrit texts, which was composed during this time was Gathasattasai. It is attributed to a Satavahana king called Hala. It consists of 700 verses all written in Prakrit.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following foreign travelers mentions in his memoirs that the Chandalas lived outside the village and had to maintain distance from the upper castes?
ans_detail: Notes:The Chinese traveler Fa-Hien mentions in his memoirs that the chandalas lived outside the village and had to maintain distance from the upper castes. The chandalas were told to strike a piece of wood to announce their arrival when they entered towns or market places so that the others might not touch them and get polluted.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: “Gapata Sarah” refers to which of the following?
options: ["Waste land","Jungle or forest land","Habitable land","Pasture land"]
ans_detail: Notes:The land during the Gupta period can be classified into the following groups:Kshetra: Cultivable landKhila: Waste landAprahata: Jungle or forest landVasti: Habitable landGapata Sarah: Pasture land

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: At which of the following places a lifesized bronze image of the Buddha has been discovered?
ans_detail: Notes:During the Gupta period, Buddhism had a great impact on art and architecture. A life-sized bronze image of Buddha belonging to the Mathura school of art has been found from Sultanganj in Bihar.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: In which of the following architectural style, temples in northern India were made in the Gupta period?
ans_detail: Notes:Temple Architecture started in India during the Gupta period. The northern temples were made in the architectural style known as Nagara. Square temples with flat-roof were built in northern India.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following was the founder of the Vatsagulma line of the Vakatakas?
ans_detail: Notes:The founder of the Vatsagulma line of the Vakatakas was Sarvasena. sarvasena was the son of Pravarasena I. Vatsagulma line is the second major Vakataka line.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following inscriptions mentions that Harsha defeated the Vallabhi king, Dhruvasena II?
options: ["Sohgaura copper plate inscription","Nausasi copper plate inscription","Kadamba copper plate inscription","None of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:Harsha emerged victorious against the ruler of Sindh in the north west. He also defeated the Vallabhi king, Dhruvasena II, as mentioned in the Nausasi copper plate inscription. However, Harsha was defeated by Chalukyan king Pulkesin II.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following kings succeeded Nagabhatta I?
ans_detail: Notes:Vatsaraja who ruled from 780 C.E. to 800 C.E. was one of the successors of Nagabhatta I. He extended his rule over to a large part of North India and made Kannauj in western U.P his capital.

ques: What is the share of paper in Indian imports?

ques: Which among the following forms a vital link on the route between eastern North America and western South America?

ans_detail: Notes:North American-western South American Route route links western South America with eastern and western North America. Panama Canal forms a vital link on the route between eastern North America and western South America.
