ques: Consider the following differences between Brahmo Samaj and the Arya Samaj:While the Brahmo Samaj drew its inspiration from the Vedas, Upanishads and other holy scriptures of ancient India, Arya Samaj believes in the Vedas onlyWhile Brahmo Samaj believed in the western culture and philosophy, the Arya Samaj rejected the western culture and accepted the Indian culture only    Which of the above statements is/are correct?
ans_detail: Notes: Major ideological differences between the Brahmo Samaj and the Arya Samaj are as follow:While the Brahmo Samaj drew its inspiration from the Vedas, Upanishads and other holy scriptures of ancient India, whereas the Arya Samaj believes in the Vedas onlyBrahmo Samaj was primarily reformist, Arya Samaj was primarily revivalist. Brahmo Samaj believed in the western culture and philosophy while the Arya Samaj rejected the western culture and accepted the Indian culture only.For the Brahmo Samaj, human reason is supreme whereas the Arya Samaj believes in the infallibility of the Vedas.The Brahmo Samaj had full faith in the goodness of British government, while Arya Samaj had no faith in the integrity of British government.Brahmo Samaj treated Islam and Christianity at par with Hinduism, Arya Samaj claimed the superiority of Hinduism and claimed that it was best way of life.Brahmo Samaj adopted a conciliatory and peaceful approach, while Arya Samaj propagated its views in an aggressive, authoritative and candid way.Brahmo Samaj mainly influenced educated and intellectuals while Arya Samaj was able to touch the minds of educated and uneducated alike.

ques: Consider the following statements about Satyagraha:The Champaran Satyagraha of 1917 was Mahatma Gandhi's first SatyagrahaForest Satyagraha was started by Loknayak Bapuji Ane   Which of the above statements is/are correct?
ans_detail: Notes:Both are correct statements The Champaran Satyagraha of 1917 was Mahatma Gandhi’s first Satyagraha. Forest Satyagraha was started by loknayak Bapuji Ane, on April 26th, at Pusad in Yeotmal district.

ques: Who helped the English to capture Ormuz by defeating Portuguese?
ans_detail: Notes:King of Iran Shah Abbas helped the English to capture Ormuz by defeating Portuguese in 1622.

ques: Arrange the following incident chronologically1
ans_detail: Notes:Treaty of Aix-La-Chapelle- 1748, Second Carnatic War- 1748-54, Battle of Wandiwash- 1760, Treaty of Paris- 1763

ques: Which of the following kinds of policy Lord Cornwallis followed in case of foreign matters?
options: ["Policy of non-retaliation","Policy of non-alignment","Policy of non-intervention","None of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:The policy of non-intervention implies no intervention in the political matters of Foreign Countries. Lord Cornwallis followed the policy of non-intervention in case of foreign matters.

ques: To defeat the Pindaris, Lord Hasting made an alliance with which of the following powers?
ans_detail: Notes:Lord Hasting made an alliance with the Bhonsle (Apa Sahib) and the Scindias to defeat the Pindaris. Lord Hastings himself commanded the army of Hindustan.

ques: The Mutiny at Barrackpore took place in which year during the reign of Lord Amherst?
ans_detail: Notes:The Mutiny at Barrackpore took place in the year 1824 (November). At that time the First Anglo Burmese war was going on. There was a myth that who will cross the sea, will lose his caste. That played a significant role in this mutiny.

ques: Who of the following is known as the founder of the modern Indian postal service?
ans_detail: Notes:Lord Dalhousie is known as the founder of the modern Indian postal service. He founded the modern Indian postal service in the year 1854. He introduced uniform postage rates. The post office in India was introduced by Lord Bentinck by the Act of 1837.

ques: First Famine code was formulated in which year?
ans_detail: Notes:The first famine code was formulated in the year 1883 by the British Commission during the viceroyship of Lord Ripon. It was actually precautionary measures and necessary instructions to be followed during a Famine.

ques: The treaty of Lhasa was signed in which year?
ans_detail: Notes:The treaty of Lhasa (It was the capital of Tibet) was signed in the year 1904 between Colonel Francis Younghusband and Dalai Lama.

ques: Which act regulates the procedure relating to the removal of a judge of a high court by the process of impeachment?
options: ["Judges Enquiry Act (1948)","Judges Enquiry Act (1958)","Judges Enquiry Act (1960)","Judges Enquiry Act (1968)"]
ans_detail: Notes:The Judges Enquiry Act of the year 1968 regulates the procedure relating to the removal of a judge of a high court by the process of impeachment. The same act also regulates the procedure of removal of a Supreme Court judge.

ques: Writ jurisdiction of the high court is not exclusive but concurrent with the writ jurisdiction of the Supreme Court under which article?
ans_detail: Notes:The writ jurisdiction of the high court under Article 226 is not exclusive but concurrent with the writ jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of India under Article 32 of the Indian Constitution.

ques: Who lays down the organisational structure, jurisdiction and nomenclature of the subordinate judiciary?
ans_detail: Notes:The states themselves lay down the organisational structure, jurisdiction and nomenclature of the subordinate judiciary.Therefore the structure differs slightly from state to state.

ques: Which of the following are the merits of Lok Adalats?1
ans_detail: Notes:The following are the merits of Lok Adalats: (1) there is no court fee and if court fee is already paid the amount will be refunded if the dispute is settled at Lok Adalat, (2) the parties to the dispute can directly interact with the judge through their counsel, (3) the award by the Lok Adalat is binding on the parties involved in the dispute.

ques: Which of the following can be the chairman of Permanent Lok Adalat?1
ans_detail: Notes:The Permanent Lok Adalat shall consist of a Chairman. The chairman can be a person who is or has been a district judge or additional district judge or has held judicial office higher in rank than that of the district judge and two other persons having adequate experience in public utilityservices.

ques: Where was the first municipal corporation set in India?
ans_detail: Notes:The first municipal corporation in India was set up in Madras in the year 1688. Later in 1726, these were also set up in Bombay and Calcutta.

ques: Each autonomous district has a district council consisting of how many members?
ans_detail: Notes:Each autonomous district in the tribal areas has a district council consisting of 30 members. Out of 30 four are nominated by the governor and the remaining 26 are elected on the basis of adult franchise.

ques: How many members are there in the State Human Rights Commission including the chairman?
ans_detail: Notes:The State Human Rights Commission is a multi-member body which consists of a chairperson and two other members. The chairperson and members are appointed by the Governor of the state on the recommendations of a committee consisting of the chief minister as its head.

ques: In which year the Competition Commission of India became fully functional?
ans_detail: Notes:The Competition Commission of India acts as the regulator of competition in India. The Commission was established in 2003, although it became fully functional only by the year 2009.

ques: First general election in India on the basis of adult franchise  was held in which year?
ans_detail: Notes:The first general election in India was held in 1952 on the basis of adult franchise. This was a simultaneous election both for the Lok Sabha and all legislative assemblies of states.

ques: Which among the following statements is not correct about Plunge pool?
options: ["It is a deep depression in a stream bed at the base of a waterfall","It is created by the erosional forces of cascading water","They occur at the mature stage of the river development","They are often very deep, generally related to the height of fall and the volume of water,"]
ans: They occur at the mature stage of the river development
ans_detail: Notes:Plunge pool or waterfall lake is a deep depression in the stream bed at the base of the waterfall. It is created by the erosional force of the cascading water. They occur at the youthful stage of the river development.

ques: What are disappearing lakes found in limestone areas called?
ans_detail: Notes:Karst landforms are a type of topography formed due to dissolution of soluble rocks like limestone, dolomite and gypsum.Turlough or turlach is a type of disappearing lake found in limestone areas. The word tur in Turlough mean ‘dry’. These landforms are found in irish karst areas.

ques: Which among the following is not correct about Oasis?
options: ["They are formed in Karst landforms","They are habitats for plants and animals","They often have a date palm grove","Location of oases has been of critical importance for trade and transportation routes"]
ans: They are formed in Karst landforms
ans_detail: Notes:Oasis is a fertile area in a semi desert or a a desert environment. They provide habitats for plants and animals. The word oasis means ‘dwelling place’. They have a date palm grove. location of oases is of critical importance for trade and transportation in desert areas.

ques: What is a long narrow inlet with steep sides or cliffs created by glacial activity called?
ans_detail: Notes:A long narrow inlet with steep sides or cliffs created by glacial activity is called a Fjord. It is a glacial landform.

ques: Which among the following statements is correct about Doab?
options: ["It is a land between two converging or confluent rivers","It is a small secluded hollow","It is a small hill","It is the lowest point on a mountain ridge between two peaks"]
ans: It is a land between two converging or confluent rivers
ans_detail: Notes:Doab is a term used in South Asia for a land between two converging or confluent rivers. It is also called as Interfluve.

ques: What is a linear lowland created by a tectonic rift or a fault called?
ans_detail: Notes:Rift valley is a type of a tectonic landform. It is a linear lowland formed by a tectonic rift or fault. It is formed on a divergent plate boundary.

ques: Which among the following statements is correct about Malpais?
options: ["It is a landform of ejecta from a volcanic vent piled up in a conical shape","It is the molten lava contained in a volcanic crater","It is a rough and barren landscape of relict and largely uneroded lava fields","It is an area of land surrounded by one or more younger lava flows"]
ans: It is a rough and barren landscape of relict and largely uneroded lava fields
ans_detail: Notes:A rough and barren landscape of relict and largely uneroded lava fields is called Malpais. Malpais in Spanish means ‘badland’. It is a characteristic of an arid environment.

ques: The Chongming Island is situated in which among the following countries?
ans_detail: Notes:The Chongming Island is a river island situated on the banks of the Yangtze river in the Shanghai district of China.

ques: The Niger Delta is located on which among the following oceans?
ans_detail: Notes:The Niger delta is on the river Niger located on the Gulf of Guinea on the Atlantic Ocean. It is a densely populated delta and is sometimes called as Oil Rivers because it was a major producer of palm oil.

ques: Which among the following statements is not correct about the coastal city Rio de Janeiro?
options: ["It is known as the Marvelous city","It is Brazil’s second largest city","It is dedicated to the fallen soldiers of World War I","It is famous for the 98 feet high ‘Christ the Redeemer’."]
ans: It is dedicated to the fallen soldiers of World War I
ans_detail: Notes:The coastal city Rio de Janeiro, Brazil’s second largest city is known as Cidade Maravilhosa meaning ‘Marvelous City’. It is famous for the 98 feet high ‘Christ the Redeemer’.The Great Ocean Road is a 243 kilometres coastal route in Australia. It is dedicated to the fallen soldiers of World War I.

ques: Who got the most runs in the 2017 Women’s Cricket World Cup?
ans_detail: Notes:Tammy Beaumont got the most runs in the 2017 Women’s Cricket World Cup. The 2017 Women’s Cricket World Cup was an international women’s cricket tournament that took place in England from 24 June to 23 July 2017. It was the eleventh edition of the Women’s Cricket World Cup, and the third to be held in England, after the 1973 and 1993 tournaments. The 2017 World Cup was the first in which all participating players were fully professional. Eight teams qualified to participate in the tournament. England won the final against India at Lord’s on 23 July by 9 runs.

ques: Which country won the Gold medal in the cricket game at the 1900 Paris Olympics, which was the only appearance of cricket at the Summer Olympics?
ans_detail: Notes:Great Britain won the Gold medal in the cricket game at the 1900 Paris Olympics, which was the only appearance of cricket at the Summer Olympics. Cricket was included as an Olympic sport at the 1900 Paris Games, where Great Britain defeated France to win the gold medal. This was the only appearance of cricket at the Summer Olympics.

ques: The “Allan Border Medal” is given to the most outstanding male cricketer of which country?
ans_detail: Notes:The “Allan Border Medal” is given to the most outstanding male cricketer of Australia. Awarded during the Australian Cricket Awards, the Allan Border Medal is considered to be the most prestigious individual prize in Australian men’s cricket. First awarded in 2000, the medal is named after former Australian men’s captain Allan Border and recognises the most outstanding male Australian cricketer of the past season as voted by his peers, the media and umpires.

ques: Which book is known as the “Bible of Cricket”?
ans_detail: Notes:Wisden is known as the “Bible of Cricket”. Wisden Cricketers’ Almanack, or simply Wisden, colloquially the Bible of Cricket, is a cricket reference book published annually in the United Kingdom. The description “bible of cricket” was first used in the 1930s by Alec Waugh. In October 2013, an all-time Test World XI was announced to mark the 150th anniversary of Wisden Cricketers’ Almanack.

ques: Which of the following is the oldest Grand Slam tennis tournament?
ans_detail: Notes:Wimbledon Championship is the oldest Grand Slam tennis tournament. The Grand Slam tournaments, also called majors, are the four most important annual tennis events. The Grand Slam itinerary consists of the Australian Open in mid-January, the French Open (also known as Roland Garros) from around late May to early June, Wimbledon in June–July, and the US Open in August–September. Each tournament is played over a two-week period. The Australian and the United States tournaments are played on hard courts, the French on clay, and Wimbledon on the grass. Wimbledon is the oldest, founded in 1877, followed by the US in 1881, the French in 1891, and the Australian in 1905.

ques: Who was “Bobby Riggs”?
options: ["An American golf player","An American tennis player","An American baseball player","An American football player"]
ans_detail: Notes:Bobby Riggs was an American tennis champion who was the World No. 1 or the World co-No. 1 player for three years, first as an amateur in 1939, then as a professional in 1946 and 1947.

ques: International Tennis Hall of Fame is located in which country?
ans_detail: Notes:The United States of America houses the “International Tennis Hall of Fame”. The International Tennis Hall of Fame is located in Newport, Rhode Island, United States. It honours both players and other contributors to the sport of tennis.

ques: Which of the following are the all-time record holders for the most number of Olympic medals in tennis?
options: ["Kathleen McKane Godfree and Venus Williams","Kathleen McKane Godfree and Serena Williams","Venus Williams and Serena Williams","Gigi Fernandez and Mary Joe Fernandes"]
ans: Kathleen McKane Godfree and Venus Williams
ans_detail: Notes:Kathleen McKane Godfree and Venus Williams are the all-time record holders for the most number of Olympic medals in tennis.

ques: Who won the gold medal in women’s singles in the 2019 BWF World Championships?
ans_detail: Notes:P.V.Sindhu won the gold medal in women’s singles in the 2019 BWF World Championships. The 2019 BWF World Championships was a badminton tournament which was held from 19 to 25 August 2019 at St. Jakobshalle in Basel, Switzerland.

ques: Which sport’s competition is known as the “BWF Super Series”?
ans_detail: Notes:“BWF Super Series” is a badminton competition. The BWF Super Series was a series of Grade 2 badminton tournaments, sanctioned by Badminton World Federation (BWF). It was launched on December 14, 2006, and implemented in 2007.

ques: The artist of which painting is called Patua?
ans_detail: Notes:Bengal Patachitra is divided into a few different aspects like Durga Pata, Chalchitra, Adivasi Patachitra, Medinipur Patachitra, Kalighat Patachitra and etc. The themes of Bengal Patachitra are mostly mythological, religious stories, folk tales, and social. Kalighat Patachitra, the last tradition of Bengal Patachitra is developed by Jamini Roy. The artist of Bengal Patachitra is called Patua.

ques: Where is the word ‘Stupa’ first mentioned?
ans_detail: Notes:Stupas were built on flat land with the help of brick and stone. The first mention of ‘Stupa’ is found in the Rigveda where the rising flames of fire have been called Stupa. In the Shukla Yajurveda, it has been said to build a high mound of mud around the tomb.

ques: By which dynasty was the Khajuraho temple built?
ans_detail: Notes:Built between 950 – 1050 CE by the Chandela dynasty, the Khajuraho temples are one of the most important specimens of Indian art. It took almost a hundred years for these sets of Hindu and Jain temples to take shape. Originally a collection of 85 temples, the number has come down to 25. Khajuraho is a major city located in the Indian state of Madhya Pradesh, which is world-famous for its ancient and medieval temples. It is located in the Chhatarpur district of Madhya Pradesh. Khajuraho was also known as ‘Khajurpura’ and ‘Khajur Vahika’ in ancient times.

ques: Who built Humayun’s Tomb in Delhi?
ans_detail: Notes:Akbar built Humayun’s Tomb in Delhi. Humayun’s Tomb is located in Delhi. It is the first typical example of the Mughal style which was inspired by the Persian architectural style. Humayun’s Tomb is now one of the best-preserved Mughal monuments in Delhi.

ques: Which dance form includes the three arts of Bhavam, Ragam and Taalam?
ans_detail: Notes:Bharatanatyam or Sadhir Attam is a classical dance form mainly from South India. Bhavam, Ragam and Taalam are included in this dance form. ‘Bha’ is taken from Bhavam, ‘Ra’ from Ragam and ‘Ta’ from Talam. Hence the name Bharatanatyam has come into existence. It is based on Bharata Muni’s Natya Shastra (which dates back to 400 BC). At present, this dance form is mainly practiced by women. The inspiration for this dance form comes from the sculptures of the ancient temple of Chidambaram.

ques: Rauf is a folk dance of which state?
ans_detail: Notes:It is a famous folk dance of the Union Territory of Jammu and Kashmir, performed by the people of the Rauf tribe of Jammu and Kashmir.

ques: Which folk music is famous in Arunachal Pradesh?
ans_detail: Notes:Ja-Jin-Ja is a folk song widely sung in Arunachal Pradesh. It is mostly sung on the occasion of weddings and meetups. Both men and women participate in it, and the public also sings songs in the chorus. The song glorifies the past events of his ancestors.

ques: Who started the Goa Carnival?
ans_detail: Notes:The Portuguese launched the Goa Carnival in India. The 40 days before Lent, seem to be a time of self-control and spirituality. It includes a feast and fun activities. People wear masks and come to have fun on the streets. It reflects the rich Goan culture and culture and has a unique Portuguese influence. Goa’s streets are decorated with colorful floats and parades, live bands and dances mark the event, which regularly attracts thousands of visitors.

ques: Kuttu varisai is also known as__
options: ["One hand silambam","Thigh based silambam","Empty hand silambam","None of these"]
ans_detail: Notes:Kuttu is the unarmed combat component of Varisai Silambam and is also a stand-alone martial art. It has animal forms.

ques: Which of the following is not a strict tradition of classical Sanskrit drama?
options: ["Well-defined opening, progression and conclusion.","The hero was male.","They always had a mysterious ending.","They were generally four to seven acting plays"]
ans: They always had a mysterious ending.
ans_detail:
Notes:Ancient Sanskrit drama was bound by some strong agreements:
• It was usually four to seven games.
• He always drew happy conclusions where the hero wins or does not die.
• The main character was a man who would always achieve his goal in the end.
• The game is well described for opening, moving, developing and stopping and conclusion.

ques: Consider the following comparisons drawn between United Nation Security Council and the International Court of Justice:While the United Nation Security Council has fifteen member states, the International Court of Justice has five judgesWhile election to the UNSC is conducted only in the General Assembly, election for ICJ is held concurrently in the UNGA and UNSC Which of the above is/are correct statements?
options: ["Only 1 is correct","Only 2 is correct","Both 1 & 2 are correct","Neither 1 nor 2 is correct."]
ans_detail: Notes:First statement is incorrect  While the Security Council has 15 member states, the International Court of Justice has 15 judges. Second statement is correct While election to the UNSC is conducted only in the General Assembly, election for ICJ is held concurrently in the UNGA and UNSC. While it requires two-third majority in UNGA to get elected to non permanent seat of UNSC, it requires absolute majority of the total membership in each organ- UNGA and UNSC to be elected as judge into the International Court of Justice. While veto applies to UNSC, it does not apply for election to the ICJ.

ques: Which country has official declared Siamese fighting fish as its national aquatic animal?
ans_detail: Notes:Thailand has official declared the Siamese fighting fish as its national aquatic animal to boost conservation efforts and commercial breeding in the country. Known in the West as a betta fish, the underwater brawler is popular in home aquariums for its iridescent body and many-hued tail. It brings up feelings of nostalgia for older generations in Thailand – which changed its name from Siam in 1939. They remember a time when the fish were traded and sparred in childhood games. The Siamese fighting fish is listed as Vulnerable by the IUCN. Thailand’s official national animal is the elephant.

ques: Rare Kakapo parrots, sometimes seen in news, are found in which of the following countries?
ans_detail: Notes:The critically endangered ‘Kakapos’ – the world’s fattest species of parrot – have enjoyed a record breaking breeding season, according to New Zealand’s Department of Conservation (DOC). This year, 76 chicks have been hatched under the DOC’s conservation scheme, with 60 expected to reach adulthood. This will significantly boost the population which has grown to 147 adults since a small number of the plump green, yellow and black birds were discovered in 1970. The kakapo is an “unusual” parrot as the females control the breeding process and only mate every two to four years when their favourite fruit grows in New Zealand’s Rimu trees – the period is known as a “mast year”. New Zealand’s kakapo recovery programme is so tightly monitored that although they remain in the wild, each one has a radio transmitter attached to its body and there are monitoring systems embedded in their nests. It is claimed that kakapo is probably one of the most intensively managed species in the world.

ques: ‘Sea Tinkle’ in Chennai beach , which is in news recently, is caused by which algae?
ans_detail: Notes:On 18th August 2019, visitors to the Injambakkam beach in Chennai and Besant Nagar’s Eliot’s Beach noticed a blue shimmer on the waves i.e. Popularly known as ‘Sea Tinkle’. According to marine experts, the Noctiluca algae were behind this blue glow phenomenon. The algae exhibit the phenomenon of bioluminescence (or biologically produce light when disturbed). The light is produced by a chemical reaction in the presence of oxygen involving an enzyme called “luciferase”. Bioluminescence has been observed in fireflies, a few beetles and in marine creatures such as Anglerfish and copepods. Though the sight that algae produce is beautiful, their arrival may not be good news for marine health. Noctiluca are known to be voracious predators of planktonic organisms(diatoms) that leads to disruption of the marine food chain. Such blooms have been reported annually in the Northern Arabian Sea since the early 2000s. Goa, Mumbai and the backwaters of Kerala have witnessed these algal blooms. Recently the magical glow featured in the Malayalam movie Kumbalangi Nights, which gained much attention.

ques: Ramsar convention is related to which of the following-
options: ["Limiting the desertification","Conservation of wetlands","Conservation of Snow Leopard","Conservation of Tigers"]
ans_detail: Notes:Ramsar convention signed in 1971 in Ramsar, Iran is related to the wise use and conservation of notified wetlands. From India there are 38 wetland sites recognized in the convention.

ques: In which of the following type of biotic interaction one species benefits and the other is harmed?
ans_detail: Notes:In predation and parasitism one species benefits whereas the other is harmed. Some examples of predator and prey are lion and zebra, bear and fish, and fox and rabbit.

ques: Which of the following are the characteristics of wetland ecosystem?1
ans_detail: Notes:Wetland ecosystems are covered by water or has waterlogged soil for atleast seven days during the growing season. The plants have adopted to the waterlogged conditions. The soils are hydric therefore not enough O2 is available for some plants.

ques: Which of the following is the smallest of all living rhinos and the only rhino in Asia to sport two horns?
options: ["Indian Rhino","Sumatran Rhino","White Rhino","None of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:The smallest of all living rhinos and the only rhino in Asia to sport two horns is the Sumatran Rhino. Its IUCN status is critically endangered and its scientific name is “Dicerorhinus sumatrensis”.

ques: Which of the following statements are correct about Ecuadorian white-fronted capuchin?1
ans_detail: Notes:Ecuadorian white-fronted capuchin is a species of gracile capuchin monkey of the family Cebidae. It resides in tropical forests in Ecuador and Peru. It is listed critically endangered in IUCN Red List.

ques: What is the IUCN status of Liben lark?
ans_detail: Notes:The scientific name of Liben lark is Heteromirafa sidamoensis. It is a species of lark which belongs to the family Alaudidae. The IUCN status of Liben lark is Critically Endangered. It is threatened by habitat loss.

ques: Which transgenic tomato variety has a better shelf life?
ans_detail: Notes:Flavr savr is a transgenic tomato variety that has a better shelf life and was the first GM food crop to be used commercially.

ques:
Hydrochloric acid is secreted by the cells lining the
____:
ans_detail: Notes:The chief cells of the stomach secrete enzymes for protein breakdown (inactive pepsinogen and rennin). Hydrochloric acid activates pepsinogen into the enzyme pepsin, which then helps digestion by breaking the bonds linking amino acids, a process known as proteolysis.

ques: Which of the following diseases has been eradicated worldwide?
ans_detail: Notes:Smallpox was one of the world’s most devastating diseases known to humanity. The last known natural case was in Somalia in 1977. It was declared eradicated in 1980 following a global immunization campaign led by the World Health Organization. Smallpox is caused by infection with the variola virus.

ques: Which of the following micro-organism causes diseases like polio and chicken pox?
ans_detail: Notes:Both polio and chicken pox are caused by virus. Poliomyelitis, often called polio or infantile paralysis, is an infectious disease caused by the poliovirus; while, Chickenpox, also known as varicella, is a highly contagious disease caused by the initial infection with varicella zoster virus (VZV).

ques:
In a poultry unit, the factor most influencing the cost is the cost of
____:
ans_detail: Notes:Feed cost is one of the important variable costs that plays a big role in determining the poultry cost. Variable costs rise and fall with the size of the output and the level of the operation. Fixed costs (for items such as taxes, insurance, interest, and depreciation on buildings and equipment), are incurred whether or not there is any output. Moreover the feed of broilers and layers varies with time of their growth.

ques: The narrowest and most numerous tubes of lungs are termed as ____:
ans_detail: Notes:The respiratory bronchioles are the narrowest airways of the lungs, one fiftieth of an inch across. The bronchi divide many times before evolving into the bronchioles. The bronchioles deliver air to the exchange surfaces of the lungs.

ques: Which type of pathogen causes the water-borne disease Ascariasis?
ans_detail: Notes:Ascariasis is a disease caused by the parasitic roundworm Ascaris lumbricoides. Infection occurs by eating food or drink contaminated with Ascaris eggs from feces. Ascariasis is most common in places without modern sanitation.

ques: Smooth muscles are likely to be found in ____:
ans_detail: Notes:The term smooth muscle refers to a muscle of the human body that is part of a involuntary muscle group. The walls of hollow organs are the primary place that smooth muscles can be found. Some of those locations include: Walls of blood vessels, walls of stomach, intestines, large (aorta) and small arteries and veins, urinary bladder, uterus, male and female reproductive tracts, respiratory tract, etc.

Who among the following has built the Vijay Stambha (Tower of Victory) in Chittorgarh?
ans_detail: Notes:The Vijaya Stambha is an imposing victory monument located within Chittor Fort in Chittorgarh, Rajasthan, India. The tower was constructed by the Mewar king, Rana Kumbha, in 1448 to commemorate his victory over the combined armies of Malwa and Gujarat led by Mahmud Khilji.

ques: Ghiyasuddin Muhammad wrote which of the following sheds light on many aspects of the social and cultural life of the age?
ans_detail: Notes:Qunum-i-Humayuni was written by Khwand Mir, also known as Ghiyasuddin Muhammad. It is an account of rules and ordinances established by emperor Humayun and of some building erected by him.

ques: Which of the following is an account of the life and reign of Sher Shah between 1539 and 1545?
ans_detail: Notes:Tarikh-i-Sher Shahi was written by Abbas Khan Sarwani. He was a descendant of an Afghan noble, in the service of Sultan Sher Shah. Abbas Khan Sarwani himself was in the service of emperor Akbar. It talks of the reign of Sher Shah and his successors.

ques: Abul Fazl, the author if Akbarnama, started his time in the Mughal empire as?
ans_detail: Notes:Abul fazl was introduced to Akbar towards the close of 1574 and was enlisted as a Mansabdar. In 1589, at the instance of Akbar, Abul Fazal started the writing of Akbarnama which is the most detailed history of the reign of Akbar. Akbarnama was initially completed in 1596, but its account was later continued up to 1601.

ques: Which of the following is not another name for Jahangir’s autobiographical account Tuzuk-i-Jahangiri?
ans_detail: Notes:Ibadat-i-Jahangiri is not a name for Jahangir’s autobiographical work. However, it is known by many names such as Tarikh-i-Salim Shahi, Kmatama-i-Jahangiri, Waqiat-i-Jahangiri, Dayaz-i-Jahangiri, Iqbalnama, Jahhangirinama, and Maqalat-i-Jahangiri. The version of the memoirs which has been accepted as authentic was written by Jahangir himself and it covers his reign.

ques: Who among the following was the most reputed historian of the reign of Shah Jahan?
ans_detail: Notes: Abul Hamid Lahori, the most reputed historian of the reign of Shah Jahan, wrote the detailed account of Shah Jahan from his childhood to November 1649. Abdul Hamid Lahori’s Padshahnama is a first-rate authority on the reign of Shah Jahan.

ques: Motif of which goddess was inscribed on Rajput kings’ coins?
ans_detail: Notes:Coins issued by most of the Rajput kings of medieval India were same in pattern i.e. included the name of the Ruler on one side and the picture of Goddess Laxmi on the other side. The text of the coins was written in Devnagiri script.

ques: Which Mughal King’s coin depicted Swastika?
ans_detail: Notes:Like his ideology, coins of Akbar also reflect secularism. The Hindu symbol of Swastika appears on many of his coins along with the “Kalima” (Islamic affirmation of faith). He also issued gold half mohurs with depictions of Rama and Sita on them. Some silver coins also had the words “Rama” and “Gobind” on them.

ques: Which Delhi Sultan assumed title Amir al-Mu’minin?
ans_detail:
Notes:In 1229, Iltutmish got recognition as the Muslim sultan of India by the Caliph of Baghdad. Hereafter, he assumed the title of Amir al-Mu’minin
or commander of the faithful and had the name of Caliph inscribed on his coins.

ques: Which of the following are the two main historiographical traditions that developed during Medieval period?1) Arabs2) PersiansSelect the correct option from the codes given below:
ans_detail: Notes:The two main historiographical traditions that developed during the medieval period were those of the Arabs and the Persians. The Arabs laid emphasis on the entirety of human society, while the Persians highlighted the feats of kings and courtiers.

ques: Which of the following antiseptic compounds is present in Dettol?
ans_detail: Notes: Chloroxylenol, also known as para-chloro-meta-xylenol, is an antiseptic and disinfectant which is used for skin disinfection and cleaning surgical instruments. It is also used within a number of household disinfectants and wound cleaners.

ques: What is the PH of the human blood?
ans_detail: Notes:The pH scale, ranges from 0 (strongly acidic) to 14 (strongly basic or alkaline). Blood is normally slightly basic, with a normal pH range of 7.35 to 7.45. Usually the body maintains the pH of blood close to 7.40.

ques: Who is the author of the book “The Sceptical Chymist” that made distinction between chemistry and alchemy and marked beginning of modern Chemistry?
ans_detail: Notes:Robert Boyle is generally considered the first modern chemist and one of the founders of modern chemical science. He also pioneered the scientific method. He developed Boyle’s Law which states that, under a closed system with constant pressure, the pressure and volume of a gas are inversely proportional. In 1661, Robert Boyle had published The Sceptical Chymist, a treatise on the distinction between chemistry and alchemy. It contains some of the earliest modern ideas of atoms, molecules, and chemical reaction, and marks the beginning of the history of modern chemistry.

ques: People suffering from acidity are given antacid tablets with most commonly which of the following salts?
ans_detail: Notes:People suffering from acidity are given antacid tablets, containing magnesium hydroxide which neutralizes excess HCl produced in stomach.

ques: Which of the following is / are products of the electrolysis of brine solution?HydrogenChlorineSodium hydroxide Select the correct option from the codes given below:
ans_detail: Notes:The process is known as chlor-alkali process. It is names so because the products formed chlor- for chlorine and alkali for sodium hydroxide. In this process, chlorine is given off at anode, hydrogen gas at the cathode and sodium hydroxide solution is formed near the cathode. The three products formed in this process are all useful.

ans: Gastric Juice < Citric Juice < Pure Water < Milk Of Magnesia
ans_detail: Notes:

ques: Which of the following metals form an amalgam with other metals?
ans_detail: Notes:An amalgam is a substance formed by the reaction of mercury with another metal. Almost all metals can form amalgams with mercury, a notable exception being iron. Silver-mercury amalgams are important in dentistry, and gold-mercury amalgam is used in the extraction of gold from ore. Dentistry has used alloys of mercury with metals such as silver, copper, indium, tin and zinc. Amalgam is an “excellent and versatile restorative material” and is used in dentistry for a number of reasons.

ques: The orientation of an atomic orbital is governed by:
options: ["principal quantum number","magnetic quantum number","spin quantum number","azimuthal quantum number"]
ans_detail: Notes:Quantum numbers may be defined as a set of four numbers which give complete information about the electron in an atom, i.e., energy, orbital occupied, size, shape and orientation of that orbital and the direction of electron spin. Magnetic quantum number is required to explain the fact that when the source giving the line spectrum is placed in a magnetic field, each spectral line splits in to a number of lines. The magnetic quantum number tells the number of orientations which the orbitals present within the same sub-shell can take up.

ques: What is the mass of 4 mole of aluminium atoms?
ans_detail: Notes:Mass of 4 moles of aluminium atoms = 4 × molecular mass of aluminum atoms in grams = 4 × 27 = 108

ques: Which is one of the most important technique for the separation of a mixture by passing it in solution or suspension through a medium in which the components move at different rates?
ans_detail: Notes:Chromatography is the separation of a mixture by passing it in solution or suspension or as a vapor (as in gas chromatography) through a medium in which the components move at different rates. Thin-layer chromatography is a special type of chromatography used for separating and identifying mixtures that are or can be colored, especially pigments.

ques: What is the full form of RISE?
options: ["Revitalising Indian Systems of Education","Revitalising Infrastructure and Systems in Education","Revitalising Infrastructure and schools in Education","Reconstruction Indian School Education"]
ans: Revitalising Infrastructure and Systems in Education

ques: Which among the following regions is/are practically without railways?Inner AustraliaWestern EuropeCentral AsiaNorthern north AmericaSelect the correct code from the options given below:
ans_detail: Notes:The tropical regions generally have fewer rail routes and the equator is crossed by less than a dozen rail tracks. Most of South America, Africa, northern Asia, Central Asia, inner Australia and northern North America are practically without railways. Western European region has the highest density of rail network.

ques: What is the percentage spending of Higher Educational Institutions on R&D out of the total R&D Expenditure?
ans_detail: Notes:The spending of Higher Educational Institutions on R&D is 6.8%. The state spending on R&D is 6.4% and the central government is 45.4%.

ques: What is  India’s growth rate in scientific publication in the world?
ans_detail: Notes:India’s growth rate of scientific publication as per the Science Citation Index is a citation index is 6.4%. The world average is 3.7% .

ques: Which of the following is known as broad money?1
options: ["1,2 and 3 only","1 and 3 only","2 and 4 only","2 and 3 only"]
ans_detail: Notes:The Monetary Aggregates or Money Stock Measures calculated money supply in the country. These monetary aggregates are: M1 (aka Narrow Money; M2, M3 (aka Broad Money) and M4.

ques: With regards to Public Private Partnership, what does A stand for in, MCA?
ans_detail: Notes:MCA stands for Model Concession Agreement. Model Concession Agreement is the basic element of a Public Private Partnership. It establishes the regulatory framework for various infrastructure projects based on international standards.

ques: Which of the following statements are correct?1
ans_detail: Notes:Currency notes and coins are called fiat money. They don’t have intrinsic value like gold or silver coin. The currency-deposit ratio measures the relationship between the cash people have on hand and what they have in their accounts.

ques: Which among the following is the first corporatized major port in India?
ans_detail: Notes:Ennore is the first corporatized major port in India.

ques: Which city is the largest coal-producing city in India?
ans_detail: Notes:Dhanbad has some of the largest coal mines in India and is called the Coal Capital of India. The city is surrounded by ~112 coal mines with a total production of 27.5 million tonnes.

ques: Which of the following non-metals is used to make antiseptic?
ans_detail: Notes: Tincture of iodine is used as an antiseptic. Tincture of iodine is a purple coloured solution which is applied on cuts and wounds as an antiseptic.

ques: Which of the following animals doesn’t lay eggs?
ans_detail: Notes: Birds and fish are not the only animals that lay eggs. Insects, turtles, lizards, and reptiles lay eggs, too. Only two mammals lay eggs. the platypus and the echidna. All other mammals give birth to live babies.

ques: Which of the following is the primary function of the stem in plants?
options: ["Support leaves","Deliver water to leaves","Transport useful products","All of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes: The primary functions of the stem are to support the leaves, to conduct water and minerals to the leaves, where they can be converted into usable products by photosynthesis, and to transport these products from the leaves to other parts of the plant, including the roots.

ques: Xylem helps in transportation of which of the following?
ans_detail: Notes:Xylem is a type of tissue in vascular plants that transports water and some nutrients from the roots to the leaves. Water is passively transported into the roots and then into the xylem. The forces of cohesion and adhesion cause the water molecules to form a column in the xylem.

ques: Which of the following disease is caused by female Anopheles mosquito?
ans_detail: Notes:Certain species of mosquitoes of the Anopheles genus and only females of those species can transmit malaria. Malaria is caused by a one-celled parasite called a Plasmodium. Malaria parasites multiply rapidly in the liver and then in red blood cells of the infected person.

ques: Which part of the plant gives us saffron?
ans_detail: Notes:The dried stigmas (thread-like parts of the flower) are used to make saffron spice. It can take 75,000 saffron blossoms to produce a single pound of saffron spice. Saffron is largely cultivated and harvested by hand.

ques: Which of the following isotope of Hydrogen has only one neutron?
ans_detail: Notes:99.985% of hydrogen atoms contain only one proton. This isotope is called protium( 1H1). Rest of the percentage of hydrogen atom contains two other isotopes, the one containing 1 proton and 1 neutron is called deuterium (1D2, 0.015%) and the other one possessing 1 proton and 2 neutrons is called tritium (1T3 ). The latter isotope is found in trace amounts on the earth.

ques: Which one amongst the following is not a GreenHouse gas?
ans_detail: Notes:A greenhouse gas (sometimes abbreviated GHG) is a gas in an atmosphere that absorbs and emits radiation within the thermal infrared range. The primary greenhouse gases in the Earth’s atmosphere are water vapour, carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, and ozone. Nitrous oxide (N2O) gas should not be confused with nitric oxide (NO) or nitrogen dioxide (NO2). Neither nitric oxide nor nitrogen dioxide is greenhouse gases, although they are important in the process of creation of tropospheric ozone which is a greenhouse gas.  There are several sources of nitrous oxide, both natural and anthropogenic (human), to the atmosphere with many of these sources difficult to measure. Because of this, there is general agreement that the atmospheric sources and sinks of nitrous oxide are difficult to bring into balance.

ques: Which branch of biology is known for the study of plant fossils?
ans_detail: Notes:Paleobotany is the scientific study of ancient plants using plant fossils found in sedimentary rocks.

ques: Which of the following is studied in Ethnobotany?
options: ["Practical use of plants by local culture and people","Relations between Plants and peoples Behvaior","Comparison of different plants in a particular area","Study of relations of plants, animals and animals in an area"]
ans: Practical use of plants by local culture and people
ans_detail: Notes:Ethnobotany is the study of the plants of an area and their practical uses through the traditional knowledge of a local culture and people.

ques: Which of the following crude oil transportation pipeline is the longest in India?
ans_detail: Notes:The Hajira-Bijaipur-Jagdishpur crude oil transportation pipeline is the longest in India. It has a total length of 1750 kilometers. It was set up by the Gas Authority of India. It connects Kawas (Gujarat) to Jagadishpur (Uttar Pradesh) via Anta (Rajasthan), Bijaipur (Madhya Pradesh).

ques: Damodar Valley Corporation was founded in which year?
ans_detail: Notes:Damodar Valley Corporation (DVC) was founded in the year 1948. The headquarter of DVC is located in Kolkata, West Bengal.

ques: Dool Hasti project is situated across which of the following river?
ans_detail: Notes:The Dool Hasti project is situated across the Chenab river in the state of Jammu & Kashmir. In the year 1986, it was commissioned.

ques: The Atomic Energy Institution at Trombay was established in which year?
ans_detail: Notes:The Atomic Energy Institution at Trombay was established in the year 1954. In the year 1967, it was renamed as Bhaba Atomic Research Centre (BARC).

ques: Which of the following does not come under the renewable natural resource?
ans_detail: Notes:Salt, or sodium chloride, is considered a non-renewable resource as the timescale for self-replenishing is too long.

ques: Which of the following characteristics are correct about plantation agriculture?1
ans_detail: Notes:In plantation agriculture generally, a single crop is grown on a large area in plantation agriculture like the monoculture. It has an interface of agriculture and industry. It uses capital intensive inputs

ques: Surface water resources are highest in which of the following places?
ans_detail: Notes:Surface water resources are highest in the Ganga plains.

ques: Due to which of the following reason(s), Gujarat is the leading producer of Salt in India?1
ans_detail: Notes:Gujarat is the leading producer of Salt in India because of the long length of the coastline, the long duration of hot and dry conditions and the presence of gulf areas.

ques: Which among the following matches of steel plants and their foreign cooperation countries are correct?1
ans_detail: Notes:The correct matches are Bhilai Iron and Steel Plant- Russia, Raurkela Iron and Steel Plant- Germany, Bokaro Iron and Steel Plant- Russia, Durgapur Iron and Steel Plant- United Kingdom.

ques: Which among the following is the largest aluminium plant of India?
ans_detail: Notes:The largest aluminium plant of India is the National Aluminium Company Ltd. (NALCO). It was established in the year 1981 in the state of Odisha. It receives bauxite from the Panchpatmali mines.

ques: Gopal Krishna Gokhale served as the president of the Indian National Congress in which of the following session of the Indian National Congress?
ans_detail: Notes: In the Benaras session of INC in the year 1905, Gopal Krishna Gokhale served as the president.

ques: Who among the following divided the revenues from all sources into three categories in the time of Lord Ripon?
ans_detail: Notes:Lord Crome divided the revenues from all sources into three categories i.e, Imperial, Divided and Provincial.

ques: The first Municipal Corporation was set up in which of the following places in India?
ans_detail: Notes:In the year the first Municipal Corporation was set up in Madras. And in the year 1726, the Municipal Corporation of Calcutta and Bombay was set up.

ques: Who among the following were associated with the foundation of the Hindu college?1
ans_detail: Notes:Hindu College was founded in the year 1817. The personalities who were associated with its foundation are Raja Rammohan Roy, David Hare, Raja Radhakanta Deb, Rasamay Dutt, Rani Rashmoni, Sir Edward Hyde East, Baidyanath Mukhopadhya.

ques: Tattobodhini Sabha was founded in which year?
ans_detail: Notes:Tattobodhini Sabha was founded on 6th October 1839. Debendranath Tagore was the founder of Tattobodhini Sabha. The name of its organ was Tattobodhini Patrika (Bengali language).

ques: Which among the following about Henry Louis Vivian Derozio are correct?1
ans_detail: Notes:Henry Louis Vivian Derozio was born in the year 1809. He was a professor of Hindu college from 1827 to 1831. In the year 1831, he was expelled from Hindu college for his radicalism. He started the Young Bengal Movement. He founded the Academic Association in the year 1827.

ques: Which among the following about the Paramhansa Mandali are correct?1
ans_detail: Notes:Paramhansa Mandali was founded in 1849 in Maharashtra. The members of the organization believed in One god. They supported window remarriage. The member of the organization used to take food prepared by lower caste people.

ques: Who among the following was/ were associated with the foundation of the Congress Socialist Party?1
ans_detail: Notes:In the year 1934, the Congress Socialist Party was founded by Jai Prakash Narayan, Acharya Narendra Deva, Ram Manohar Lohia. The party was dissolved in 1948.

ques: Which of the following attempted to control the sovereign power of Punjab?1) Abdus Samad Khan2) Zakariya KhanSelect the correct option from the codes given below:
ans_detail: Notes:When Sikh groups started consolidating themselves as a political force, these activities raised the alarm for the Mughal governors of the Lahore subah. Abdus Samad Khan and Zakariya Khan attempted to control the sovereign power of Punjab.

ques: Which one of the following is connected with the ‘Blue Water policy’?
ans_detail: Notes:Francisco de Almeida who was also the first Portuguese viceroy of India introduced the Blue water policy. His was to be powerful in the sea instead of building forts. He wanted to make Portugal a powerful country in water.

ques: The manufacture of iron from iron ore involves the process of:
ans_detail: Notes:The manufacture of iron ore involves the process of reduction. Important ores of iron : Haematite, Magnetite.

ques: Which of the following is very reactive and kept in kerosene?
ans_detail: Notes:Sodium is a very reactive metal. It reacts vigorously both with oxygen and water. A lot of heat is generated in this process. Therefore, it is stored in kerosene to avoid contacts between both atmospheric oxygen and water.

ques: Catalytic converters are generally made from:
ans_detail: Notes:Transition metals are used directly as catalysts in the anti–pollution catalytic converters in car exhausts. For example, expensive transition metals such as Platinum and rhodium are used in the catalytic converters in car exhausts to reduce the emission of carbon monoxide and nitrogen monoxide, which are converted to the non–polluting gases nitrogen and carbon dioxide.2NO (g) + 2CO(g) —> N2 (g) + 2CO2 (g)

ques: Which of the following is not a gaseous air pollutant?
ans_detail: Notes:The gaseous air pollutants of primary concern in urban settings include oxides of carbon, sulphur and nitrogen such as sulfur dioxide, nitrogen dioxide, and carbon monoxide; these are emitted directly into the air from the combustion of fossil fuels.Smoke, a collection of airborne solid and liquid particulates and gases emitted when a material undergoes combustion, is also a pollutant. Hydrocarbon is an organic compound consisting entirely of hydrogen and carbon. On combustion, it produces carbon dioxide and water only.

ques: Brass is an alloy of which of the following metals?
options: ["Copper and mercury","Copper and zinc","Copper and nickel","Copper and silver"]
ans_detail: Notes:Brass is a metallic alloy that is made of copper and zinc. Brass is used for decoration for its bright gold-like appearance; for applications where low friction is required such as locks, gears, bearings, doorknobs, ammunition casings and valves; for plumbing and electrical applications; and extensively in brass musical instruments such as horns and bells.

ques: Which of the following is not a noble gas?
ans_detail: Notes:Noble gas, any of the seven chemical elements that make up Group 18 (VIIIa) of the periodic table.The elements are helium (He), neon (Ne), argon (Ar), krypton (Kr), xenon (Xe), radon (Rn), and oganesson (Og).The noble gases are colourless, odourless, tasteless, nonflammable gases.

ques: Acid rain is caused due to pollution of atmosphere by:
options: ["oxides of carbon and nitrogen","oxides of nitrogen and sulphur","oxides of nitrogen and phosphorous","none of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:The water soluble oxides of sulphuric and nitrogen are responsible for acid rain. These oxides dissolve in water vapour forming nitrous acid, sulphurous acids, etc.

ques: Which of the following is not a chemical reaction’?
options: ["Burning of paper","Digestion ot of food","Conversion of water into steam","Burning of coal"]
ans_detail: Notes:The conversion of water into steam is an example of a physical change, where the state of the matter changes without changing its composition. A physical change involves a change in physical properties. Examples of physical properties include melting, transition to a gas, change of strength, change of durability, changes to crystal form, textural change, shape, size, color, volume and density.

ques: The Chemical formula of Acetic acid is:
ans_detail: Notes:Acetic acid, systematically named ethanoic acid, is a colorless liquid organic compound with the chemical formula CH3COOH. It is the second simplest carboxylic acid after formic acid. Vinegar is roughly 3-9% acetic acid by volume, making acetic acid the main component of vinegar apart from water.

ques: What is the chemical name of the deadly posion ‘cyanide’?
ans_detail: Notes:The salts of hydrogen cyanide (Chemical name of Prussic acid) are known as cyanides.It is a colorless, extremely poisonous and flammable liquid that boils slightly above room tempe-rature, at 25.6°C. It is pro-duced on an industrial scale and is a highly valuable pre-cursor to many chemical com-pounds ranging from polymers to pharmaceuticals.

ques: What is the force that is required to produce unit elongation in a wire known as?
ans_detail: Notes:Force constant of material of wire is the force required to produce unit elongation in a wire. It is denoted by k. K = F/l or K = YA/l

ques: What do we call the strain produced in a body when the deforming force produces a change in its shape without changing its volume?
ans_detail: Notes:When the deforming force produces a change in the shape of the body without changing its volume, the strain produced is called shearing strain.

ques: In which form is the work done in stretching a wire stored as?
ans_detail: Notes:In stretching a wire work is done against internal restoring forces. This work is stored in the wire as elastic potential energy. It is also known as strain energy

ques: Which of the following equation represents the Torricelli’s law?
ans_detail: Notes:Torricelli’s theorem is also called as Torricelli’s law, It states that the speed, v, of a liquid flowing under the force of gravity out of an opening in a tank is proportional jointly to the square root of the vertical distance, h, between the liquid surface and the centre of the opening and to the square root of double the acceleration due to gravity. V = (2gh)1/2

ques: What is the S
ans_detail: Notes:The SI unit of pressure is N/m2 It has been named as Pascal (Pa) in honour of the French scientist Blaise Pascal for carrying out pioneering studies on fluid pressure. Its dimensions are M L-1T -2

ques: Which of the following is equal to the upthrust of the body?
options: ["mass of body","weight of liquid","weight of liquid displaced","density of liquid"]
ans_detail: Notes:Archimedes Principle: when a body is immersed partially or completely in a liquid, it experiences an upthrust, which is equal to the weight of the liquid displaced by the body.

ques: What is the main cause of capillarity?
options: ["difference in weight of fluids","pressure difference","temperature difference","velocity gradient"]
ans_detail: Notes:The main cause of capillarity is the difference in pressures on two sides of (concave and convex) curved surface of liquid.

ques: Which of the following represents Kinematic viscosity?
ans_detail: Notes:Kinematic viscosity is defined mathematically as the ratio of the viscosity of a fluid to its density. It is the measure of the resistive flow of a fluid under the influence of gravity.

ques: When are the two particles said to be in same phase?
options: ["if the phase difference between them is an even multiple of π","if the path difference is an even multiple of (λ / 2)","if the time interval is an even multiple of (T/ 2)","All of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:Two vibrating particle are said to be in same phase, if the phase difference between them is an even multiple of π or path difference is an even multiple of (λ / 2) or time interval is an even multiple of (T/ 2).

ques: What is second’s pendulum?
options: ["simple pendulum whose time period of vibrations is one second","simple pendulum whose time period of vibrations is two seconds","simple pendulum whose time period of vibrations is four seconds","simple pendulum whose time period of vibrations is ten seconds"]
ans: simple pendulum whose time period of vibrations is two seconds
ans_detail: Notes:A second’s pendulum is that simple pendulum whose time period of vibrations is two seconds.

ques: Inbuan wrestling is the original martial art of which of the following?
ans_detail: Notes:Indian wrestling is a wrestling match that began in 1750 in Mizoram, India. According to some sources it is also believed that it originated in Burma and later reached Mizoram but there is no guarantee of this. It has very strict rules that prevent you from stepping out. Goal, kick and kneel. How to overcome this by getting those who oppose it to stand on their own feet, strictly following the rules. And this includes the wearing of belts (worn around their waists) by athletes.

ques: What is meant by Lokadharmi?
options: ["Depiction of love stories","depiction of old age","realistic depiction of daily lives","narrative plays of morality"]
ans_detail: Notes:Lokadharmi is the branch of technical practice that forms a play — a play based on natural behavior and not on simple and artificial and its plot on the occupations and activities of individuals and on simple acting. And there is no playful flowering of the limbs and, depending on the type of male and female, it is called Lokadharmi (folklore).

ques: What is the chief form of Bhuta Aradhana?
ans_detail: Notes:Bhoot, meaning soul, is a traditional form of worship for the dead ancestors are predominant in coastal Karnataka. Kol is the main form of Bhuta Aradhana Worship is a ritual theatre.

ques: Kabuki a regional theatre of Japan is similar to which Indian folk theatre?
ans_detail:
Notes:Kabuki, a regional theatre in Japan, is similar to Yakshagana in its structure and performance. The famous districts of Yakshagana in Karnataka are Dakshina Kannada, Udupi, Uttara Kannada, Shimoga West, and Chikmagalur districts.
It is also famous in the Kasaragod district of Kerala. This theatrical form combines dance, music, dialogue, costumes, makeup and theatrical techniques to create a unique style and look. Yakshagana is also known as “Atta” or Asana. The’Badagu Tittu’ is a popular form of Yakshagana in the Thulanadu region. It is based on myths and legends.

ques: Who is the founder of The Hindu?
options: ["G Subramanian Iyer","VD Savarkar","Gopal Krishna Gokhale","MG Ranade"]
ans_detail: Notes:The Hindu Weekly was founded on 20 September 1878 in Madras by G. Subramanian Iyer. The Hindu is the English language Indian daily newspaper owned by The Hindu Group, headquartered in Chennai, Tamil Nadu. It started as a weekly in 1878 and became a daily in 1889. It is one of the Indian newspapers and the second most widely circulated English language newspaper in India after The Times of India. As of March 2018, The Hindu has been published in 21 locations in 11 states in India.

ques: Samvad Kaumudi was started by?
options: ["Madhusudan Ray","Raja Ram Mohan Roy","Dadabhai Nauroji","Devendranath Tagore"]
ans_detail: Notes:It was a Bengali weekly newspaper published in Kolkata in the first half of the 19th century by Ram Mohan Roy. It was a well-known pro-Reformist book that campaigned for the abolition (standing) of Sati Pratha.

ques: Which of the following factors may bring changes in the marriage system?
ans_detail: Notes:Modern education has shaken the traditional core concept of the marriage system in India. However, it broke the barriers of caste and allowed inter-caste marriages which sustain the reliability of our laws and constitution. Thus, modern education brings change to the marriage system.

ques: Which of the following is a very popular sweet in Eastern India’s Bihar, Odisha, and West Bengal?
ans_detail: Notes:Khaja is a type of dish which is mainly made from maida, sugar, ghee, or dalda. It is very popular in Eastern India’s Bihar, Odisha, and West Bengal. All these regions were once part of the Maurya Empire. It is said that even two thousand years ago, Khaja was made in the fertile areas of these regions.

ques: Rignai is the traditional dress of women of __
ans_detail: Notes:Rignai is the traditional dress of Tripuri women native to Tripura. It is a garment worn around the waist. It is worn with “rikutu”. It covers the upper half of the body. It is worn by every Tripuri woman in Tripura.

ques: Panchi and Parhan are the famous fabrics of __
ans_detail: Notes:Panchi and Parhan are the famous fabrics of Jharkhand. Panchi and Parhan is the traditional dress of the women of Jharkhand. The lower garment is panchi and the upper one, is the parahan. Jharkhand popularly known as Vanchal (Land of the Forest) is cultured with a dynamic heritage of textiles and clothing.

Who was the first member of the Sharqi dynasty to assume the royal title?
options: ["Malik Sarwar","Mubarak Shah","Ibrahim Shah","None of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:Feroz Shah Tughlaq appointed Malik Sarwar the governor of the Jaunpur region in 1388. To put an end to the unrest in the Sultanate, Malik Sarwar and his adopted son, Mubarak Shah, founded the Sharqi dynasty. After the death of Malik Sarwar in 1399, his adopted son Malik Qaranphul succeeded him and assumed the title of Mubarak Shah. He was the first member of the Sharqi dynasty to assume royal title, to strike coins and read khutba in his name.

ques: Which of the following rulers founded the city of Ahmedabad?
ans_detail: Notes:Ahmad Shah was a very ambitious ruler. With energy and power of organization, he first reorganized the administrative system of the kingdom, then he built the modern city of Ahmedabad on the site of the old town of Aswal and made it his capital.

ques: Which of the following laid the foundations of the Saluva dynasty?
options: ["Saluva Narasimha","Saluva Gunda","Narasa Nayaka","None of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:Saluva Narasimha laid the fondation of Saluva dynasty.  Saluva Narasimha was the eldest son o Saluva Gunda. Saluva Gauda was the chief of Chandragiri of the Chittoor district.

ques: Saluva Narasimha was imprisoned in 1490 CE by which of the following?
options: ["King of Chittor","King of Orissa","King of Awadh","None of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:Saluva Narasimha sieged Udayagiri however soon after the siege he was imprisoned in 1490 CE by the king of Orissa and he died shortly afterwards a year later. Saluva Narasimha initiated the process of centralization once again during his reign.

ques: Which of the following kinds of coins were in use during the rule of the Vijayanagar kingdom?1) Varaha 2) Dinara3) FanamSelect the correct option from the codes given below:
ans_detail: Notes:Abdur Razzak, the Ambassador from Iran who visited the Indian subcontinent during the rule of Deva Raya II states that in Vijayanagar, three kinds of coins were in use-Varaha, Dinara and Fanam. Of these, the Fanam was most popular.

ques: Which of the following was called the Prime minister during the administration of the Bahamani kingdom?
ans_detail: Notes:The administration of the Bahamani kingdom which ruled the Deccan from 1347 CE to 1527 CE was well-organized. Wazir-i-kul was the term used for the prime minister during the rule of the Bahamani kingdom.

ques: Which of the following statements are correct about Sufism?1
ans_detail: Notes:Sufism represents the inward or esoteric, mystical side of Islam. Sufis believed that God is Mashuq and Sufis are the Ashiqs and they regarded God as the supreme beauty, and believed that one must admire him.

ques: The Chisti presence in Delhi was established by which of the following saints?
options: ["Qutbuddin Bakhtiyar Kaki","Sultan Muhammad Tughlaq","Khwaja Muinuddin Chishti","Iltutmish"]
ans_detail: Notes:The Chisti presence in Delhi was established by Qutbuddin Bakhtiyar Kaki  who was a disciple of Khwaja Muinuddin Chishti, who settled in Delhi from his homeland in Transoxiana in c.1221 CE.

ques: Which of the following founded the Order of the Whirling Dervishes in the thirteenth century?
ans_detail: Notes:Jalauddin Rumi who was a great Sufi mystic and poet, founded the Order of the Whirling Dervishes in the thirteenth century. He was born in Afghanistan in 1207 CE.

ques: Which of the following was the spiritual successor of Shaikh Nizamuddin?
ans_detail: Notes:After the death of Shaikh Nizamuddin in 1325 CE, he was succeeded by Shaikh Nizamuddin. But the spiritual successor of Shaikh Nizamuddin was Nasiruddin Mahmud, popularly known as Chiragh-i-Delhi.

ques: What is the law of demand?
options: ["if the price of a good increases, the demand for that good decreases","if the price of a good increases, then the demand for that good increases","if the price of a good increases, the quantity demanded of that good decreases","if the price of a good increases, the quantity demanded of that good increases"]
ans: if the price of a good increases, the quantity demanded of that good decreases
ans_detail: Notes:The law of demand states that, other things remaining the same, the quantity demanded of a commodity is inversely related to its price. Thus, according to the law of demand, there is an inverse relationship between price and quantity demanded, other things remaining the same.

ques: What are internal economies?
options: ["arise when there is expansion in an industry","arise in an economy as it makes progress","accrue to a firm when it expands its output","arise when there is expansion in internal trade"]
ans: arise when there is expansion in an industry
ans_detail: Notes:Internal Economies: Reduction in cost of production – which accrues to the firm itself when it expands its production or increases the scale of production. Internal economies arise as a result of their own expansion within a firm, independent of the size and expansion of the industry as a whole.

ques: Selling cost will have to be borne in case of__
options: ["Perfect Competition","Monopoly","Monopolistic Competition","None of the given options"]
ans_detail: Notes:A good product is a product that people demand more as income increases. These are products that are usually more expensive and rare, like diamonds and classic cars.

ques: The principle of maximum social benefit is the basic principle of which of the following?
ans_detail: Notes:The principle of ‘maximum social benefit’ is a fundamental principle of public finance which was introduced by British economist Hugh Dalton. It should aim at all financial actions of the state to maximize net social benefit. It takes into account both aspects of public finance which is government revenue or taxation as well as government expenditure. It studies the problems related to government taxation and spending, it comes under the domain of fiscal economics.

ques: Cultivation of cotton crops comes under which of the following areas of economic activity?
ans_detail: Notes:The cultivation of cotton crops comes under the primary sectors. The primary sector is an area in which raw materials are extracted from the earth. Agriculture is the biggest example of primary sector in India.

ques: As a result of the high rate of inflation in India, the U
ans_detail: Notes:As a result of the high rate of inflation in India, the US dollar will appreciate and the Indian rupee will depreciate. This will lead to an increase in imports of American goods into India and a decrease in Indian exports to the United States, which, in turn, will lead to a foreign exchange rate of dollar in rupee terms and the price of the Indian rupee in dollar terms.

ques: The food stock created during the years of bumper harvest is called?
ans_detail: Notes:Commercial grain stock is the current amount of grain harvest stored domestically, including both on-farm and off-farm storage sites. Buffer stocks are created to ensure food security during periods of normal or bumper harvest, when production is below normal demand during poor agricultural years.

ques: Who is also known as Lender of the Last Resort?
ans_detail: Notes:The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is known as the Lender of Last Resort. This is because when a commercial bank faces a financial crisis and fails to obtain funds from other sources, then the central bank provides them with financial assistance in the form of credit. This role of the central bank saves the commercial bank from bankruptcy.

ques: Who recommends the Minimum Support Price (MSP)?
options: ["The Commission for Weights and Measures","The Food Safety and Standards Authority of India","The Farmers’ Welfare Society","The Commission for Agricultural Costs and Prices"]
ans: The Commission for Agricultural Costs and Prices
ans_detail: Notes:Minimum Support Price (MSP) is a form of market intervention by the Government of India to insure agricultural producers against any sharp fall in agricultural prices. The Minimum Support Price is announced by the Government of India at the beginning of the sowing season for certain crops based on the recommendations of the Commission for Agricultural Costs and Prices (CACP).

ques: A situation where the expenditure of the government exceeds its revenue is called__
ans_detail: Notes:The Budget Deficit is the financial situation wherein the expenditures exceed the revenues. It generally relates to the government’s expenditure and not the business or individual’s spending. The budgetary deficit is usually expressed as a percentage of GDP.

ques: Which of the following reef are isolated and discontinuous patches, lying shoreward of offshore reef structures?
ans_detail: Notes:Patch Reefs are isolated outcroppings of corals that are in close proximity to each other but are physically separated by sand rings lying shoreward of offshore reef structures as seen in the Palk Bay, Gulf of Mannar and Gulf of Katchchh.

ans_detail: Notes:Algal blooms can be greenish, brown, and even reddish orange depending upon the type of organism, the type of water, and the concentration of the organisms. They are scientifically known as Harmful Algal Blooms (HABs).

ques: What is the IUCN status of Blue Whale?
ans_detail: Notes:The IUCN status of Blue Whale is Endangered. Its scientific name is “Balaenoptera musculus”. Blue Whale is the largest animal in the world which weighs close to 200 tons and is the loudest animal on Earth, with their calls reaching 188 decibels.

ques: Which of the following statements are correct about “Mountain Plover”?1
ans_detail: Notes:Mountain Plover’s IUCN status is “Near Threatened”. They only nest on bare ground or areas with sparse vegetation. They are one of 12 birds which inhabit the western Great Plains.

ques: What is the IUCN status of white-bellied heron?
ans_detail: Notes:The IUCN status of white-bellied heron is Critically Endangered. It is also known with the name of imperial heron or great white-bellied heron. It is found in the foothills of the eastern Himalayas in India and Bhutan to northeastern Bangladesh and Burma.

ques: What is the IUCN status of the Attenborough’s pitcher plant?
ans_detail: Notes:The scientific name of Attenborough’s pitcher plant is Nepenthes attenboroughii. The species appeared on the 2012 list of the world’s 100 most threatened species. The IUCN status of the Attenborough’s pitcher plant is Critically Endangered.

ques: India became a contracting party to the Ramsar Convention in which of the following year?
ans_detail: Notes:The Ramsar Convention was signed in 1971. India became a contracting party to the Ramsar Convention in 1981 and has been implementing conservation programmes for wetlands, mangroves and coral reefs.

ques: Which of the following lists species that are the most endangered among CITES-listed animals and plants?
ans_detail: Notes:Appendix I includes species threatened with extinction. It provides the greatest level of protection including restrictions on commercial trade. Some of the examples include gorillas, sea turtles, most lady slipper orchids, and giant pandas.

ques: The headquarters of UNCCD is located at which of the following places?
ans_detail: Notes:United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification is the first and only internationally legally binding framework set up to address the problem of desertification. It is headquartered at Bonn in Germany.

ques: Which country became the champion of the 2018 FIBA Women’s Basketball World Cup?

ques: In which Summer Olympics, table tennis got introduced for the first time?
options: ["1976 Summer Olympics","1980 Summer Olympics","1984 Summer Olympics","1988 Summer Olympics"]
ans_detail: Notes:In the 1988 Summer Olympics, table tennis got introduced for the first time. Table tennis is a sport in which two or four players hit a lightweight ball, also known as the ping-pong ball, back and forth across a table using small rackets. The game takes place on a hard table divided by a net.

ques: What is Tomokazu Harimoto famous for?
options: ["As a Japanese table tennis player","As a Japanese tennis player","As a Japanese badminton player","As a Japanese polo player"]
ans: As a Japanese table tennis player
ans_detail: Notes:Tomokazu Harimoto is a Japanese table tennis player. Tomokazu Harimoto is a Japanese table tennis player. In 2018, he won the 2018 World Junior Singles and Team Title at the ITTF 2018 World Junior Championship for Japan.

ques: What is Manika Batra famous for?
options: ["As an Indian squash player","As an Indian tennis player","As an Indian table tennis player","As an Indian badminton player"]
ans: As an Indian table tennis player
ans_detail: Notes:Manika Batra is an Indian table tennis player. As of January 2019, she is the top-ranked female table tennis player in India and ranked 47th in the world. She specialises in playing long-pimples on her backhand, a rubber which is not often played by top players. She received the Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna award in 2020.

ques: What is Sathiyan Gnanasekaran famous for?
options: ["As an Indian badminton player","As an Indian squash player","As an Indian table tennis player","As an Indian tennis player"]
ans: As an Indian table tennis player
ans_detail: Notes:Sathiyan Gnanasekaran is an Indian table tennis player, currently ranked at 32 in the world as of April 2020. He was a member of the Indian team that took the bronze in the 2011 Junior World Championships. In May 2019, Sathiyan attained his career-best World ranking of 24 and became the first Indian paddler ever to break into the World Top-25 ITTF rankings.

ques: Which country won the most number of medals in table tennis at the 2018 Commonwealth Games?
ans_detail: Notes:India won the most number of medals in table tennis at the 2018 Commonwealth Games. Table tennis at the 2018 Commonwealth Games was held at the Oxenford Studios on the Gold Coast, Australia from April 5 to 15.

ques: Who won the gold medal in table tennis men’s singles at the 2018 Commonwealth Games?
ans_detail: Notes:Gao Ning won the gold medal in table tennis men’s singles at the 2018 Commonwealth Games. Table tennis at the 2018 Commonwealth Games was held at the Oxenford Studios on the Gold Coast, Australia from April 5 to 15.

ques: Which sport’s tournament is known as the “Solheim Cup”?
ans_detail: Notes:The Solheim Cup is a biennial golf tournament for professional women golfers contested by teams representing Europe and the United States. It is named after the Norwegian-American golf club manufacturer Karsten Solheim, who was a driving force behind its creation.

ques: Which famous golf player is nicknamed as “The King”?
ans_detail: Notes:Arnold Palmer was an American professional golfer who is generally regarded as one of the greatest and most charismatic players in the sport’s history. Dating back to 1955, he won numerous events on both the PGA Tour and the circuit now known as PGA Tour Champions. Nicknamed The King, he was one of golf’s most popular stars and seen as a trailblazer, the first superstar of the sport’s television age, which began in the 1950s.
