ques: Which among the following mountain ranges and their peaks is not correctly matched?
options: ["Ural Mountains – Mt. Narodnaya","Hindukush Mountains – Mt. Trich Mir","Himalayas – Mt. Everest","Caucasus Mountains – Mt. Lesotho"]
ans_detail: Notes:The Caucasus mountains in Europe are located between the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea. Mt.Elbrus is the highest peak in the Caucasus mountains. The Drakensberg Mountains in South Africa, are young folded mountains. Mt. Lesotho is the highest peak in the Drakensberg Mountains.

ques: Which is the highest mountain in South America?
ans_detail: Notes:Mt. Aconcagua in the Andes is the highest mountain in South American continent. It is 6960 metres above sea level. It is located in Argentina.

ques: Which is the highest mountain in the European continent?
ans_detail: Notes:Mount Elbrus is the highest mountain on the European continent. It is 5642 metres above sea level. It is located in Russia.

ques: What is the proportion of insolation that is reflected back by the surface called?
ans_detail: Notes:Albedo is the proportion of insolation that is reflected back by the surface. It depends upon the nature of the surface upon which the solar radiation is incident and the angle of incidence of the solar beam.

ques: Which is a Mediterranean wind that comes from the Sahara and reaches hurricane speeds in North Africa and Southern Europe?
ans_detail: Notes:Sirocco is a harm wind causing dry dusty conditions along the northern coast of Africa, storms in the Mediterranean Sea, and cool wet weather in Europe. It is a Mediterranean wind that comes from the Sahara and reaches hurricane speeds in North Africa and Southern Europe.

ques: What type of climate is present in Mountain areas of Uttarakhand?
options: ["Tundra Type","Polar Type","Tropical Savannah type","Hot Desert Type"]
ans_detail: Notes:According to Koeppen’s climate classification system, the Mountain areas of Uttarakhand are characterised by Et(Tundra) of climate. The average temperature varies from 0 to 10°C.

ques: What is the average width of the continental shelves?
ans_detail: Notes:The continental shelf is the stretched margin of all continent occupied by comparatively shallow gulfs and sea. It is the shallowest part of the ocean. The average width of continental shelves is about 80 km.

ques: Which among the following statements is/are correct about Ocean Temperature?The maximum and minimum annual temperatures of ocean water in the Northern Hemisphere are in the months of August and February respectively
ans_detail: Notes:The temperature of the oceans is not uniform. The maximum and minimum annual temperatures of ocean water in the Northern Hemisphere are in the months of August and February respectively.The annual range of temperature is higher for the inland seas as compared to the open oceans.

ques: Which among the following statements is not correct about the salinity of ocean?
options: ["More saline water freezes slower than lesser saline water","Salinity decreases the density of sea water","The boiling point of saline water is higher than fresh water","Evaporation is lower over more saline water"]
ans: Salinity decreases the density of sea water
ans_detail: Notes:Salinity is defined as ‘the total amount of solid material in grams contained in 1 kg of sea water and is expressed in parts per thousand’.Salinity is directly positively related to seawater density. Salinity increases the density of sea water.

ques: As per the census 2001, the maximum number of urban centers falls under which category of cities specified by the census department?

ques: Who gave the Competing Migrants Model of Migration?
ans_detail: Notes:In 1960, Stouffer further modified his theory of intervening opportunities and added a concept of competing migrants. According to the new model during a given time interval, the number of migrants from city 1 to city 2 is the direct function of the number of opportunities in city 2 and an inverse function of the number of opportunities intervening between city 1 and city 2, and also the number of other migrants for the opportunities in city 2.

The right pulmonary artery is _____:
options: ["Longer than the left","Shorter than the left","Wider than the left","Of same size as the left"]
ans_detail: Notes:The right pulmonary artery is longer and larger and runs horizontally outward in front of right main bronchus and behind the superior vena cava, to the base of the right lung where it divides in two branches. The left pulmonary artery is shorter and runs horizontally over the left upper division bronchus, to the base of the left hilum where it divides into two branches.

ques: Which one of the following forms the base of vegetable fibres?
ans_detail: Notes:The principal chemical component of vegetable fibres is cellulose, with varying amounts of lignin and hemicelluloses also usually present; thus, the fibres are also referred to as cellulosic or lignocellulosic. Examples include cotton, hemp, jute, flax, ramie, sisal, bagasse, and banana. Vegetable fibres are usually stiffer but less tough than synthetic fibres.

ques: Which one of the following is known as the immovable property in the cell?
ans_detail: Notes:Nucleic acids are large biological molecules essential for all known forms of life. They include DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) and RNA (ribonucleic acid). They are merely transmitted from one generation to next.

ques: The ‘DPT vaccine’ is given to young babies to protect them from ____:
options: ["Diphtheria, Polio and Tetanus","Diphtheria, Pneumonia and Tuberculosis","Diphtheria, Smallpox and Tetanus","Diphtheria, Whooping cough and Tetanus"]
ans_detail: Notes:DPT refers to a class of combination vaccines against three infectious diseases in humans: diphtheria, pertussis (whooping cough) and tetanus. The vaccine components include diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, and killed whole cells of the organism that causes pertussis.

ques: ____ is a straw coloured, viscous fluid constituting nearly 55 per cent of the blood:
ans_detail: Notes:Plasma is a straw coloured, viscous fluid constituting nearly 55 per cent of the blood. 90-92 per cent of plasma is water and proteins contribute 6-8 per cent of it. Fibrinogen, globulins and albumins are the major proteins. Fibrinogens are needed for clotting or coagulation of blood; while, globulins primarily are involved in defense.

ques: Which among the following does not have a cell wall?
ans_detail: Notes:Mycoplasma is a genus of bacteria that lacks a cell wall around their cell membrane. Without a cell wall, they are unaffected by many common antibiotics such as penicillin or other beta-lactam antibiotics that target cell wall synthesis. In comparison to other prokaryotes, they are consequently placed in a separate class Mollicutes(mollis, soft; cutis, skin).

ques: Pulses are obtained from the family of ____:
ans_detail: Notes:Pulse, in botany, is a common name for members of the Fabaceae (Leguminosae), a large plant family. Pulses, high in protein, are used as food for humans and other animals. Besides, they play a key role in crop rotation due to their ability to fix nitrogen.

ques: Excess of fluoride in drinking water causes ____:
options: ["Intestinal infection","Mottling of teeth","Lung disease","None of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:Enamel fluorosis is a mottling of the tooth surface that is attributed to fluoride exposure during tooth formation. The process of enamel maturation consists of an increase in mineralization within the developing tooth and concurrent loss of early-secreted matrix proteins. formation.

ques: Choose the correct option regarding the statements
options: ["Statement I is correct, but Statement II is incorrect","Statement I is incorrect, but Statement II is correct","Both statements I and II are correct","Both statements I and II are incorrect"]
ans: Statement I is correct, but Statement II is incorrect
ans_detail: Notes:A meristem is the tissue in most plants containing undifferentiated cells (meristematic cells), found in zones of the plant where growth can take place. Meristems give rise to permanent tissues.

ques: Which of the following disease does not spread through the air?
ans_detail: Notes:Cholera is an infection of the small intestine by some strains of the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. It is a water borne disease. Tuberculosis (TB) is an infectious disease usually caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB). Tuberculosis, Cough-cold and Pneumonia are air borne diseases.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following kings fought with Parasikas?
ans_detail: Notes:According to the details of the achievements of Yasovarman as given in Gaudavaho, Yasovarman marched into  South India, defeated the King of the Deccan, and reached the Southern Sea. He also fought against the Parasikas and received tribute from the regions of Western Ghats.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following founded their rule in the northern Karnataka and the Konkan in fourth century A
ans_detail: Notes:The Kadambas was an ancient royal family of Karnataka that founded their rule in the northern Karnataka and the Konkan in fourth century A.D. The Pallavas also came into conflict with Kadambas.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Where was the earliest capital of the Gangas situated?
ans_detail: Notes:The earliest capital of the Gangas was located near Kolar. The Kolar supplied a lot of gold to the kingdom of Gangas. They made most of the land grants to the Jainas. They were earlier feudatories of the Pallavas.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Tantricism puts special emphasis on which of the following?1
ans_detail: Notes:Tantricism puts special emphasis on certain things like Mantras which are prayers and formulae, Bijas which are syllables of mystic significance peculiar to each deity, Yantras which are diagrams drawn on paper or inscribed in preciousstone, metal, etc., Mudras means special positions of fingers and movements of hands and Nayasas involve placingthe deities on different parts of the body by touching them with finger tips and the palm, mostly of the right hand.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: At which of the following places, Jain and Brahmanical (Saiva and Vaishnava) temples were erected in the typical Aryavarta style in medieval India?
ans_detail: Notes:The period from 600 A.D. to 1000 A.D. was the golden era of religious architecture. The Hindu monarchs competed with one another in the magnificence and number of their temples. At Khajuraho, Jain and Brahmanical (Saiva and Vaishnava) temples were erected in the typical Aryavarta style.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following authors wrote Sabdansusana?
ans_detail: Notes:Sakatayana was a Jain writer of the 9th century A.D.He lived during the reign of  Rashtrakuta ruler Amoghavarsha. He was the founder of a new school. His main work was Sabdansusana.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following kings succeeded the king Amoghvarsha I?
ans_detail: Notes:Krishna II who ruled the Rashtrakuta Empire from 878 A.D. to  914 A.D. ascended the Rashtrakuta throne after the demise of his father Amoghavarsha I who ruled the Rashtrakuta empire for 64 years. His Kannada name was Kannara.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following succeeded Pulkshein II after pushing the Pallavas out of Badami?
ans_detail: Notes:The Chalukyan King Vikramaditya I succeeded in pushing the Pallavas out of Badami after the death of Pulkshein II and reestablished his authority over whole kingdom. He not only defeated the successive Pallava rulers but also captured their capital Kanchi.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: The Manda site of Indus Valley Civilization is located on bank of which river?
ans_detail: Notes:Indus Valley Civilization site Manda is situated on the right bank of Chenab river in the foothills of Pir Panjal range, 28 km northwest of Jammu. It was excavated by Archaeological Survey of India during 1976-77 by J. P. Joshi.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following was birth place of Buddha?
ans_detail: Notes:Gautam Buddha was born into the Shakya royal family in the sacred area of Lumbini located in the Terai plains of southern Nepal, testified by the inscription on the pillar erected by the Mauryan Emperor Asoka in 249 BC. He grew up in Kapilvastu, the capital city of the Shakya kingdom. Using historical records, Buddha’s birth date is usually given as May 563 BC. He was an ascetic, a religious leader and teacher. In the Vaishnavite sect of Hinduism, the historic Buddha or Gautama Buddha, is the ninth avatar among the ten major avatars of the god Vishnu.

Cephalopoda is a class of animals in which__
options: ["Notochord extends up to the head","The foot is located on the head","The Head is located on the foot","The Head is fused with the thorax"]
ans: The foot is located on the head
ans_detail: Notes:Cephalopoda is a class of animals in which the foot is located on the head. A cephalopod is any member of the class Cephalopoda of the phylum Mollusca.

ques: A connecting link between reptiles and birds is __
ans_detail: Notes:A connecting link between reptiles and birds is Archaeopteryx. Archeopteryx had a complete set of teeth, a rather flat sternum, a long, ponytail, australis, and three claws on the wing.

ques: The sweat glands in mammals are primarily concerned with:
options: ["Regulation of water content","Regulation of body heat","The killing of skin bacteria","Removal of excess salt"]
ans_detail: Notes:The sweat glands in mammals are primarily concerned with the regulation of body heat. When the internal temperature rises, the eccrine glands secrete water to the surface of the skin, where the heat is removed by evaporation.

ques: In terms of animal products, what is Mohair?
ans_detail: Notes:Mohair is a fabric or yarn made from the hair of the Angora goat. Mohair is one of the oldest textile fibers. It is composed of keratin, a protein found in the hair, wool, horns, and skin of all mammals

ques: What is the unit of the Nervous system?
ans_detail: Notes:The units that make up the nervous system are nerve cells or neurons. Therefore, it is called the functional and structural unit of the neuron nervous system. Neuron is the largest cell in the body.

ques: The persistence of vision for the human eye is __
options: ["1/6th of a second","1/10th of a second","1/16th of a second","1/18th of a second"]
ans_detail: Notes:The persistence of vision for the human eye is 1/16th of a second. The process of seeing begins when light rays from the objects you see pass through the cornea, the clear, dome-like structure that covers your eyes.

ques: Which of the following is protein hormone?
ans_detail: Notes:Insulin and human growth hormone are protein hormones while oxytocin and antidiuretic hormones are peptide hormones. TSH or Thyroid Stimulating Hormone consists of carbohydrates attached to protein hence it comes under glycoprotein hormone.

ques: Which is the Growth hormone inhibiting hormone?
ans_detail: Notes:Somatostatin works against Growth Hormone (GHRH), hence it is known as Growth Inhibiting Hormone. It consists of two peptides of 14 and 28 amino acids and is released from neurosecretory nerves.

ques: Human sperm moves with the help of which of the following?
ans_detail: Notes:Human sperm moves with the help of the Flagellum. The flagellum is primarily a motility organ that enables movement and chemotaxis.

ques: Which of the following are the benefits of vermicomposting?
options: ["develops roots of the plants","increases the fertility and water-resistance of the soil","Both 1 and 2","Neither 1 nor 2"]
ans_detail: Notes:The benefits of vermicomposting are to develop roots of the plants, improve the physical structure of the soil, and increase the fertility and water-resistance of the soil.

ques: Which committee’s recommendations became the basis for drafting an amendment bill for conferring the constitutional status and protection to the Panchayati Raj institutions?
options: ["Balwant Rai Committee","Ashok Mehta Committee","Thungon Committee","Gadgil Committee"]
ans_detail: Notes:The recommendations of the Gadgil Committee which was constituted in the year 1988 became the basis for drafting an amendment bill aimed at conferring the constitutional status and protection to the Panchayati Raj institutions.

ques: How are the members of a Port Trust selected?
ans_detail: Notes:A port trust, created by an Act of Parliament, has both elected and nominated members. It performs more or less similar functions as that of a municipality.

ques: Which of the following are the sources of income for the urban local bodies?
ans_detail: Notes:Urban local bodies have six sources of income-1. Tax Revenue2. Non-tax Revenue3. Grants4. Devolution5. Loans

ques: Who submits a report to the president regarding the administration of scheduled areas?
ans_detail: Notes:The governor has a special responsibility regarding scheduled areas. He has to submit a report to the president regarding the administration of scheduled areas, annually or whenever so required by the president.

ques: Who can make provisions with respect to matters relating to delimitation of constituencies?
ans_detail: Notes:The Parliament of India can make provisions with respect to all matters relating to elections to the Parliament and the state legislatures. It can also make provisions with respect to the preparation of electoral rolls, the delimitation of constituencies and all other matters necessary for securing their due constitution.

ques: In which year the Election Commission made the earliest attempt to regulate opinion polls?
ans_detail: Notes:The earliest attempt to regulate opinion polls was made in 1998. The ECI took an overall view of the situation and issued an order laying down “Guidelines for Publication and Dissemination of Results of Opinion Polls/Exit Polls”.

ques: Who said that the CAG shall be the most important Officer under the Constitution of India?
ans_detail: Notes:Dr. B.R. Ambedkar said that the Comptroller and Auditor General of India (CAG) shall be the most important Officer under the Constitution of India as his duty is to uphold the Constitution of India and laws of Parliament in the field of financial administration.

ques: Under which article of the constitution the CAG advises the President with regard to prescription of the form in which the accounts of the Centre and the states shall be kept?
ans_detail: Notes:Under Article 150 of the Constitution of India the CAG advises the President with regard to prescription of the form in which the accounts of the Centre and the states shall be kept.

ques: Which of the following commissions recommended the establishment of the institution of Lokpal and Lokyukta?
options: ["Administrative Reforms Commission","Sarkaria Commission","Srikrishna Commission","None of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:Lokpal and lokayukta were to be set up based on the recommendations of the Administrative Reforms Commission of India (1966–1970) for the redressal of grievances of citizens.

ques: Which article of the constitution contains provisions regarding the reservation of seats for scheduled castes and scheduled tribes in the legislative assemblies of the states?
ans_detail: Notes:The article 332 of the Constitution of India contains provisions regarding the reservation of seats for scheduled castes and scheduled tribes in the legislative assemblies of the states in India.

ques: Which of the following were present in the Akbar’s Navratnas?1) Abul Fazl2) Kabir3) Fakir Aziao DinSelect the correct option from the codes given below:
ans_detail: Notes:Akbar was a great lover of the artists and intellectuals. He had a passion for knowledge and interest in learning. He endorsed the court with great minds & genius. Nine of these courtiers were known as Akbar’s Navratnas. And these were: Abul Fazl. Abul Faizi, Fakir Aziao Din, Tansen, Raja Birbal/ Mahesh Das, Raja Todar Mal, Raja Man Singh, Abdul Rahim Khan-i-Khanan, Abdul Rahim Khan-i-Khanan.

ques: Who succeeded Jahandar Shah?
ans_detail: Notes:Jahandar Shah was succeeded by Farrukh Siyar. Farrukh Siyar was the brother of Jahandar Shah. He defeated Jahandar Shah at Agra in c.1713 CE. He ruled from c.1713 to 19 CE.

ques: The Badshahi Mosque in Lahore was built by which Mughal Emperor?
ans_detail: Notes:The Badshahi Mosque in Lahore, Pakistan was commissioned by the sixth Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb. Constructed between 1671 and 1673, it was the largest mosque in the world upon construction. It is the third-largest mosque in Pakistan and the seventh-largest mosque in the world. The mosque is adjacent to the Lahore Fort and is the last in the series of congregational mosques in red sandstone.

ques: Who among the following was one of the women Nayanar saints?
ans_detail: Notes:Karaikkal Ammaiyar, earlier named Punitavati, was one of the Tamil Shaivite saints. She was married to a merchant but her ardent devotion to Lord Shiva conflicted with her duties as a wife and she thus chose to move out of the marriage, thereby denouncing the patriarchal norms

ques: Great Mosque lies inside which of the following buildings?
ans_detail: Notes:The Great Mosque lies inside the building of Gulbarga Fort. The mosque has 140 supporting pillars and multiple arches.

ques: Which was the ministry of foreign affairs in the Delhi Sultanate administration?
ans_detail: Notes:In the Delhi Sultanate, Diwan-I Risalt was the foreign ministry, in command of state connections with neighbouring kingdoms, and also tasked with allying with powerful rulers.

ques: Who established Khalji dynasty in Malwa Sultanate repacking Ghurid dynasty in 1436?
ans_detail: Notes:Hushang Khan’s son and heir, Muhammad Shah, was an ineffectual ruler and deposed by one of his nobles, who ascended the throne in 1436, with the title Muahmud Khalji ( 1436-69). He crushed Ghurid resistance and established the Khalji dynasty.

ques: Which Malwa Sultan was titled Qadir Shah?
ans_detail: Notes:Malwa’s new Sultan was Mallu Khan, who adopted the title Qadir Shah. He was a Far-sigthe d ruler, making peace with Silahdi’s sons, who ruled over Raisen, and improving relations with the Rajput chieftains. Sher Shah, the Sur ruler of Delhi, however, conquered Malwa and installed afghan governors there.

ques: In which year the battle of Chaul took place?
ans_detail: Notes:In the battle of Chaul in January 1508 the governor of Junagarh and the Egyptian fleet sent by the Mamluk Sultan were victorious, but the Egyptian and Gujarati fleets invincible at sea and opened negotiations for peace with governor Albuquerque.

ques: Who wrote commentaries on Jayadeva’s Gitagovinda?
ans_detail: Notes:Raja Kumbha is said to have been proficient in the Vedas, Smritis, Mimamsa, Upanishads, Vyakarana, politics and literature. He wrote commentaries on Jayadeva’s Gitagovinda and on Chandisatakam.

Mekhla Sador is an indigenous traditional dress of__
ans_detail: Notes:Mekhla Sador is an indigenous traditional Assamese dress traditionally worn by Assamese women.

ques: Who wrote Tazuk-i-Jahangiri?
ans_detail: Notes:Tujuk-i-Jahangiri or Tujuk-i-Jahangiri or Jahangir-nama is the autobiography of the Mughal emperor Noor-ud-din Muhammad Jahangir (1569-1627). Also known as Jahangirnama, [1] Tuzk-i-Jahangiri is written in Persian. He wrote memoirs on many stages of his life until his death in 1622. His own manuscript was wonderfully illustrated by his painters’ studio, [2] but the drawings were quickly scattered, mostly found in the Murakka (album).

ques: For which masterpiece did Rabindranath Tagore receive the Nobel prize?
ans_detail: Notes:The poet Rabindranath Tagore won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1913 for his anthology Gitanjali, published in London in 1913. It is part of UNESCO’s collection of representative works. Its main theme is devotion and its motto is “I am here to sing your songs”. The original collection of Bengali poems 156/157 was published on August 14, 1910. The English Gitanjali or Song Offering / Singing Angel is a collection of 103 English prose poems, English translations of Tagore’s own Bengali poems, and the first to be published. November 1912 by the India Society in London. It contains 53 translations of poems from the original Bengali Gitanjali, as well as 50 other poems from his other works. Translations are often revolutionary, ignoring or replacing large parts of the poem and combining two different verses in one context (song 95, which includes the offering songs 89 and 90).

ques: What is the period of Chayawad yug?
ans_detail:
Notes:Chhayavaad is that poetic stream of the romantic rise of Hindi literature which started around AD. From 1918 to 1937, it was the main Yugvani.
Jaishankar Prasad, Suryakant Tripathi ‘Nirala’, Sumitranandan Pant, Mahadevi Verma, Pandit Makhan Lal Chaturvedi are considered representative poets of this poetic stream. The credit for naming Chhayavaad goes to Mukutdhar Pandey.

ques: In which language did Kalhana write Rajatarangini?
ans_detail: Notes:Kashmir gained literary prominence when Kalhana composed Rajatarangini in Sanskrit.

ques: What is the state animal of Uttar Pradesh?
ans_detail: Notes:Barahsingha is the state animal of Uttar Pradesh. It is also known as Swamp deer.

ques: What is the national animal of Bihar?
ans_detail: Notes:Ox is the national animal of Bihar. Bos taurus is the scientific name of Ox.

ques: What is the national Tree of india?
ans_detail: Notes:Due to many medicinal properties and its long life, Ficus benghalensis or the Banyan (Bargad) tree is the national tree of india.

ques: How many genres of music were created by Amir Khusrau?
ans_detail: Notes:Amir Khusrau created six genres of music: khyal, tarana, Naqsh, Gul, Qaul, and Qalbana. Although,  some suggests that Sadarang may have been the father of modern khyal.

ques: How many melakarta ragas are there?
ans_detail: Notes:There are seventy-two melakarta ragas, thirty six of whose madhyama (subdominant) is shuddha (perfect fourth from the tonic), the remaining thirty-six of whose madhyama (subdominant) is prati (an augmented fourth from the tonic).

ques: What do we call the wave if the constituents of the medium oscillate perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation?
ans_detail: Notes:If the constituents of the medium oscillate perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation, we call the wave a transverse wave. If they oscillate along the direction of wave propagation, we call the wave a longitudinal wave

ques: Which of the following waves is absorbed by the ozone layer present in the atmosphere?
ans_detail: Notes:UV light in large quantities has harmful effects on humans. But fortunately, most of it is absorbed in the ozone layer in the atmosphere at an altitude of about 40 – 50 km.

ques: What is the effect of increase of temperature on the speed of sound?
options: ["it increases","it decreases","it may or may not increase","No effect"]
ans_detail: Notes:In any medium as we increase the temperature the speed of sound increases. For example, the speed of sound in air is 331 m s–1 at 0 ºC and 344 m s–1 at 22 ºC.

ques: Which of the following conditions will not show any Doppler effect?
options: ["When source and listener both are at rest","When medium alone is moving","When source and listener are moving in mutually perpendicular directions","All of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:Conditions for no Doppler effect : (i) When source (S) and listener (L) both are at rest. (ii) When medium alone is moving. (iii) When S and L move in such a way that distance between S and L remains constant. (iv) When source S and listener L, are moving in mutually perpendicular directions

ques: What is the freezing point of water as per the Fahrenheit scale?
ans_detail: Notes:The ice and steam point have values 32 °F and 212 °F, respectively, on the Fahrenheit scale and 0 °C and 100 °C on the Celsius scale.

ques: What is the value of universal gas constant?
options: ["2.31 J mol<sup>-1</sup> K<sup>–1</sup>","4.31 J mol<sup>-1</sup> K<sup>–1</sup>","6.31 J mol<sup>-1</sup> K<sup>–1</sup>","8.31 J mol<sup>-1</sup> K<sup>–1</sup>"]
ans_detail: Notes:As per the ideal gas equation, PV = nRT where R is the Universal Gas constant and has a value of 8.31 J mol-1 K–1.

ques: Which of the following is correct about the rate of loss of heat of the body, as per the Newton’s law of cooling?
options: ["It is directly proportional to the difference of body’s temperature and the surroundings","It is inversely proportional to the difference of body’s temperature and the surroundings","It is equal to the difference of body’s temperature and the surroundings","None of the above"]
ans: It is directly proportional to the difference of body’s temperature and the surroundings
ans_detail: Notes:According to Newton’s law of cooling, the rate of loss of heat, – dQ/dt of the body is directly proportional to the difference of temperature of the body and the surroundings.

ques: Which of the following is the efficiency of a Carnot engine(a = Temperature of source, b=Temperature of sink)?
ans_detail: Notes:Carnot engine is a reversible engine operating between two temperatures T1 (source) and T2 (sink). The Carnot cycle consists of two isothermal processes connected by two adiabatic processes. The efficiency of a Carnot engine is given as: 1 – T2/T1

ques: Which of the following is the mirror formula?
ans_detail: Notes:Mirror formula represents image distance (v), object distance (u) and focal length (f) of the mirror. The mirror formula is 1/v + 1/u = 1/f. In case of lens it is 1/v – 1/u = 1/f.

ques: What happens when light travels from a denser medium to a rarer medium?
options: ["it slows down and bends towards the normal","it speeds up and bends towards the normal","it slows down and bends away from the normal","it speeds up and bends away from the normal"]
ans: it speeds up and bends away from the normal
ans_detail: Notes:A ray of light travelling from a rarer medium to a denser medium slows down and bends towards the normal. When it travels from a denser medium to a rarer medium, it speeds up and bends away from the normal.

ques: Water cycle refers to:
options: ["an integrated attempt to recycle water in relatively arid regions","constant movement of water from ocean to land and back to ocean once again","scientific management of water in areas excessively plagued with water-logging","water distribution in relatively dry areas"]
ans: constant movement of water from ocean to land and back to ocean once again
ans_detail: Notes:Constant movement of water from ocean to land and back to ocean once again. During cycle water passes through the different phases.

ques: Surface water is a better source of drinking water because it is poor in:
ans_detail: Notes:Surface water is a better source of drinking water because it is poor in arsenic and other heavy metals. They being heavy sediment to water surface.

ques: The enormous amount of energy released in an explosion of an atmoic bomb is due to the:
options: ["conversion of mass into energy","conversion of chemical energy into heat energy","conversion of mechnical energy into nuclear energy","conversion of neutrons into protons"]
ans_detail: Notes:The enormous amount of energy released in an explosion of an atomic bomb is due to the converson of neutrons into protons. When a neutron strikes the nucleus of an atom of the isotopes uranium 235 or plutonium 239, it causes that nucleus to split into two fragmens, each of which is a nucleus with about half the protons and neutrons of the original nucleus. In the process of splitting, a great amount of thermal energy as well as gamma rays along with two or more neutrons, are released.

ques: The degree of dissociation of an electrolyte depends on:
ans_detail: Notes:The extent to which an electrolyte dissociates into ions is known as degree of dissociation or ionization and depends upon the following factors:(1) Nature of the electrolyte,(2) Temperature,(3) Dilution,(4) nature of the solvent, and(5) presence of other ions with respect to common ion effect.

ques: Which of the following can be used to absorb neutrons to control the chain reaction during nuclear fission?
ans_detail: Notes:Boron shielding is used as a control for nuclear reactors, taking advantage of its high cross-section for neutron capture. Elemental boron is rare and behaves more similarly to silicon than to aluminium. Crystalline boron is chemically inert and resistant to attack by boiling mineral acids.

ques: Which of the following particles were made to fall on a thin gold foil by Ernest Rutherford?
ans_detail: Notes:Ernest Rutherford directed beams of alpha particles (which are the nuclei of helium atoms and hence positively charged) at thin gold foil to test this model and noted how the alpha particles scattered from the foil. He realised that the positively charged alpha particles were being repelled and deflected by a tiny concentration of positive charge in the atom. As a result of this experiment, the plum pudding model was replaced by the nuclear model of the atom.

ques: The antiseptic compound present in dettol is:
ans_detail: Notes:The active ingredient in Dettol that confers its antiseptic property is chloroxylenol (C8H9ClO), an aromatic chemical compound. Chloroxylenol comprises 4.8% of Dettol’s total mixture, with the rest composed of pine oil, isopropanol, castor oil soap, caramel and water.

ques: Which of the following is used to make light weight, but strong plastic?
ans_detail: Notes:Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) is a common, strong but lightweight plastic that is used in making tough plastic. It is used for flexible applications such as insulating cables. It is the third-most widely produced synthetic plastic polymer, after polyethylene and polypropylene.

ques: Malathion is a/an:
ans_detail: Notes:Malathion is an organophosphate (OP) insecticide that has been registered for use in the United States since 1956. It is widely used in agriculture, residential landscaping, public recreation areas, and in public health pest control programs such as mosquito eradication. It is of relatively low human toxicity.

ques: Chemistry of carbon compounds is known is:
ans_detail: Notes:In chemistry, an organic compound is generally any chemical compound that contains carbon. Organic compounds contain carbon bonds in which at least one carbon atom is covalently linked to an atom of another type (usually hydrogen, oxygen or nitrogen). Most polymers are organic compounds.

ques: How many islands lie within Australia's borders - 822 or 8,222?
Which Middle Eastern country opened its borders to foreign tourists in 2019?
The Spanish Steps are in which city?
In which country would a thumbs up be considered a rude gesture?
Which two cities did the original Orient Express travel between?
If you were to visit the National Diet, you would be visiting the parliament of which country?
O'Hare Airport serves which American city?
Lemurs can only be seen in the wild on which country?
Which Caribbean Island is known as the Island of Spice?
Which capital city is the furthest north in the world?
In which African country can you order a fantasy coffin?
Which European country has the most World Heritage sites?
What is the capital city of Serbia, which has been battled over in 115 wars due to its strategic position?
The Straight of Gibraltar connects the Atlantic Ocean with which Sea?
Where can you visit Tivoli Gardens?
On the London Underground map, which line is the colour black?
If you were cruising in Halong Bay, you would be in what country?
What flightless bird is the native symbol of New Zealand?
What were the top three most confiscated items at airport security in 2019?
ans: Snow globes, jams and spreads, toiletries

ques: Grand Canyon National Park is in which US state?
Who won the gold medal in table tennis men’s singles at the 2018 Commonwealth Games?
ans_detail: Notes:Gao Ning won the gold medal in table tennis men’s singles at the 2018 Commonwealth Games. Table tennis at the 2018 Commonwealth Games was held at the Oxenford Studios on the Gold Coast, Australia from April 5 to 15.

ques: Which of the following is golf’s governing body along with the United States Golf Association, who governs the rules and the sport of golf worldwide?
options: ["The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews","The R&A","International Golf Federation","International Olympic Committee"]
ans_detail: Notes:The R&A is golf’s governing body along with the United States Golf Association, who governs the rule and the sport of golf worldwide. They operate in different areas of the world, with the USGA governing in the United States and Mexico and The R&A governing in the rest of the world. They both share a single code for the Rules of Golf, Rules of Amateur Status, Equipment Standards and World Amateur Golf Rankings.TheR&A’s head office is based in Scotland.

ques: What is “Muirfield” famous for?
options: ["As a golf club","As a tennis club","As a football club","As a table tennis club"]
ans_detail: Notes:Muirfield is a privately owned links which is the home of The Honourable Company of Edinburgh Golfers. Located in Scotland, overlooking the Firth of Forth, Muirfield is one of the golf courses used in rotation for The Open Championship.

ques: Who won the gold medal in golf women’s individual at the 2016 Summer Olympics?
ans_detail: Notes:Inbee Park won the gold medal in golf women’s individual at the 2016 Summer Olympics. Golf at the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, was held in August at the new Olympic Golf Course. The 2016 Summer Olympics was the first time golf had been played at the Olympics since the 1904 Summer Olympics and featured two events: the men’s and women’s individual events.

ques: Which boxing style is in which a boxer who generally lacks finesse and footwork in the ring, but makes up for it through sheer punching power?
ans_detail: Notes:A brawler is a fighter who generally lacks finesse and footwork in the ring but makes up for it through sheer punching power. Many brawlers tend to lack mobility, preferring a less mobile, more stable platform and have difficulty pursuing fighters who are fast on their feet.

ques: Which professional wrestler’s nickname is “King Kong”?
ans_detail: Notes:Emile Czaja, better known by his ring name King Kong, was an Australian-Indian professional wrestler. He was active from 1929 until 1970. He wrestled mostly in Japan, Singapore, Europe, New Zealand, and Australia. In professional wrestling, his arch-rivals were Aslam Pahalwan, Hamida Pahalwan, Sheik Ali and Dara Singh.

ques: Which sport’s regional form is “Sambo”?
ans_detail: Notes:Sambo is a Soviet martial art, an internationally-practised combat sport, and a recognized style of amateur wrestling included by UWW in the World Wrestling Championships along with Greco-Roman wrestling and freestyle wrestling.

ques: Headquarters of the International Powerlifting Federation is located in which country?
ans_detail: Notes:The International Powerlifting Federation is an international governing body for the sport of powerlifting as recognized by the General Association of International Sports Federations (GAISF) as well as the International Olympic Committee via inclusion into the World Games, headquartered in Luxembourg.

ques: The “Ligat Ha’Al” is the top professional handball league of which country?
ans_detail: Notes:Ligat Ha’Al is the top Israeli professional handball league. The league is sponsored by Winner Corporation since 2010 and known also as Ligat Winner. Founded in 1954, the league currently consists of 12 teams and managed by the Israel Handball Association.

ques: Which country won the gold medal in men’s handball at the 2016 Summer Olympics?
ans_detail: Notes:Denmark won the gold medal in men’s handball at the 2016 Summer Olympics. The men’s tournament of Handball at the 2016 Summer Olympics at Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, began on 7 August and ended on 21 August 2016. Games were held at the Future Arena.

ques: Which among the following is/are warm ocean currents in the Pacific Ocean?California currentOyashio currentNorth Pacific DriftHumboldt currentSelect the correct code from the options given below:
ans_detail: Notes:Warm Ocean Currents in Pacific Ocean:North Equatorial Current South Equatorial Current Counter Equatorial Current Kuroshio System East Australia Current North Pacific DriftCold Ocean Currents in pacific ocean:Oyashio Current California CurrentPeruvian or Humboldt Current

ques: Which among the following primary weather conditions is/are associated with a coastal region?Sea Breeze During The DayLand Breeze In The EveningsModerate Climate Throughout The YearSelect the correct code from the options given below:
ans_detail: Notes:The climate of a coastal region is characterized by several weather conditions, which combine to form atmospheric conditions that are unique to areas in and around the coast.Primary weather conditions associated with a coastal region:Sea Breeze During The DayLand Breeze In The EveningsModerate Climate Throughout The YearCoastal FogHigher Rainfall Than Inland Areas

ques: What settlement is produced when the inter-settlement distances in a region are almost equal?
ans_detail: Notes:A uniform pattern of settlement – It is produced when the inter-settlement distances in a region are almost equal. It indicates a uniform distribution of basic resources. These settlements can sometimes be a result of planned development of settlements for the utilisation of uniformly distributed resources.

ques: Which among the following areas is/are occupied by Migratory Herders?Dry steppe region of RussiaTropical grasslands south of SaharaSemi-deserts of South-western and Central AsiaSelect the correct code from the options given below:
ans_detail: Notes:Pastoral herding is the simplest form of pastoral activity. Migratory people travelling with their flocks or herds occupy three great areas in the Eastern Hemisphere which include the semi-deserts of South-western and Central Asia, together with the dry steppe region of Russia, the tropical grasslands south of Sahara in Africa, and sub-Arctic forests of Eurasia.

ques: What is a specialized branch of aquaculture which involves the cultivation of marine organism for food and other products in the open ocean, an enclosed section of the ocean called?
ans_detail: Notes:Mariculture – It is a specialized branch of aquaculture which involves the cultivation of marine organism for food and other products in the open ocean, an enclosed section of the ocean. Example, farming of marine fish, prawns, or oysters in salt water ponds.

ques: What are the favourable conditions for Fishing in the world?Abundance of planktonClimateMarketFishing PortsSelect the correct code from the options given below:
ans_detail: Notes:‘Fishery’ –  the act of catching animal life from water. It refers to the place where fish are caught. Oceans are vast treasure houses of fish and other-marine mammals. Favourable Conditions for Fishing in the world:Abundance of planktonClimateMarketFishing Ports

ques: What are large units where sheep are reared in Australia called?
ans_detail: Notes:Large units where sheep are reared in Australia are called sheep stations. The term applied to large animal farms inSouth America is estancias. The ranches or sheep stations consist of large areas of natural pasture and also the ranch house and some area devoted to supplementary feed crops.

ques: Where did the most popular dairy cow, the Holstein-Friesian originate?
ans_detail: Notes:The best dairy cows that form the foundation of modern dairy farming in most parts of the world are native to Western Europe. The most popular dairy cow, the Holstein-Friesian originated in the coastal lowlands of the Netherlands and Germany.

ques: Which cheese from southern France is made from sheep milk and cured in limestone caves?
ans_detail: Notes:Ireland and northern France are well-known for their excellent butter. The highlands of southern France are famous for their quality cheese. A cheese from southern France, Roquefort, is made from sheep milk and cured in limestone caves.

ques: Which among the following countries is/are the leading producers of Tin?ChinaPeruBrazilSelect the correct code from the options given below:
ans_detail: Notes:Tin is one of those important metals that are used for making alloys. The alluvial deposits in Southeast Asian region are the most important source of this metal. The world’s leading producers are China, Indonesia, Peru, Brazil, Malaysia and Bolivia.

Which of the following statements are correct regarding Agenda 21?1
ans_detail: Notes:Agenda 21 is an outcome of the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED) held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, in 1992. It is a comprehensive blueprint of action to be taken in every area in which humans directly affect the environment. The number 21 refers to an agenda for the 21st century.

ques: Which of the following statements are correct regarding CITES?1) Species may be added to or removed from Appendix I and II, or moved between them, only by the Conference of the Parties
ans_detail: Notes:Species may be added to or removed from Appendix I and II, or moved between them, only by the Conference of the Parties. However, species may be added to or removed from Appendix III at any time and by any Party unilaterally.

ques: Birdlife International was established in which of the following year?
ans_detail: Notes:BirdLife International is a global partnership of non-governmental organizations which was formed in 1922. It strives to conserve birds and their habitats. It serves the objective of Partnership for Nature and People.

ques: Birdlife International is headquartered at which of the following places?
ans_detail: Notes:BirdLife International was founded in 1922 as the International Council for Bird Preservation by American ornithologists T. Gilbert Pearson and Jean Theodore Delacour. Initially it was founded under the name International Committee for Bird Protection. It is headquartered at Cambridge, United Kingdom.

ques: Which of the following statements are correct regarding Ozone gas?1
ans_detail: Notes:Ozone naturally occurs in the upper layers of the atmosphere. It shields the earth from the harmful ultraviolet rays of the sun. At the ground level however, it is a pollutant with highly toxic effects.

ques: Which of the following country is the largest Greenhouse Gas emitter?
ans_detail: Notes:With a share of almost 30 percent of the world’s total CO2 emissions, China tops the ranking of the largest green house gas emitter and the USA is the second largest Greenhouse Gas emitter.

ques: Which of the following are the dimensions for adaptation and mitigation under National Mission for Sustainable Agriculture?1
ans_detail: Notes:The dimensions for adaptation and mitigation under National Mission for Sustainable Agriculture are as follows: 1. Improved Crop Seeds, Livestock and Fish Culture, 2. Pest Management, 3. Water Efficiency, 4. Improved Farm Practices, 5. Nutrient Management, 6. Agricultural Insurance, 7. Credit Support, 8. Markets, 9. Livelihood Diversification and 10. Access to Information

ques: What percentage of total forest area of Karnataka is reserve forest?
ans_detail: Notes:With total area of 29,688.37 sq. km, 68% of total forest area of Karnataka is reserve forest.

ques: What kind of trees grow in Deciduous forest of Karnataka?
ans_detail: Notes:eak, kino, mahogany, neem, mango, jack, flame, kokko, banyan, sandal and bamboo grows in Deciduous forest of Karnataka.

ques: Dodo is a bird categorized under ____:
ans_detail: Notes:The dodo (Raphus cucullatus) is an extinct flightless bird that was endemic to the island of Mauritius, east of Madagascar in the Indian Ocean. Subfossil remains show the dodo was about 1 metre (3ft 3 inches) tall and may have weighed 10.6–17.5 kg (23– 39 lb) in the wild. The closest living relative of the dodo is the Nicobar pigeon.

ques: Which of these words refers to the scientific study of domestic dogs?
ans_detail: Notes:Cynology is the study of matters related to canines or domestic dogs. Craniology is the study of differences in shape, size and proportions among skulls from various human races. Carpology is the branch of botany dealing with fruits and seeds.

ques: Tachycardia is a condition characterized by ____:
options: ["Heart rate increases from the normal","Heart rate decreases from the normal","Heartbeat stops","Heart fails to pump"]
ans: Heart rate increases from the normal
ans_detail: Notes:Tachycardia is a heart rate that exceeds the normal resting rate. In general, a resting heart rate over 80 beats per minute is accepted as tachycardia in adults. A healthy adult heart normally beats 60 to 100 times a minute when a person is at rest. Tachycardia occurs when an abnormality in the heart produces rapid electrical signals.

ques: Which of the following is true with reference to blood platelets?
options: ["They have prominent nuclei","They are involved in phagocytosis","They have a pigment called haemoglobin","They are also called thrombocytes"]
ans_detail: Notes:Platelets, also called thrombocytes, are a component of blood whose function is to stop bleeding by clumping and clotting blood vessel injuries. Unlike red and white blood cells, platelets are not actually cells but rather small fragments of cells.

ques: Cockroach cannot survive in the water because its respiratory organ is ____:
ans_detail: Notes:In cockroach, an arthropod belonging to class Insecta, the respiratory system includes openings called spiracles present in abdominal surface. These opening are further connected with trachea, trachioles and bronchioles to direct allow the atmospheric air to interact with body cells for gaseous exchange. Therefore, cockroach with its abdomen immersed in water die of oxygen starvation.

ques: Which among the following vitamin helps in controlling infection in human body?
ans_detail: Notes:Vitamin C (Ascorbic acid) is an antioxidant that protects body from free radicals‘ damages. It is used as therapeutic agent in many diseases and disorders. Vitamin C protects the immune system, reduces the severity of allergic reactions and helps fight off infections.

ques: Locomotory organ of a starfish is _____:
ans_detail: Notes:Starfish carry out movements with the help of tube feet that are part of the water vascular system. Apart from their function in locomotion, the tube feet act as accessory gills. The water vascular system serves to transport oxygen from, and carbon dioxide to, the tube feet and also nutrients from the gut to the muscles involved in locomotion.

ques: Which of the following is used for wrapping of fractured bones?
ans_detail:
Notes:Plaster of Paris is a plaster made by calcining gypsum.
CaSO4•1/2?H2?O.
It can be used to impregnate gauze bandages to make a sculpting material called modroc. It is used to make classic plaster orthopedic casts to protect limbs with broken bones.

ques: Webbed neck is a characteristic of _____:
ans_detail: Notes:A webbed neck, or pterygium colli deformity, is a congenital skin fold that runs along the sides of the neck down to the shoulders. It is a feature of Turner syndrome and Noonan syndrome, as well as the rarer Klippel-Feil syndrome. Turner Syndrome (TS) is a condition in which a female is partly or completely missing an X chromosome.

ques: Bulbils takes part in ____:
ans_detail: Notes:Bulbil is a small bulblike organ of vegetative reproduction growing in leaf axils or on flower stalks of plants such as the onion and tiger lily. It is a reproductive organ that takes part in vegetative reproduction. The bulbils drop from the parent plant on to the ground, give out adventitious roots and develop into new plants. The other structures involved in vegetative propagation include rhizome, bulb, corm, cuttings, etc.

ques: Maximum oxygen is available from _____:
ans_detail: Notes:Most of Earth’s oxygen comes from tiny ocean plants – called phytoplankton – that live near the water’s surface and drift with the currents. Like all plants, they photosynthesize – that is, they use sunlight and carbon dioxide to make food. Scientists believe that phytoplankton contribute between 50 to 85 percent of the oxygen in Earth’s atmosphere (National Geographic).

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Parameshvaraman I was succeeded by which of the following kings?
ans_detail: Notes:Narsimhavarman II also known as Rajasimha ruled the Pallavas in the south from 700 A.D. to 728 A.D. By the time Rajasimha ascended the throne, the Pallavas had the most powerful military force in the subcontinent.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following statements are correct regarding Chola administration?1
ans_detail: Notes:The Chola government carried out land surveys regularly and a record of holdings was also maintained. All the royal dues were collected by the village assemblies. These were paid either in cash or in kind or both.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of the following kings assumed the title of Kongarkoman?
options: ["Maravarman Arikesari Parankusan","Maravarman Rajasimha I","Koccadiyan Ranadhira","Srimar Srivallabha"]
ans_detail: Notes:Koccadiyan Ranadhira who ruled from 700 A.D. to  730 A.D. reduced an Ay chief at Mardur “a hill country between Tinnevelly and Travancore.” He also conquered the Kongu country and assumed the title of Kongarkoman.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: What are the schools of arts developed during the Kushan Period known as?
ans_detail: Notes:Gandhara School of art of India during Kushan Period shows Greek influence, therefore, it is known as Indo-Greek art. It was an influential mixture of both Indian and Greek art. The important features of this school are : (i) Buddha is shown as Roman and Greek gods (ii) Moustache and beard are added to Buddha’s face (iii) The figures of this school follow a given ratio between the size of the face and rest of the body. During first and second century blue grey schist stone was used to make idols.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which of these is a knwon Buddhist Literature?
ans_detail: Notes:Tripitaka is a traditional term used by various Buddhist sects to describe their various canons of scriptures. As the name suggests, a Tripitaka traditionally contains three “baskets” of teachings: a Sutra Pitaka, a Vinaya Pitaka and an Abhidharma Pitaka. Tripitaka is the three main categories of texts that make up the Buddhist canon. It is the oldest collection Buddhist scriptures.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: What was the ancient name of Guwahati?
ans_detail: Notes:Guwahati lies between the banks of the Brahmaputra River and the foothills of the Shillong plateau. The ancient cities of Pragjyotishpur (Guwahati) a and Durjaya (North Guwahati) were the capitals of the ancient state of Kamarupa.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Which lake of Gujarat was built as an artificial reservoir by Mauryas?
ans_detail: Notes:Saurashtra lake was built by Pushyagupta the provincial ruler of Chandragupta Maurya. Ashoka’s governor Tushak, later drew a canal from it. During the time of Rudradaman, the lake dam was broken due to excessive rainfall and he repaired it. In the Gupta period by the order of Skandagupta, Chakrapalit rebuilt the lake. Skandagupta spent money with great generosity and got a dam built on this lake.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: During which ruler Greek ambassador Megasthenese visited India?
ans_detail: Notes:Megasthenes was the ambassador of Seleucus Nicator, a Hellenistic emperor, appointed to the court of Chandragupta Maurya after Seleucus defeated at the hands of Chandragupta c.305 BC. He lived in the court of Chandragupta Maurya for about five years (302-298 B.C.). ‘Indica’ by Megasthenes is helpful in reconstructing the social structure of India during the Mauryan period.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: How many Mahajanpadas were there in the 7th and early 6th centuries BC?
ans_detail: Notes:The Mahajanapadas were sixteen kingdoms or oligarchic republics that existed in ancient India from the sixth to fourth centuries BC, during the lifetime of Gautam Buddha. Ancient Buddhist texts like the Anguttara Nikaya make frequent reference to sixteen great kingdoms and republics which had evolved and flou-rished in a belt stretching from Gandhara in the north-west to Anga in the eastern part of the Indian sub-continent.

topic: ancient indian history multiple choice questions
ques: Who founded the Chalukya dynasty?
ans_detail: Notes:Pulakeshin I (540–567) was the founder and first sovereign ruler of the Chalukya dynasty of Vatapi and as such, has been termed as the “real founder” of his dynasty.He ruled parts of the present-day Maharashtra and Karnataka states in the western Deccan. Pulakeshin established the city of Vatapi, and performed the Ashva-medha sacrifice to assert his sovereign status.

ques: The largest invertebrate is a/an ____:
ans_detail: Notes:The largest invertebrate is Mollusc. With over 80,000 species, molluscs form the second largest phylum of animals on Earth and range from tiny snails to giant squid and octopuses.

ques: In a period from Li to F, ionisation potential:
ans_detail: Notes:Ionization energy increases along a period with increase in atomic number. However, in the periodic table, going from left to right, while the Ionization Potential of Li is 5.4 eV, that of Be: 9.3 eV, B: 8.3 eV, C: 11.3 eV, N: 14.6 eV, O: 13.6 eV, and F: 17.0 eV.

ques: Who developed the model of atomic structure?
ans_detail: Notes:In 1911 Ernest Rutherford used experimental evidence to show that an atom must contain a central nucleus. Neils Bohr further developed Rutherford’s nuclear atom model. He used experimental evidence to support the idea that electrons occupy particular orbits or shells around positively charged the nucleus of an atom.

ques: How many moles are present in 36 gm of water?
ans_detail: Notes:The molecular weight of H2O = 18. Thus, 18 grams of H2O = 1 mol of H2O 36 grams of H2O = 2 mole of H2O

ques: The atoms of the elements having same difference between mass number and atomic number are called:
ans_detail: Notes:Atomic number is the number of protons present in an atom; while, mass number is the sum of the number of protons and the neutrons of an atom. Isotones are the atoms of different elements which contain same number of neutron with different mass number and atomic number. For example, Silicon and Phosphorous have same number of neutron 16 with different mass number 30,31 and atomic number 14,15.

ques: The major constituent of air is:
ans_detail: Notes:Depending on various geographical locations average air composition may change, but for the most part air, it is made up of 78% nitrogen (N2), 21% oxygen (O2), and trace amounts of carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), hydrogen (H2), argon (Ar) and helium (He). The CO2, CH4, H2, Ar, and He, when combined together, make up about 1% of our air.

ques: Which of the following is used in welding broken pieces of iron rails and machine parts?
ans_detail: Notes:Aluminum powder is a highly flammable powder produced by grinding aluminum into fine grains of material. Aluminium powder is used to reduce iron oxide in aluminothermy process to produce iron (molten) for welding. Piece of magnesium are used to charge toe mixture.Fe2O3 + 2Al —> Al2O3 + 2Fe

ques:
Which among the following is an incorrect pair?
(Natural source) – (Acid)Vinegar – Acetic acidCurd – Lactic acidTamarind – Citric acidSelect the correct answer from the codes given below:
ans_detail: Notes:Tamarinds contain high levels of tartaric acid, just as citrus fruits contain citric acid. Tartaric acid, a carboxylic acid, gives tamarind its sour color. It also contains a significant level of vitamin C, E, and B, calcium, iron, phosphorous, potassium, manganese, and dietary fiber. There are also a number of organic compounds that make tamarind a powerful antioxidant and anti-inflammatory agent.

ques: Which of the following is radioactive in nature?
ans_detail: Notes:Thorium is a radioactive chemical element found in nature as thorium-232. It is found primarily in the rare earth mineral monazite but can also be found in euxenite and thorianite. Thorium is found more abundantly in the Earth’s crust than uranium and only occurs naturally in an oxidized form.

ques: Bayer’s reagent is:
options: ["Alkaline potassium permanganate","Acidified potassium permanganate","Hydrogen peroxide","Bromine water"]
ans_detail: Notes:Baeyer’s reagent is an alkaline solution of potassium permanganate, which is a powerful oxidant. It is used in organic chemistry in a qualitative test for finding the presence of unsaturation. i.e. presence or absence of double or triple bond in hydrocarbon.

ques: What will be the apparent frequency when the both source of the sound and listener move in the same direction with same velocity?
options: ["it will be more than the actual frequency","it will be less than the actual frequency","it will be equal to the actual frequency","None"]
ans: it will be equal to the actual frequency
ans_detail: Notes:When both moves in the same direction with same velocity n’ = n, i.e. there will be no Doppler effect because relative motion between source and listener is zero.

ques: What do we call the process in which no exchange of heat energy takes place between the gas and the surroundings?
ans_detail: Notes:A process in which no exchange of heat energy takes place between the gas and the surroundings, is called an adiabatic process.

ques: Which of the following represents the Boiling process?
ans_detail: Notes:Boiling and Melting both are an example of Isothermal processes because temperature is constant.

ques: Which of the following metals is mostly used for filaments of electric bulbs?
ans_detail: Notes:Tungsten is mostly used to manufacture filaments of electric bulbs. Among all the metals, Tungsten has the highest melting point. Its symbol is W, its atomic number is 74, and its atomic weight is 183.85. It is used in many other high temperature application because of its high melting point.

ques: What is the equivalent EMF of a series combination of n cells?
options: ["the arithmetic mean of their EMFs","the product of their individual EMF","the sum of their individual EMF","None of the above"]
ans: the sum of their individual EMF
ans_detail: Notes:The equivalent emf of a series combination of n cells is just the sum of their individual EMFs.

ques: What do we call a cell that induces a spontaneous redox reaction to create a flow of electrical charges?
options: ["Voltaic cell","Electrolytic cell","Such cells don’t exist","None of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:A Galvanic cell or Voltaic cell induces a spontaneous redox reaction to create a flow of electrical charges, or electricity.

ques: Which of the following is the name given to electrons moving at high speed?
ans_detail: Notes:Beta particles are the electrons moving at high speed.

ques: Which of these rays have the highest ionising power?
ans_detail: Notes:Alpha rays have the highest ionising power followed by Beta rays and then Gamma rays.

ques: Which of the following metal foils was used in the Rutherford’s alpha particle scattering experiment?
ans_detail: Notes:Rutherford directed beams of alpha particles (which are the nuclei of helium atoms and hence positively charged) at thin gold foil and noted how the alpha particles scattered from the foil.

ques: What happens to the resistance of a p-n junction diode when forward biased?
options: ["it becomes high","No effect","it becomes low","it becomes zero"]
ans_detail: Notes:The resistance of a p-n junction diode becomes low when forward biased and becomes high when reverse biased. This is the principle of the working of rectifier.

ans_detail: Notes:The Governor appoints the upalokayukta in consultation with the following-1. Chief justice of the state high court2. Leader of Opposition in the state legislative assembly

ques: India’s exclusive economic zone extends upto how many nautical miles?
ans_detail: Notes:The territorial waters of India extend to a distance of about 12 nautical miles from the appropriate base line. Similarly, India’s exclusive economic zone extends upto 200 nautical miles.

ques: In which of the following cases the Supreme Court criticised the doctrine of sovereign immunity of the State?
options: ["P and O Steam Navigation Company case","Kasturilal case","Nagendra Rao Case","None of the above"]
ans_detail: Notes:The Supreme Court of India criticised the doctrine of sovereign immunity of the State and adopted a liberal approach with respect to the tortuous liability of the State in the Nagendra Rao Case of the year 1994.

ques: In 2015 the government of which state laid down the preconditions to its police personnel before invoking sedition?
ans_detail: Notes:In a 2015 circular, the government of the state of Maharashtra laid down certain preconditions to its police personnel before invoking sedition. The circular came during the hearing of a public interest litigation (PIL) in the Bombay High Court, after a cartoonist was booked for sedition under section 124A.

ques: Which section of IPC is related to offences related to Marriage?
ans_detail: Notes:The section 493 to 498 of Indian Penal Code is related to offences related to Marriage. Section 493  states “A man by deceit causing a woman not lawfully married to him to believe that she is lawfully married to him and to cohabit with him in that belief” is an offence.

ques: An application regarding domestic violence can be presented to which of the following?
ans_detail: Notes:An application regarding domestic violence can be presented to magistrate for seeking one or more reliefs mentioned in the section by: (1) the aggrieved person, (2) protection officer on behalf of aggrieved person, (3) any other person on behalf of aggrieved person.

ques: The Mental Health Act was passed in which year?
ans_detail: Notes:The Mental Health Act was passed on 22 May 1987 in India. The Mental Health Act of 1987 superseded the previously national law governing the mental health issues, the Indian Lunacy Act of 1912.

ques: The Inter-State Migrant Workmen (Regulation of Employment and Conditions of Service) Act was passed in which year?
ans_detail: Notes:The Inter-State Migrant Workmen (Regulation of Employment and Conditions of Service) Act in the year 1979 by the Parliament of India. It was enacted to regulate the condition of service of inter-state labourers.

ques: GST is a type of which of the following?
options: ["Direct tax","Indirect tax","It depends on the goods and services","It depends on the associate states"]
ans_detail: Notes:Goods and Service tax is a type of indirect tax.

ques: The independent state of Bengal was founded by which of the following king?
ans_detail: Notes:The independent state of Bengal was founded by Murshid Quli Khan. Murshid Quli Khan united his force and position and in the year 1719 and renamed his capital city from Makhsusabad to Murshidabad after his name.

ques: Which of the following Nizam of Hyderabad secured the protection of French General Bussy in 18th century to protect his territories?
ans_detail: Notes:Salabat Jung was the 4th Nizam of Hyderabad and the 3rd son of Nizam-ul-Mulk. After death of Nizam-ul-Mulk, the question of succession gave opportunities to the Marathas,French and the English to play King Makers. In 1751-52, Nizam Salabat Jang secured the protection of the French general, Bussy. This made Hyderabad stronger and it was not easy to eliminate the Nizam so long French General was there.

ques: Which of the following statements are correct?1
ans_detail: Notes:The Doctrine of Lapse was introduced by Lord Dalhousie. The states that were annexed by the application of this doctrine of lapse are Satara, Jaitpur and Sambalpur, Baghat, Udaipur, Jhansi and Nagpur. Due to this annexation policy discontent simmered among many sections of Indian society and the largely indigenous armed forces.

ques: Which of the following portfolio was held by Rajendra Prasad in the interim government formed in 1946?
ans_detail: Notes:The Interim Government of India, had the task of assisting the transition of British India to independence. The Food and Agriculture Portfolio was held by Rajendra Prasad in the interim government formed in 1946.

ques: Which of the following statements are correct?1
ans_detail: Notes:August offer was made in 1940. Cabinet Mission arrived in 1946. Muslim League Launched Direct Action in 1946. Jinnah wrecked of the Shimla Conference in 1945.

ques: During which of the following period the worst famine occurred in India under the British rule?
ans_detail: Notes:The Great Famine of 1876–1878 was a famine in India which occurred under the rule of the British crown. It began in 1876 after an intense drought resulting in crop failure in the Deccan Plateau.

ques: In which year, Vandemataram Movement started?
ans_detail: Notes:After partition of Bengal in 1905, Swadeshi Movement started in Bengal as well as several other parts of the country. It is also known as Vandemataram Movement. It included Swadeshi and Boycott as two main strategies centered around objective of unification of Bengal.

ques: Which revolutionary was charged with Mainpuri Conspiracy in 1919?
ans_detail: Notes:Ram Prasad Bismil, through his revolutionary organisation Matrivedi, and Genda Lal Dixit, through his armed youth organisation Shivaji Samiti, mobilised youths in Etawah, Mainpuri, Agra and Shahjahanpur to collect funds for the party through loot of the government treasury in 1918. The whole plan came to be known as the ‘Mainpuri Conspiracy’. The Judiciary Magistrate of Mainpuri held Dixit, Bismil and others as absconders on 1 November 1919.

ques: Which of the following statements are correct regarding Mofussil police force which was organised on a large scale after the Maratha war in 1817?1
ans_detail: Notes:The Mofussil police force which was organised on a large scale after the Maratha war in 1817, consisted of three elements, the village police, the stipendiary district police and certain irregular corps. The Collector and District Magistrate was the head of the entire police organisation in the district.
